EPISODE_NARRATIVE: North-central and northeast OH resided within the warm sector from 7 AM on the 27th through 7 AM EST on the 28th. Simultaneously, a surface low moved east-northeastward from southern MN to near Georgian Bay and allowed the trailing cold front to sweep eastward to western OH. During the late morning of the 27th, a multicell thunderstorm associated with a low-level jet (LLJ) undergoing moist isentropic ascent persisted northeastward across Lake County and produced hail up to nickel-size. Additional multicell thunderstorms associated with a separate LLJ undergoing moist isentropic ascent persisted generally east-northeastward or eastward across portions of north-central and northeast OH during the early morning of the 28th. These storms produced hail as large as pennies to quarters. All of the aforementioned storms occurred amidst moderate to strong effective bulk shear, steep mid level lapse rates, and weak to moderate MUCAPE.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to nickel-size about one-mile west of Concord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure pushed northeast from the Tennessee Valley and moved along and off the coast. An accumulating snow took place across interior portions of Northeastern New Jersey, with far northwestern sections towards Western Passaic, Western Essex, and Northern Bergen receiving an accumulating snow of 3 to 6 inches. Further south and east where the snow mixed with, and even changed to rain amounts were much lower.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Accumulating snow took place across the zone, with amounts that were reported between 3 and 5 inches. Cocorahs reports were 4.5 inches in Wayne, 4.3 inches in West Milfored, 4.1 inches in Little Falls, and a trained spotter came in also with 3.8 inches in Wayne. These amounts fell short of warning criteria with the snow going over to mixed precipitation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure pushed northeast from the Tennessee Valley and moved along and off the coast. An accumulating snow took place across interior portions of Northeastern New Jersey, with far northwestern sections towards Western Passaic, Western Essex, and Northern Bergen receiving an accumulating snow of 3 to 6 inches. Further south and east where the snow mixed with, and even changed to rain amounts were much lower.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An accumulating snow took place before a mix and change to rain. Reports averaged in the 2 to 4.5 inch range for the most part. Cocorahs reported 4.0 inches in Verona and 3.5 inches at 1.3 NE West Caldwell.  There was a public report of 4.4 inches in North Caldwell and 3.5 inches in West Orange. Amounts fell short of warning criteria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved northeast from the Mid-Atlantic Region to southern New England during the night of January 9, 2024. Its center passed just north of the region with the pressure gradient tightening as the center of the storm approached, producing high winds over Northeastern New Jersey during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1115 PM Local Standard Time, the Department of Highways reported in Fort Lee, NJ a downed tree on Routes 1 & 9 northbound, north of Bergen Boulevard with all lanes closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure shifted northeast through the eastern Great Lakes Region on January 13, 2024. This sent a warm front, quickly followed by a cold front, across Southeastern New York during the morning hours. The resulting strong pressure gradient helped produce high winds across the area during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured high wind gust of 60 mph occurred at a mesonet station located at Great Gull Island, NY at 636 AM Local Standard Time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On January 14, 2024, a strong pressure gradient resulted over Southern Connecticut in part from a strong low pressure system slowly moving across Southeastern Canada. An associated cold front passed through during the afternoon. The combination of the cold front and strong pressure gradient helped produce high wind gusts across the area during the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured high wind gust of 60 mph occurred at a mesonet station at Stonington Outer Breakwater, CT at 249 PM Local Standard Time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On January 14, 2024, a strong pressure gradient resulted over Southeastern New York in part from a strong low pressure system slowly moving across Southeastern Canada. An associated cold front passed through during the afternoon. The combination of the cold front and strong pressure gradient helped produce high wind gusts across the area during the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured high wind gust of 58 mph occurred at 421 PM Local Standard Time at a mesonet site located at Fishers Island Airport, NY.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large low pressure system impacted the area late on January 9th and into the 10th with long duration persistent moderate to heavy rainfall. In addition to widespread river flooding, some localized areas of flash flooding occurred as the heaviest rainfall associated with convection moved through. Precipitable water values of 1.2-1.4 inches were record levels for early January. The anomalous moisture and heavy rainfall resulted in a widespread 2 - 4 inches of rainfall, much of it occurring over a several hour timeframe before the cold frontal passage. The Yantic River reached Major Flood Stage on January 10th at 9Z and continued to remain in Major flood stage until 2330Z.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Yantic River remained in Major Flood Stage with a reported partial dam break in Fitchville as a result of heavy rain and snow melt.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure pushed northeast from the Tennessee Valley and moved along and off the coast. An accumulating snow took place across interior portions of Northeastern New Jersey, with far northwestern sections towards Western Passaic, Western Essex, and Northern Bergen receiving an accumulating snow of 3 to 6 inches. Further south and east where the snow mixed with, and even changed to rain amounts were much lower.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An accumulating snow took place before a change to a wintry mix. Trained spotters reported 6.2 inches at 2 NNE Franklin Lakes, 5.7 inches at 1 N Franklin Lakes, 4.0 inches at Franklin Lakes, 4.0 inches at Glen Rock, and 4.0 inches at 1 ESE Westwood, and 3.4 inches in Fair Lawn. A Cocorahs observer reported 5.5 inches at Oakland.  Amounts fell off quickly heading southeast. Amounts averaged below warning criteria across the zone.

The pressure gradient tightened as the center of the storm approached, producing high winds over Southern Connecticut during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple high wind gusts were recorded at mesonet sites, including 59 mph at 1145 PM Local Standard Time in Fairfield, CT and 60 mph at 1026 PM Local Standard Time in Stamford at an elevation of 131 feet.

A major storm across the Great Lakes remained nearly stationary during the afternoon of April 3rd as a coastal low developed off the NJ-DE that eventually moved to near Cape Cod, MA by midday April 4th. In addition, a strong area of high pressure was located in Hudson Bay but was ridging/cresting toward northern New England and NY.||Windy conditions developed across VT during the afternoon hours of April 3rd and continued into the early morning hours of April 4th. The stronger winds were located across southern VT where some wind gusts exceeded 50-60 mph with approximately 13,000+ outages due to wind.||Mixed rain, sleet and snow developed in the afternoon and evening hours of April 3rd and then transitioned to a heavy wet snow overnight through midday on April 4th. Snowfall totals ranged from 2 to 6 inches along the immediate lakeshore with 6 to 10 inches within 3-5 miles in the Champlain valley. Other snowfall totals were 8 to 12 inches within the immediate Connecticut River Valley with 12 to 20+ inches elsewhere across the state.||Impacts were significant across the region with hundreds of motor vehicle accidents, numerous school closing and more than 35.000 power outages at it's peak due to snow weighted trees on powerlines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy, wet snowfall totals of 10 to 15 inches were common with slightly lower amounts in the deepest valley with higher totals in the higher terrain. Some specific totals include; 20 inches in Waldon, 17 inches in Sutton, 16 inches in Stannard and Wheelock, 14 inches in West Burke, 12 inches in Groton, 10 inches in Danville with 9 inches in St. Johnsbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Just after sunrise, a quasi-linear convective system (QLCS) produced five confirmed EF-0 tornadoes. Four of these occurred in rural south-central Illinois, and another tracked through Charlack, Missouri in northern St. Louis County. No reported injuries or fatalities with these tornadoes. Also, there were a few reports of damaging winds and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak tornado touched down 3.7 miles southeast of Lambert International Airport, on Lackland Road. As it tracked to the northeast, it snapped off several large trees and caused minor shingle, soffit and gutter damage to two houses. Another home sustained moderate siding damage. Overall, the tornado was rated EF0 with a path length of 0.10 miles and a maximum width of 50 yards. The maximum sustained winds were estimated to be near 75 mph. No deaths or injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A historic tornado event for Wisconsin as the first documented tornado occurred in the month of February. An approaching cold front and upper level disturbance initiated the severe thunderstorms from late afternoon into the early evening.  An EF-1 tornado occurred in Green County near Juda/Albany and then a second tornado developed which was stronger and produced EF-2 level damage.  The long track tornado impacted 30 houses and numerous barns and outbuildings.  Only 1 injury occurred when the tornado hit someone driving a car near Hwy 14 and Territorial Rd.  A high volume of hail also occurred with these storms, but the largest hailstone were generally just at or above severe levels.

Additional snow chances continued mid-week, mostly for the northern Sierra. Conditions continued to be treacherous over the Sierra overnight on the 4th with breezy winds, snow, and blowing snow. Conditions briefly improved over the Sierra the morning through the afternoon of the 5th with additional snow shower chances continuing thereafter, especially for the Sierra north of US-50.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter located 5.0 mi WSW of June Lake Mountain Ski resort reported a 24 hour snowfall amount of 10.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level trough over the southern Appalachians pivoted across the Carolinas during the evening. This resulted in a band of showers and embedded storms across portions of central North Carolina. Numerous downed trees were reported as a result of strong downdrafts across the southern Piedmont, Sandhills, and southern Coastal Plain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and powerlines were reported down along south and north Randolph St, as well as north Lee St and Rockingham Rd in the town of Rockingham.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extreme winter storm affected all of southeast Idaho the first 4 days of the month.   Extreme amounts of Pacific moisture combined with several short waves and a cold frontal passage brought widespread snow amounts over a foot.  With temperatures near freezing, widespread damage occurred due to the heavy wet nature of the snow especially in the Snake River Plain.   Although there was a break in the snow late on the 2nd, it returned on the 3rd and continued into the 4th.   Strong winds were also a common feature with the multi day storm with widespread gusts over 40 mph causing blowing and drifting snow and low visibility by the 3rd and 4th when colder temperatures arrived.  Road closures were widespread.   Thunderstorms occurred with the cold frontal passage early on the 2nd.   School closures also occurred on the 4th as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy snow fell in the Caribou Range and combined with strong winds to cause power outages and road closures on the 2nd with very wet snow.   Road closures also occurred on the 4th with strong winds and blowing and drifting snow.    The Swan Valley COOP observer recorded 27 inches of snow.   US Highway 26 closed from Ririe to Swan Valley on the 2nd and also on the 4th.   Lower Valley Energy reported power outages from Palisades Reservoir to Swan Valley during the morning of the 2nd.   Idaho Highway 31 closed on the 4th from Swan Valley to Victor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extreme winter storm affected all of southeast Idaho the first 4 days of the month.   Extreme amounts of Pacific moisture combined with several short waves and a cold frontal passage brought widespread snow amounts over a foot.  With temperatures near freezing, widespread damage occurred due to the heavy wet nature of the snow especially in the Snake River Plain.   Although there was a break in the snow late on the 2nd, it returned on the 3rd and continued into the 4th.   Strong winds were also a common feature with the multi day storm with widespread gusts over 40 mph causing blowing and drifting snow and low visibility by the 3rd and 4th when colder temperatures arrived.  Road closures were widespread.   Thunderstorms occurred with the cold frontal passage early on the 2nd.   School closures also occurred on the 4th as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy and wet snow fell on the 1st and 2nd and a trained spotter recorded 31.8 inches of snow on 230 PM MST on the 2nd.   Idaho Highway 31 was closed from Swan Valley to Victor on the 4th due to blowing and drifting snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following summer-like, record warmth, severe thunderstorms developed in the late afternoon of February 27th over northwest Illinois and spread east through the evening across the Chicago metro area. A total of 11 tornadoes touched down in Illinois. There were 11 tornadoes in total across the NWS Chicago area of responsibility, which is the most in a February event since official NWS tornado records began in 1950. In addition to the tornadoes, the storms produced numerous instances of severe hail and damaging straight-line wind.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Will County EMA reported 1 hail in Bolingbrook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between January 28th and January 29th, a strong low pressure system organized over the Gulf of Alaska, then moved north towards the Prince William Sound.  This low was able to interact favorably with an extremely cold air mass entrenched over the southern Mainland, producing very high snow to liquid water ratios for the duration of the snowfall event across much of Southcentral.||The deep layer of cold air was able to stay mostly in place across the Mat-Su Valleys and Cook Inlet region as moderate to heavy snow moved in near the approaching low.  This lead to the extremely unusual combination of surface temperatures between 0 and 5F and heavy snow that lasted for many hours between 1/28 and 1/29.  This storm had widespread impacts to travel due to the prolonged nature of moderate to heavy snowfall rates for numerous locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: DOT closed the Richardson Highway, including Thompson Pass, around 10:40 am Jan 28, from MP 12-42 due to heavy snow and the potential for avalanche mitigation. Meanwhile, the Valdez Avalanche Center issued an Avalanche Warning for mountains surrounding Valdez and Thompson Pass due to the avalanche danger in place. DOT eventually reported 5 to 10 inches of snow along the Richardson Hwy between MP 12-42. ||Other local storm reports include: 28 inches, 30 inches, and 42 inches of snow in and around Valdez. There was also a snow report of 42 inches near Robe Lake in Valdez.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong offshore winds developed across the Southwest Coast ahead of a strong low pressure moving over the Bering Sea.  Small amounts of falling snow were observed for this event, with the strong winds acting as the main contributor to lowered visibility in blowing snow.  Numerous AWOS/ASOS and mesonet sites were not funtional during the event, but whiteout conditions were observed on several webcams along the Kuskokwim Delta Coast from the evening of 1/2 to the early morning of 1/3.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Toksok Bay AWOS recorded 1/4 mile visibility with falling/blowing snow from around 9 PM 1/2 to 1 AM AKST 1/3.  The wind sensor at the observation site was down for the course of the event, but a nearby mesonet site at Chefornak consistently recorded winds around 35 to 45 mph during this timeframe.  Webcam imagery along the coast helped verify conditions on the ground and showed extremely poor visibility along the Kuskokwim Delta Coast from the evening of 1/2 to early morning of 1/3.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over Siberia pushed a very cold Arctic air mass south over mainland Alaska on Jan 26 & 27. Low pressure in the Gulf helped draw colder air southward and kept a modest northerly wind across much of Southwest Alaska, leading to cold wind chills below -40F at several locations across Bristol Bay and the Kuskokwim Delta for multiple days near the end of January.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous observation sites across the Kuskokwim Delta recorded wind chills persistently between -40 and -50F, mostly between 1/27 and 1/29 with northerly winds between 10 and 20 mph.  The coldest wind chill values were recorded in Eek, where values dipped to -51F during the early morning hours of 1/29.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over Siberia pushed a very cold Arctic air mass south over mainland Alaska on Jan 26 & 27. Low pressure in the Gulf helped draw colder air southward and kept a modest northerly wind across much of Southwest Alaska, leading to cold wind chills below -40F at several locations across Bristol Bay and the Kuskokwim Delta for multiple days near the end of January.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several observation sites across Bristol Bay and the northern Alaska Peninsula recorded periods lasting several hours of northerly winds above 15 mph and wind chills lower than -40F.  Naknek recorded the longest stretch with wind chills below -40F between 10 PM AKST 1/27 and 4 PM AKST 1/28.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between January 28th and January 29th, a strong low pressure system organized over the Gulf of Alaska, then moved north towards the Prince William Sound.  This low was able to interact favorably with an extremely cold air mass entrenched over the southern Mainland, producing very high snow to liquid water ratios for the duration of the snowfall event across much of Southcentral.||The deep layer of cold air was able to stay mostly in place across the Mat-Su Valleys and Cook Inlet region as moderate to heavy snow moved in near the approaching low.  This lead to the extremely unusual combination of surface temperatures between 0 and 5F and heavy snow that lasted for many hours between 1/28 and 1/29.  This storm had widespread impacts to travel due to the prolonged nature of moderate to heavy snowfall rates for numerous locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: DOT reported up to 7 inches of snow on the Richardson Hwy between mileposts 42 and 82 at 0845 January 28th. Additionally, travel was severely hampered for the duration of the snow event as areas along the Richardson Hwy, including Thompson Pass, were closed due to heavy snow. Additionally, a Borough Official reported a storm total snow amount of 16 inches at 0800 January 29th in McCarthy, a town affected by the road closures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surge of deep northerly flow and strong cold air advection brought strong and gusty gap winds to much of Southcentral Alaska between 1/17 and 1/18.  The strongest wind gusts as high as 83 mph occurred through Thompson Pass on the evening of 1/17 at the peak of the northerly wind event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Department of Transportation (RWIS) observation site along the Richardson Highway in Thompson Pass recorded a gust to 83 mph at 9:30 PM AKST 1/17.  Gusts as high as 70 mph were also recorded at multiple sites in the port of Valdez from the evening of 1/17 to very early morning of 1/18.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With the influence of a mid-level trough to the north, a surface low pressure system moving across the Southeast U.S. pulled a warm front across South Florida on the morning of January 6th. Showers and thunderstorms moving north along the warm front produced a waterspout off the coast of Miami-Dade County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An airplane pilot reported a waterspout associated with a thunderstorm over the local Atlantic waters off the coast of Miami-Dade County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following summer-like, record warmth, severe thunderstorms developed in the late afternoon of February 27th over northwest Illinois and spread east through the evening across the Chicago metro area. A total of 11 tornadoes touched down in Illinois. There were 11 tornadoes in total across the NWS Chicago area of responsibility, which is the most in a February event since official NWS tornado records began in 1950. In addition to the tornadoes, the storms produced numerous instances of severe hail and damaging straight-line wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large storm system digging into the four corners region spread strong wind energy across a large portion of the nation including a large portion of West Texas. Warm temperatures allowed for deep boundary layer mixing which permitted strong winds aloft to mix down to the surface. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major storm across the Great Lakes remained nearly stationary during the afternoon of April 3rd as a coastal low developed off the NJ-DE that eventually moved to near Cape Cod, MA by midday April 4th. In addition, a strong area of high pressure was located in Hudson Bay but was ridging/cresting toward northern New England and NY.||Windy conditions developed across VT during the afternoon hours of April 3rd and continued into the early morning hours of April 4th. The stronger winds were located across southern VT where some wind gusts exceeded 50-60 mph with approximately 13,000+ outages due to wind.||Mixed rain, sleet and snow developed in the afternoon and evening hours of April 3rd and then transitioned to a heavy wet snow overnight through midday on April 4th. Snowfall totals ranged from 2 to 6 inches along the immediate lakeshore with 6 to 10 inches within 3-5 miles in the Champlain valley. Other snowfall totals were 8 to 12 inches within the immediate Connecticut River Valley with 12 to 20+ inches elsewhere across the state.||Impacts were significant across the region with hundreds of motor vehicle accidents, numerous school closing and more than 35.000 power outages at it's peak due to snow weighted trees on powerlines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports of wind gusts in excess of 45 mph, along with scattered tree debris and isolated to scattered power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front draped across central North Carolina served as a focus for thunderstorm redevelopment during the afternoon as the cold front shifted slowly south. Supercells developed across the southern Piedmont, Sandhills, and southern Coastal Plain Counties. The severe storms went on to produce prolific hail ranging from ping pong to just over hen egg size across southern portions of central North Carolina. One supercell thunderstorm went on to produce 3-4 inch hail in nearby Robeson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were reported down along US Highway 421 in Delway.

CZ_NAME: COASTAL WATERS FROM STAKE ISLAND LOUISIANA TO SOUTHWEST PASS OF THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER FROM 20 TO 60 NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed on the afternoon of April 28th in east Texas along the dryline. As the afternoon and evening progressed, these storms merged together into a mesoscale convective system. The outflow boundary from this MCS drove it southeastward from Texas into Louisiana on the 29th of April. As the leading edge of the storms passed over the local coastal waters, many marine observation platforms measured severe wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mesonet station KGLX Mississippi Canyon 724 measured a thunderstorm wind gust of 47 mph or 41 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-air analysis showed a trough over the northern Rockies the evening of May 23rd. That night, this trough ejected out into the central and northern Great Plains. At the surface, a low-pressure developed in western South Dakota. Extending south and southwest of this surface low into Colorado was a cold front. A secondary low-pressure center was noted in northwestern Kansas where the surface cold front intersected a dry line that extended south into western Texas. |Shortly after midnight, a line of severe thunderstorms along this cold front moved into the OAX CWA. From 05 UTC through 10 UTC, this line of storms brought widespread severe wind gusts up to 110 miles per hour and 17 spin-up tornadoes across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. These storms continued to be severe and tornadic through the morning of the 24th, later being classified as a derecho. |Troughing over the western CONUS continued to bring southwesterly flow aloft the region even behind this first trough. By the evening of the 25th, another shortwave trough had amplified over the Great Basin and had shifted over the Rocky Mountains. Ahead of this disturbance, a low-pressure developed in northwest Kansas, with a warm front extending east-southeast across northern and eastern Kansas. The evening of the 25th, scattered strong to severe thunderstorms developed across this frontal zone in northern Kansas and generally tracked to the east-northeast. As such, scattered thunderstorms moved into southeast Nebraska after 9 PM CDT. While largely remaining below severe limits, severe straight-line winds were observed along the south and east side of the Omaha metro as a thunderstorm tracked from western Otoe into eastern Pottawattamie County. It was estimated wind gusts reached as high as 70 miles per hour with this storm, with power outages being reported due to the winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 58 miles per hour wind gust was reported by a trained spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second, very strong, winter storm impacted Southwestern California. Rainfall totals were very significant across the area. Los Angeles county reported rain totals of 4 to 14 inches, Ventura county reported 2 to 10 inches, Santa Barbara county reported 4 to 12 inches and San Luis Obispo county reported 2 to 5 inches. With the heavy rainfall, numerous reports of flooding were received. In the mountains, very significant snowfall was reported with amounts in the 1 to 3 foot range. Also, severe thunderstorms and tornadoes were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported significant flooding on Highway 101 near Campo de Cahuenga. Numerous vehicles were stuck in the flood waters.

Across San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties, rainfall totals between 2 and 6 inches were reported which produced numerous reports of urban flooding. Across Ventura and Los Angeles counties, rainfall totals of 1 to 4 inches were reported along with some reports of flash flooding. In the mountains, winter storm conditions were observed with 2-5 inches of snowfall and wind gusts up to 69 MPH.

With the heavy rainfall, numerous reports of flooding were received. In the mountains, very significant snowfall was reported with amounts in the 1 to 3 foot range. Also, severe thunderstorms and tornadoes were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported the full closure of Highway 23 near Carlisle Road due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A third, powerful, winter storm brought significant impacts to Southwestern California. Rainfall totals ranged between 2 and 12 inches with the highest totals across southern Santa Barbara county and western Ventura county. With the heavy rainfall, numerous reports of flooding and mud/debris flows were reported. Also, some gusty winds were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant flooding closed Highway 1 between Black Road and Soloman Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first powerful storm of February brought heavy rain, flooding, mountain snow and wind to the area. Across San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties, rainfall totals between 2 and 6 inches were reported which produced numerous reports of urban flooding. Across Ventura and Los Angeles counties, rainfall totals of 1 to 4 inches were reported along with some reports of flash flooding. In the mountains, winter storm conditions were observed with 2-5 inches of snowfall and wind gusts up to 69 MPH.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winter storm conditions impacted the eastern range of the San Gabriel Mountains. Snowfall totals up to 3 inches were reported along with wind gusts up to 69 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front interacting with a seasonably warm and moist environment triggered clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms across central Illinois during the afternoon and evening of August 30th.  One cell dropped nickel-sized hail, while others produced wind gusts of around 60mph and minor wind damage.  In addition, urban flash flooding occurred across portions of Springfield and Champaign.  No road closures or water rescues were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing across the road and sidewalk on Columbia Avenue near Neil Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick hitting winter storm brought around 12 hours of snow, centered over Connecticut, with the greatest amount of snow in Massachusetts falling on Cape Cod and the islands. This was a notoriously difficult to forecast storm passing south of 40/70 benchmark, which was a significant shift south in the final 24 hours leading up to the storm. This moved the band of heavy snow well south of Boston (0.1) to Cape Cod which received 7-9 inches of snow. The heaviest snow of the storm fell in Hartford County, Connecticut where over 15 inches of snow was reported. The result was many schools and businesses in eastern MA closing and receiving little to no snow. Cape Cod had about 30,000 people lose power due to the heavy, wet nature of the snow. Winds were also strong on the Cape and islands, gusting 45 to 55 mph in the afternoon which reduced visibility in blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Generally 4 to 11 inches of snow fell in Hartford County. This was the bullseye of the snow totals in southern New England. Some notable accumulations included 15.5 inches in Farmington, 15.2 inches in West Hartford, and 12.5 inches in East Windsor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak clipper moved across the Ohio Valley on January 19th bringing light snow to the region. As the clipper progressed east into the 20th it intensified off the East Coast as cold air poured into the region. The light snow with the clipper on January 19th was enhanced by moisture picked up off of Lake Erie as colder air poured in. Continued cold air advection behind the East Coast low into the 20th and early 21st allowed lake effect snow showers to continue, particularly in the higher elevations in the Snowbelt region of extreme Northeast Ohio. The heaviest snow generally occurred during the daytime hours on January 19th in and around the Cleveland area, though the higher terrain of Geauga and Ashtabula Counties saw another period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers on the 20th. Snow rates reached 1 to 2 inches per hour at times with visibility occasionally falling below a quarter of a mile, especially in bands of heavy lake enhanced snow on the 19th. A trained spotter reported a prolonged storm total of 21.4 inches in Monroe Township in Ashtabula County. Other select reports include spotters reporting 13.1 inches in Garfield in Cuyahoga County, 12.5 inches in Macedonia in Summit County, 9.7 inches in Elyria in Lorain County and 9 inches in Streetsboro in Portage County. Cleveland Hopkins International Airport measured 6.9 inches of snow with this storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak clipper moved across the Ohio Valley on January 19th bringing light snow to the region. As the clipper progressed east into the 20th it intensified off the East Coast as cold air poured into the region. The light snow with the clipper on January 19th was enhanced by moisture picked up off of Lake Erie as colder air poured in. Continued cold air advection behind the East Coast low into the 20th and early 21st allowed lake effect snow showers to continue. There was a period of steadier and at times heavy snow during the afternoon and early evening hours on the 19th. Lake effect snow was heavy at times again on the 20th before gradually diminishing and ending by the early morning hours on the 21st. Snow rates reached 1 inch per hour at times with visibility occasionally falling below a half mile when snow was most intense. A trained spotter reported a prolonged storm total of 9.5 inches in Novelty, with other spotters reporting 8.3 inches in Burton and 7.8 inches in Chesterland. A CoCoRaHS observer measured 8 in Thompson, with a Cooperative observer in Chardon reporting 7.6 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extreme winter storm affected all of southeast Idaho the first 4 days of the month.   Extreme amounts of Pacific moisture combined with several short waves and a cold frontal passage brought widespread snow amounts over a foot.  With temperatures near freezing, widespread damage occurred due to the heavy wet nature of the snow especially in the Snake River Plain.   Although there was a break in the snow late on the 2nd, it returned on the 3rd and continued into the 4th.   Strong winds were also a common feature with the multi day storm with widespread gusts over 40 mph causing blowing and drifting snow and low visibility by the 3rd and 4th when colder temperatures arrived.  Road closures were widespread.   Thunderstorms occurred with the cold frontal passage early on the 2nd.   School closures also occurred on the 4th as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific system brought heavy snow and strong winds brought road closures at times for several days.   Snow amounts were 17 inches at the Island Park COOP site, 12 inches at Harriman State Park and 11 inches at Warm River.  Idaho Highway 27 closed on the 2nd from the US Highway 20 junction to the Montana border.  Idaho Highway 47 closed on the 4th from Ashton to Bear Gulch.  US Highway 20 closed from Ashton to the Montana border on the 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy and wet snow fell in the Eastern Magic Valley and combined with strong winds to cause travel issues.   Idaho Highway 81 was closed from Malta to Declo on the 2nd and Interstate 84 was closed from Interstate 86 to the Utah border as well.   5 miles east of Acequia recorded 8.5 inches of snow and Minidoka Dam recorded 12 inches of snow with the storm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific system brought in extreme moisture with very heavy snow in the Blackfoot Mountains.   The Bone COOP observer recorded 42 inches of snow the first 4 days of the month.   2 to 4 feet were common.   The North Gem School District 149 was closed on the 4th due to the snow and wind conditions and dangerous travel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second, very strong, winter storm impacted Southwestern California. Rainfall totals were very significant across the area. Los Angeles county reported rain totals of 4 to 14 inches, Ventura county reported 2 to 10 inches, Santa Barbara county reported 4 to 12 inches and San Luis Obispo county reported 2 to 5 inches. With the heavy rainfall, numerous reports of flooding were received. In the mountains, very significant snowfall was reported with amounts in the 1 to 3 foot range. Also, severe thunderstorms and tornadoes were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the community of Nipomo, several vehicles were trapped in flood waters near the intersection of Guadalupe Road and Division Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold southwesterly winds shifted westerly during the daytime hours on January 16th, briefly shifting an intense lake effect snow band impacting western New York south into northern Erie County, Pennsylvania. This event was short-lived with snow shifting north and back into New York by early that evening. However, snow rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour occurred for a few hours under the heart of the lake effect band across northern portions of Erie County. The heaviest snow amount reported was 7.2 inches in North East township by a trained spotter. Other selected spotter reports include 6.5 inches in Greene Township, 6.1 inches in the city of Erie and 6 inches in Lake City.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cold southwesterly winds shifted westerly during the daytime hours on January 16th, briefly shifting an intense lake effect snow band impacting western New York south into northern Erie County, Pennsylvania. This event was short-lived with snow shifting north and back into New York by early that evening. However, snow rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour occurred for a few hours under the heart of the lake effect band across northern portions of Erie County. Selected reports from trained spotters include 7 inches in the borough of North East, 6.1 inches in the city of Erie and 6 inches in Lake City. Visibilities below one-quarter of a mile and snow covered roads led to hazardous travel conditions and accidents during the heaviest snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large low pressure tracked out of the Mississippi Valley and into the Great Lakes on January 9th. Strong south to southeast winds occurred ahead of this low pressure on January 9th, causing localized damaging winds mainly along and north of I-90 near Lake Erie.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Shortly before 11:00 AM, winds caused roof damage to a building along East 12th street in Erie, closing the road for several hours. At around the same time, multiple large trees were uprooted near the intersection of Cabot Avenue and Halley Street in Lawrence Park. During the afternoon, a large tree near downtown Erie was uprooted and crushed a parked truck. At 1:48 PM, Erie Airport measured a peak wind gust of 63 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure lifted out of the lower Mississippi Valley and into the Great Lakes January 12th and 13th. Strong southeasterly winds ahead of the low caused damage in northern Erie County during the evening of January 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 7:06 PM, Erie International Airport measured a 69 MPH wind gust. These wind gusts caused downed trees and power-lines across the county with over 3000 customers losing power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Damaging winds along with heavy snow accompanied a major winter storm system that moved through the region. Sierra travel remained treacherous through the weekend, with periods of life-threatening blizzard conditions. IDSS messaging included avoiding travel into the Sierra through this weekend.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public located at Homewood Mountain Ski Base, CA, the Palisades Tahoe Ski Base, Northstar Ski Base , CA, and Tahoe-Donner Ski Base reported storm total snowfall amounts of  88.0 inches, 72.0 inches, 70.0 inches,  and 62 inches respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak clipper moved across the Ohio Valley on January 19th bringing light snow to the region. As the clipper progressed east into the 20th it intensified off the East Coast as cold air poured into the region. The light snow with the clipper on January 19th was enhanced by moisture picked up off of Lake Erie as colder air poured in. Continued cold air advection behind the East Coast low into the 20th and early 21st allowed lake effect snow showers to continue, particularly in the higher elevations in the Snowbelt region of extreme Northeast Ohio. The heaviest snow generally occurred during the daytime hours on January 19th in and around the Cleveland area, though the higher terrain of Geauga and Ashtabula Counties saw another period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers on the 20th. Snow rates reached 1 to 2 inches per hour at times with visibility occasionally falling below a quarter of a mile, especially in bands of heavy lake enhanced snow on the 19th. A trained spotter reported a prolonged storm total of 21.4 inches in Monroe Township in Ashtabula County. Other select reports include spotters reporting 13.1 inches in Garfield in Cuyahoga County, 12.5 inches in Macedonia in Summit County, 9.7 inches in Elyria in Lorain County and 9 inches in Streetsboro in Portage County. Cleveland Hopkins International Airport measured 6.9 inches of snow with this storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak clipper moved across the Ohio Valley on January 19th bringing light snow to the region. As the clipper progressed east into the 20th intensified off the East Coast as cold air poured into the region. The snow with the clipper on January 19th was enhanced by moisture picked up off of Lake Erie as colder air poured in, leading to locally heavier snow. There was a period of steadier and at times heavy snow from the late morning through early evening hours on the 19th when a slow-moving band of lake-enhanced snow drifted across much of northern Summit County. Snow rates reached 1 to 2 inches per hour at times with visibility occasionally falling below a quarter mile within this heavier lake enhanced snow band. This resulted in very poor travel conditions under these lake enhanced bands with numerous accidents reported. A trained spotter reported 12.5 inches of snow in Macedonia. Other spotters reported 8 inches of snow in Hudson and Sagamore Hills, with 6.1 inches in Richfield. Lake effect snow showers re-developed on January 20th and brought light additional accumulations to northern parts of the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 7:06 PM, Erie International Airport measured a 69 MPH wind gust. These wind gusts caused downed trees and power-lines across the county with over 3000 customers losing power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure lifted out of the lower Mississippi Valley and into the Great Lakes January 12th and 13th. Strong southeasterly winds ahead of the low caused damage to parts of northern Ohio during the evening of January 12th, particularly near the Lake Erie shoreline from Cleveland points northeast. Strong westerly winds behind the low caused additional damage to parts of northern Ohio on January 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 7:22 PM Ashtabula County regional airport measured a wind gust of 61 MPH. Conneaut Lighthouse measured a 64 MPH wind gust at 7:48 PM. Trees and power-lines were downed, knocking out power to over 5000 customers in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure lifted out of the lower Mississippi Valley and into the Great Lakes January 12th and 13th. Strong southeasterly winds ahead of the low caused damage to parts of northern Ohio during the evening of January 12th, particularly near the Lake Erie shoreline from Cleveland points northeast. Strong westerly winds behind the low caused additional damage to parts of northern Ohio on January 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 6:39 PM a CWOP weather station measured a 59 MPH wind gust in Wickliffe. Trees and power-lines were downed, knocking out power to over 3000 customers in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure lifted out of the lower Mississippi Valley and into the Great Lakes January 12th and 13th. Strong southeasterly winds ahead of the low caused damage to parts of northern Ohio during the evening of January 12th, particularly near the Lake Erie shoreline from Cleveland points northeast. Strong westerly winds behind the low caused additional damage to parts of northern Ohio on January 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 6:30 PM power-lines were downed in Claridon Township due to strong winds, causing a small brush fire. At around the same time, a large tree fell onto a house in Auburn Township, causing some damage to the homes roof, gutters, and porch. Strong winds knocked down trees and power-lines, causing over 2000 customers to lose power in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure lifted out of the lower Mississippi Valley and into the Great Lakes January 12th and 13th. Strong southeasterly winds ahead of the low caused damage to parts of northern Ohio during the evening of January 12th, particularly near the Lake Erie shoreline from Cleveland points northeast. Strong westerly winds behind the low caused additional damage to parts of northern Ohio on January 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 6:10 PM, Burke Lakefront Airport measured a 59 MPH wind gust. A 61 MPH wind gust was measured by a CWOP station in Parma at 7:20 PM. These wind gusts downed trees and power-lines across the county. On Memphis Avenue in Cleveland, a large tree fell onto a parked car. Several trees were reported downed in Lakewood around 6:45 PM, including on Cranford, Grace, Arthur, Winchester, Maile and Riverside roads. On Grace Road, a large tree fell onto a house, causing significant damage. At around 8:30 PM, a tree was downed onto a car and blocking a street in West Park. Over 6000 customers lost power across the county.

This event was short-lived with snow shifting north and back into New York by early that evening. However, snow rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour occurred for a few hours under the heart of the lake effect band across northern portions of Erie County. The heaviest snow amount reported was 7.2 inches in North East township by a trained spotter. However, snow rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour occurred for a few hours under the heart of the lake effect band across northern portions of Erie County. Selected reports from trained spotters include 7.2 inches in North East township, 6.5 inches in Greenfield Township and 5 inches in Greene Township. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large low pressure system impacted the area late on January 9th and into the 10th with long duration persistent moderate to heavy rainfall. In addition to widespread river flooding, some localized areas of flash flooding occurred as the heaviest rainfall associated with convection moved through. Precipitable water values of 1.2-1.4 inches were record levels for early January. The anomalous moisture and heavy rainfall resulted in a widespread 2 - 4 inches of rainfall, much of it occurring over a several hour timeframe before the cold frontal passage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Block Blvd closed in East Massapequa due to flooding.

As the clipper progressed east into the 20th it intensified off the East Coast as cold air poured into the region. The light snow with the clipper on January 19th was enhanced by moisture picked up off of Lake Erie as colder air poured in. Continued cold air advection behind the East Coast low into the 20th and early 21st allowed lake effect snow showers to continue. There was a period of steadier and at times heavy snow during the afternoon and early evening hours on the 19th. Lake effect snow was heavy at times again overnight through the morning of the 20th before gradually diminishing and ending by the early morning hours on the 21st. Snow rates reached 1 to 2 inches per hour at times with visibility occasionally falling below a quarter of a mile when snow was most intense. A trained spotter reported a prolonged storm total of 21.4 inches in Monroe Township, with another spotter in Pierpont reporting 20.2 inches. Other selected spotter reports include 11.7 inches in Jefferson and 10 inches in Harpersfield Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure lifted out of the lower Mississippi Valley and into the Great Lakes January 12th and 13th. Strong southeasterly winds ahead of the low caused damage to parts of northern Ohio during the evening of January 12th, particularly near the Lake Erie shoreline from Cleveland points northeast. Strong westerly winds behind the low caused additional damage to parts of northern Ohio on January 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 10:00 AM a 61 MPH wind gust was measured in Fairport. These strong winds caused some tree damage and power-outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak clipper moved across the Ohio Valley on January 19th bringing light snow to the region. As the clipper progressed east into the 20th it intensified off the East Coast as cold air poured into the region. The light snow with the clipper on January 19th was enhanced by moisture picked up off of Lake Erie as colder air poured in. Continued cold air advection behind the East Coast low into the 20th and early 21st allowed lake effect snow showers to continue, particularly in the higher elevations in the Snowbelt region of extreme Northeast Ohio. The heaviest snow generally occurred during the daytime hours on January 19th in and around the Cleveland area, though the higher terrain of Geauga and Ashtabula Counties saw another period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers on the 20th. Snow rates reached 1 to 2 inches per hour at times with visibility occasionally falling below a quarter of a mile, especially in bands of heavy lake enhanced snow on the 19th. A trained spotter reported a prolonged storm total of 21.4 inches in Monroe Township in Ashtabula County. Other select reports include spotters reporting 13.1 inches in Garfield in Cuyahoga County, 12.5 inches in Macedonia in Summit County, 9.7 inches in Elyria in Lorain County and 9 inches in Streetsboro in Portage County. Cleveland Hopkins International Airport measured 6.9 inches of snow with this storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak clipper moved across the Ohio Valley on January 19th bringing light snow to the region. As the clipper progressed east into the 20th it intensified off the East Coast as cold air poured into the region. The snow with the clipper on January 19th was enhanced by moisture picked up off of Lake Erie as colder air poured in, leading to locally heavier snow. There was a period of steadier and at times heavy snow from the mid-morning through the early evening hours on the 19th when the lake-enhanced snow was most prevalent. Snow rates reached 1 to 2 inches per hour at times with visibility occasionally falling below a quarter mile with the heavier lake enhanced snow bands. This resulted in very poor travel conditions under these lake enhanced bands with numerous accidents reported. A trained spotter reported 13.1 inches of snow in Garfield Heights. Other selected spotter reports include 13 inches in both Cleveland Heights and Shaker Heights, 10.5 inches in North Royalton, 9.9 inches in Parma and Seven Hills, 9.3 inches in Broadview Heights, 8.3 inches in Strongsville and 8 inches in Westlake. A CoCoRaHS observer measured 8 inches of snow in Lakewood, with 6.9 inches at Cleveland Hopkins Airport. Lake effect snow showers re-developed on January 20th and brought light additional accumulations to parts of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure lifted out of the lower Mississippi Valley and into the Great Lakes January 12th and 13th. Strong southeasterly winds ahead of the low caused damage to parts of northern Ohio during the evening of January 12th, particularly near the Lake Erie shoreline from Cleveland points northeast. Strong westerly winds behind the low caused additional damage to parts of northern Ohio on January 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 7:22 PM Ashtabula County regional airport measured a wind gust of 61 MPH. Trees and power-lines were downed, knocking out power to over 5000 customers in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure lifted out of the lower Mississippi Valley and into the Great Lakes January 12th and 13th. Strong southeasterly winds ahead of the low caused damage to parts of northern Ohio during the evening of January 12th, particularly near the Lake Erie shoreline from Cleveland points northeast. Strong westerly winds behind the low caused additional damage to parts of northern Ohio on January 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 9:05 AM, a CWOP weather station measured a 64 MPH wind gust in Parma. At 9:21 AM, Burke Lakefront Airport measured a 59 MPH wind gust. At 10:03 AM, Cleveland Hopkins International Airport measured a 61 MPH wind gust. These strong winds caused some tree damage and power-outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak clipper moved across the Ohio Valley on January 19th bringing light snow to the region. As the clipper progressed east into the 20th it intensified off the East Coast as cold air poured into the region. Generally light snow with the clipper on January 19th was enhanced by moisture picked up off of Lake Erie as colder air poured in. Continued cold air advection behind the East Coast low into the 20th and early 21st allowed lake effect snow showers to continue, particularly in the higher elevations in southern Erie County and northern Crawford County. There were two periods in which snowfall was steadiest and at times heavy: During the afternoon and early evening hours on January 19th, especially across Erie County, and then from late-evening on the 19th through the evening on the 20th in locally intense lake effect bands, especially across southern Erie County and northern Crawford County. Snow rates reached 1 inch per hour at times with visibility occasionally falling below a quarter of a mile. Wind gusts up to 30 miles per hour led to patchy blowing snow, especially on the 20th. A trained spotter reported a prolonged storm total of 19 inches in Greenfield Township. Other select spotter reports include 16 inches in Edinboro, 15.6 inches in Venango, 13.5 inches in Meadville and 10.5 inches in North East.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak clipper moved across the Ohio Valley on January 19th bringing light snow to the region. As the clipper progressed east into the 20th it intensified off the East Coast as cold air poured into the region. The light snow with the clipper on January 19th was enhanced by moisture picked up off of Lake Erie as colder air poured in. Continued cold air advection behind the East Coast low into the 20th and early 21st allowed lake effect snow showers to continue, though this activity was generally lighter north of I-90 and close to Lake Erie. The snow was steadiest and at times heavy during the afternoon and early evening hours on January 19th. Snow rates reached 1 inch per hour at times with visibility occasionally falling below one-half of a mile. Wind gusts up to 30 miles per hour led to patchy blowing snow, especially on the 20th. A trained spotter reported a prolonged storm total of 10.5 inches in North East, mostly falling on January 19th. Another spotter reported 9.6 inches in Lake City. A CoCoRaHS observer in Erie reported 8.3 inches. Erie International Airport measured 6.7 inches of snow with this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Developing low pressure moved across the Ohio Valley on February 16th, with a large area of generally light to moderate snow evolving north of the system. A narrow band of heavy snow with snow rates of up to 2 inches per hour evolved within the larger area of lighter snow across Central Ohio during the late afternoon and early evening hours, with a narrow corridor of amounts greater than 6 inches observed. A Co-op Observer near Centerburg measured 10 inches of snow with this storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Developing low pressure moved across the Ohio Valley on February 16th, with a large area of generally light to moderate snow evolving north of the system. A narrow band of heavy snow with snow rates of up to 2 inches per hour evolved within the larger area of lighter snow across Central Ohio during the late afternoon and early evening hours, with a narrow corridor of amounts greater than 6 inches observed across the southern one-third of Knox County. A Co-op Observer near Centerburg measured 10 inches of snow with this storm, the highest in the county. Members of the public also reported 8 inches of snow near Knox County airport south of Mount Vernon, with 6 inches measured near Martinsburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick hitting winter storm brought around 12 hours of snow, centered over Connecticut, with the greatest amount of snow in Massachusetts falling on Cape Cod and the islands. This was a notoriously difficult to forecast storm passing south of 40/70 benchmark, which was a significant shift south in the final 24 hours leading up to the storm. This moved the band of heavy snow well south of Boston (0.1) to Cape Cod which received 7-9 inches of snow. The heaviest snow of the storm fell in Hartford County, Connecticut where over 15 inches of snow was reported. The result was many schools and businesses in eastern MA closing and receiving little to no snow. Cape Cod had about 30,000 people lose power due to the heavy, wet nature of the snow. Winds were also strong on the Cape and islands, gusting 45 to 55 mph in the afternoon which reduced visibility in blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Generally 7 to 13 inches of snow fell in Tolland County. Some notable accumulations included 13 inches in Vernon, 12.5 inches in Tolland, and 12 inches in Columbia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper level trough brought several frontal passages which brought several days of blizzard like conditions and widespread heavy snow. Thunderstorms and snow squalls with heavy winds caused power outages in Mountain Home, Idaho. Schools were closed across the Treasure Valley area due to travel difficulties from heavy snow. Highway 20 in the Camas Prairie was closed for several days due to blizzard like conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power outages were reported for nearly 33 customers near Mountain Home due to wind gusts bringing power poles.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at the KBOI airport measured a wind gust to 43 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure tracked through the Ohio River Valley and up through the Great Lakes Region. A strong low level jet enhanced moisture flow into the low pressure system leading to an extended period of moderate rain that caused widespread minor flooding with isolated moderate flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Carpenter Mill Road is closed due to flooding at the intersection with Matthew Mill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On December 28th, an outbreak of severe weather took place. Initially, a few isolated supercells storms developed and produced some tornadoes. As this occurred, a line of storms also developed and eventually pushed eastward across our region. Widespread damaging winds occurred with the line along with numerous tornadoes. This particular convective system was extremely efficient at producing tornadoes. This resulted in a record number of tornadoes for the month of December. The total across our forecast area was 43. The previous December record was 24 back in 2022.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-3 tornado touched down in southern Franklin County near Middleton Creek Road and moved northeast. Broad and sporadic wind damage in the area suggests the tornado was still consolidating in this area. As the tornado crossed Berryton Road, it had reached EF-3 intensity and destroyed the O'Zion Baptist Church there. Most walls were collapsed, but two people took shelter in the bathroom and were unharmed. Documents from the church including bank statements and cancelled checks were found as far away as Brandon, MS to the northeast. Several homes in the area were also damaged including roof damage to a home, and an unanchored mobile home which was rolled once. Both residents of the mobile home were injured, but had sought safety in the bathroom of the home after receiving the Tornado Warning alert on their phones. The tornado continued northeast and damaged tree and power lines along its path. It crossed through the McCall Creek and Lucien areas at US Highway 84 where a modular home lost significant portions of its roof. The tornado collapsed an electrical transmission line tower just west of the Lincoln County line south of Hunsucker Lane. The tornado continued northeast across multiple roads through northwest Lincoln County and damaged trees, power lines, and homes. It dissipated just north of Pleasant Ridge Road. The maximum wind speed was 140 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure tracked through the Ohio River Valley and up through the Great Lakes Region. A strong low level jet enhanced moisture flow into the low pressure system leading to an extended period of moderate rain that caused widespread minor flooding with isolated moderate flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 8800 block of Dyke Road is closed due to flooding near Roach River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A third, powerful, winter storm brought significant impacts to Southwestern California. Rainfall totals ranged between 2 and 12 inches with the highest totals across southern Santa Barbara county and western Ventura county. With the heavy rainfall, numerous reports of flooding and mud/debris flows were reported. Also, some gusty winds were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Swift water rescue teams rescued two people from San Marcos Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front progressed southeastward across the state late evening of the 18th through the early morning hours of the 19th. This brought very cold temperatures to the state. Before the cold air could depart the region, a new storm system approached from the west. While surface temperatures remained at or below freezing, temperatures a few thousand feet above the surface were much warmer. This led to the main form of precipitation being freezing rain which led to slick roads and ice accretion from southern Oklahoma into western and northern Arkansas from the afternoon through late evening hours of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hot Springs Airport received 0.14 inches of freezing rain accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An impressive trough provided strong forcing aloft to support a sub-980mb cyclone that trekked across the Great Lakes 1/9 into 1/10. This system dropped heavy, wet snow with snow-to-liquid ratios near 10:1 -- and even lower during the evening hours of 1/9. While most of northern Michigan saw at least several inches of snow, parts of northern lower saw between 8-12 by the morning of 1/10. Gusty winds of 25-45 mph also lead to blowing and drifting snow across northern Michigan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper level trough brought several frontal passages which brought several days of blizzard like conditions and widespread heavy snow. Thunderstorms and snow squalls with heavy winds caused power outages in Mountain Home, Idaho. Schools were closed across the Treasure Valley area due to travel difficulties from heavy snow. Highway 20 in the Camas Prairie was closed for several days due to blizzard like conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Idaho Transportation Department closed US Highway 20 from milepost 115 to 152 due to whiteout conditions. This also affected the Pine-Featherville road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The COOP Observer at Deadwood Reservoir measured 11.2 inches of snow about 30 miles north of Lowman, ID.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two SNOTELs in the Boise Mountains, the ITD Avalanche Center and Atlanta Summit, measured 19.0 and 16.0 inches of snow respectively in a 48 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough brought a cold front through the region on March 2nd, bringing several consecutive days of snow showers to the region. This brought several days of heavy snowfall to mountains and one day of moderate snowfall to the Treasure Valley. This caused some traffic delays.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public measured 10.0 inches of snow 5 miles northwest of Featherville, ID.  Another member of the public measured 5.0 inches of snow 10 miles east of Boise.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An impressive trough provided strong forcing aloft to support a sub-980mb cyclone that trekked across the Great Lakes 1/9 into 1/10. This system dropped heavy, wet snow with snow-to-liquid ratios near 10:1 -- and even lower during the evening hours of 1/9. While most of northern Michigan saw at least several inches of snow, parts of northern lower saw between 8-12 by the morning of 1/10. Gusty winds of 25-45 mph also lead to blowing and drifting snow across northern Michigan.

A third, powerful, winter storm brought significant impacts to Southwestern California. Rainfall totals ranged between 2 and 12 inches with the highest totals across southern Santa Barbara county and western Ventura county. With the heavy rainfall, numerous reports of flooding and mud/debris flows were reported. Also, some gusty winds were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported on the Refugio Road offramp along Highway 101. Several vehicles were stuck in the flooded roadway.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust was measured at KGLS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong troughing worked across the Mississippi Valley and over the southern Great Lakes 1/12 into 1/13, providing impressive forcing aloft to rapidly deepen a cyclone near 980mb as it worked across the southern half of Michigan and over Lake Huron by the morning of 1/13. This system produced a swath of 7 to 12 inches of snowfall across most of northern lower Michigan away from the Lake Michigan shoreline, with localized totals of 15 inches in West Branch and Hale. Wind gusts exceeding 40 mph across most of the area lead to blowing and drifting snow that resulted in significant travel disruptions.

Storms developed during the afternoon hours over the Flint Hills on Friday, April 26th along an eastward moving dryline. As the storms progressed east they started to produce five tornadoes. Two of the tornadoes were rated an EF-2. One of them struck southwest of Fredonia and the other southwest of Yates Center. Luckily there were no injuries or fatalities with these tornadoes. The other tornadoes were rated EF1, EF0 and EFU. Large hail ranging from quarter size to ping pong ball size was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Parts of metal roofs to outdoor buildings at the fairgrounds sustained damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms developed during the afternoon hours over the Flint Hills on Friday, April 26th along an eastward moving dryline. As the storms progressed east they started to produce five tornadoes. Two of the tornadoes were rated an EF-2. One of them struck southwest of Fredonia and the other southwest of Yates Center. Luckily there were no injuries or fatalities with these tornadoes. The other tornadoes were rated EF1, EF0 and EFU. Large hail ranging from quarter size to ping pong ball size was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was damage to trees, outbuildings and part of about a third of the metal roof on a home. A horse trailer was knocked on its side.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow spread across the region on the 12th. As the snow was ending, northwest winds increased and temperatures dropped below zero on the 13th. There was blowing snow across western and central Minnesota, but the lack of snow on the ground kept travel impacts to a minimum. Overnight wind chills fell to near 40 below across western and central Minnesota the night of the 13th into the 14th.||Based on discussions with other forecasters, emergency managers, and Minnesota Department of Transportation, this would have been a high-impact blizzard if there was a deep snow pack.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted to 36 mph at the Glenwood airport, with blowing snow and reduced visibilities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough brought a cold front through the region on March 2nd, bringing several consecutive days of snow showers to the region. This brought several days of heavy snowfall to mountains and one day of moderate snowfall to the Treasure Valley. This caused some traffic delays.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The CoCoRaHS station one mile north of Boise measured 3.8 inches of snow, while several south of Boise measured 1-2 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough brought a cold front through the region on March 2nd, bringing several consecutive days of snow showers to the region. This brought several days of heavy snowfall to mountains and one day of moderate snowfall to the Treasure Valley. This caused some traffic delays.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public measured 4.5 inches of snow in Gooding, ID on March 4th with the initial snow shower. By March 6th, another member of the public measured 4.7 inches of new snow in Wendell, ID. Another member of the public measured 4.0 inches of new snow in Twin Falls, ID.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds brought travel headaches for high profile vehicles in Malheur County, especially during an evening cold frontal passage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Rome airport measured a gust of 61 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front approached southeast South Carolina in the morning hours and moved across the region through the early evening hours. Ahead of the front, and outside of thunderstorms, a tight pressure gradient and strong low-level jet combined to produce strong and damaging wind gusts. These gusts brought down numerous trees and produced damage across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Colleton County Emergency Management reported a tree down blocking both lanes of a road west of Walterboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southwesterly impacted Southwestern California. Across the mountains and deserts, wind gusts of 60 to 70 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong southwesterly winds impacted the  Eastern San Gabriel Mountains. Some peak gusts include: Ford Observatory (gust 71 MPH) and Big Pines (gust 64 MPH).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southwesterly impacted Southwestern California. Across the mountains and deserts, wind gusts of 60 to 70 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong southwesterly winds impacted the mountains of San Luis Obispo county. The sensor at Mount Lowe reported gusts up to 58 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late-season, storm brought significant rainfall to the area along with strong thunderstorms. Rainfall totals across the area ranged from 0.50 to 1.50 inches across San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties to 1 to 2 inches across Ventura and Los Angeles counties. Unstable air, associated with the storm, brought scattered strong thunderstorms to the area, producing gusty winds, large hail and even some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall in the Monrovia area, generated debris flows in the area around the Fish Fire burn scar. Per local emergency managers, the debris catch basins were over halfway full after the debris flow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second, late season, storm rolled across Southwestern California. This storm brought strong north to northeast winds as well as strong thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds  and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north to northeast winds were observed across the eastern range of the Santa Ynez Mountains. The RAWS sensor at Montecito reported peak gusts of 69 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms developed during the afternoon hours over the Flint Hills on Friday, April 26th along an eastward moving dryline. As the storms progressed east they started to produce five tornadoes. Two of the tornadoes were rated an EF-2. One of them struck southwest of Fredonia and the other southwest of Yates Center. Luckily there were no injuries or fatalities with these tornadoes. The other tornadoes were rated EF1, EF0 and EFU. Large hail ranging from quarter size to ping pong ball size was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officer sent in pictures of tree damage that occurred in eastern Elk County.

A quick-moving cold front came through California on January 31, bringing widespread rain and high winds. A narrow cold frontal rainband (NCFR) developed during the afternoon and evening commute, with moderate to heavy rain across the region as a result. Impacts and post-frontal showers continued through February 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One foot of water was over the ramp at the intersection of San Jose Avenue and Monterey Boulevard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of frontal systems with a weak subtropical tap led to widespread rainfall and nuisance flooding across the Bay Area and Central Coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Standing water was reported on Southbound Interstate 280 just south of the John Daly Tunnel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong troughing worked across the Mississippi Valley and over the southern Great Lakes 1/12 into 1/13, providing impressive forcing aloft to rapidly deepen a cyclone near 980mb as it worked across the southern half of Michigan and over Lake Huron by the morning of 1/13. This system produced a swath of 7 to 12 inches of snowfall across most of northern lower Michigan away from the Lake Michigan shoreline, with localized totals of 15 inches in West Branch and Hale. Wind gusts exceeding 40 mph across most of the area lead to blowing and drifting snow that resulted in significant travel disruptions.

Very strong troughing worked across the Mississippi Valley and over the southern Great Lakes 1/12 into 1/13, providing impressive forcing aloft to rapidly deepen a cyclone near 980mb as it worked across the southern half of Michigan and over Lake Huron by the morning of 1/13. This system produced a swath of 7 to 12 inches of snowfall across most of northern lower Michigan away from the Lake Michigan shoreline, with localized totals of 15 inches in West Branch and Hale. Wind gusts exceeding 40 mph across most of the area lead to blowing and drifting snow that resulted in significant travel disruptions.

With the influence of a mid-level trough to the north, a surface low pressure system moving across the Southeast U.S. pulled a warm front across South Florida on the morning of January 6th. This brought plenty of warm air and diurnal instability to the area ahead of a cold front, which was the source of lift to spark several showers and thunderstorms in the afternoon and evening. Some thunderstorms became severe, producing a funnel cloud and two tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High-resolution satellite imagery showed a tornado damage path through a field near Browns Farm Road southeast of Belle Glade after a severe thunderstorm moved through the area. Time, path width, and path length are estimated based on radar and satellite imagery. Due to an inability to survey the area, maximum wind speeds and EF rating are unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon hours of April 26th, supercells produced 4 brief EF-0 tornadoes in Bates and Henry Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ping pong ball sized hail was reported in Hume.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon hours of April 18th, Henry and Pettis County received severe hail and wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed power lines and outages reported near 1601 Road northwest of Montrose.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon hours of April 18th, Henry and Pettis County received severe hail and wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail reported in downtown Clinton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Blizzard brought widespread heavy Blowing and Drifting snow, zero visibility, as well as winds commonly around 60 mph beginning in the late morning hours of January 8th and winding down toward midnight. The heavy accumulations and drifting caused many stranded vehicles on area highways.||Blizzard warning criteria was met by around 12 to 1 pm as several southwest Kansas reached the 3 hours criteria of one quarter mile visibility in snow and blowing snow, with wind gusts commonly reaching 55 to 62 mph. The snow band then rotated to the east through the afternoon, with quarter mile or less visibility, and heavy drifting of snow which resulted in the widespread closure of highways in the blizzard warned area.||Numerous wind gusts well in excess of high wind warning criteria were observed by METARS.  Wind gusts to 67 mph were recorded at non asos/awos sites in Morton and Finney counties, and one 70 mph gusts was reported by the similar network in Seward county near Hayne. Snowfall totals, which many were called in on the 9th, averaged from 4 to 9 inches across the major area, and as much as 14.2 inches measured by a cooperative observer near Scott City.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three hours of blizzard conditions characterized by less than one quarter mile visibility in winds of 37 mph sustained and gusting to 54 mph, in heavy snow and blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of frontal systems with a weak subtropical tap led to widespread rainfall and nuisance flooding across the Bay Area and Central Coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A man drove off a slick Highway 101 North in Novato just after 5 PM on January 20, and wrapped his car around the traffic light on the frontage road, north of Hamilton Parkway, outside Safeway. According to the California Highway Patrol, speed and wet roadway were factors. The Novato Fire Department extracted the man from the wreckage and paramedics tried, unsuccessfully, to perform CPR. The man was taken to a hospital, where he died of his injuries. The car was totaled and a fence and light pole were damaged. Report courtesy KTVU television (FOX San Francisco-Oakland).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated storm produced hail in east-central Louisiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel to quarter size hail fell in Larto.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following a robust storm system the preceding day, strong gradient winds and dry air contributed to damaging winds with some fire weather concern during the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large oak tree was blown down and crushed the midsection of a school bus. Only the driver was onboard, and no injuries occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms in northeastern Louisiana produced wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down near Hughes Chapel Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon and evening hours of April 27th, severe storms impacted northeast and eastern Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low surface pressure developed over the Panhandles of Texas and Oklahoma on the 4th and 5th of January, lifting moist air northward into colder air at the surface over western Kansas. Snow developed on the overnight of the 4th into the 5th, with many first measured reports coming in around 7 am. Snowfall amounts of 3 to 5 inches were common before the snow tapered off during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow of 2.7 inches was measured 3 northwest of Dodge City.
