EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure pushed northeast from the Tennessee Valley and moved along and off the coast. An accumulating snow took place across portions of Fairfield County, with far northern sections towards the Litchfield border receiving heavy snow in the vicinity of New Fairfield. Further south and east where the snow mixed with, and even changed to rain amounts were much lower.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts varied greatly across Northern Fairfield with Trained spotters reporting 8.5 inches in New Fairfield, 8.0 inches at 4 SSE Sherman, and 4.4 inches at Danbury. However, amounts were noticeably lower going south with Redding reporting 4.0 inches, Stamford reporting 3.5 inches, Norwalk reporting 3.0 inches, and a Cocorahs report of 2.6 inches in Brookfield. Well more than half the zone reported snow that fell short of warning criteria with some amounts on the order of 1 to 3 inches along the immediate sound shore with Bridgeport NWS observation of 3 .0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of frontal systems with a weak subtropical tap led to widespread rainfall and nuisance flooding across the Bay Area and Central Coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cypress Point Apartments at Felix Street in Santa Cruz flooded as a result of Neary Lagoon overflowing. Eight units were reported flooded, with five of those being occupied at the time. Report courtesy KION-TV Monterey-Salinas and KPIX-TV San Francisco.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong troughing worked across the Mississippi Valley and over the southern Great Lakes 1/12 into 1/13, providing impressive forcing aloft to rapidly deepen a cyclone near 980mb as it worked across the southern half of Michigan and over Lake Huron by the morning of 1/13. This system produced a swath of 7 to 12 inches of snowfall across most of northern lower Michigan away from the Lake Michigan shoreline, with localized totals of 15 inches in West Branch and Hale. Wind gusts exceeding 40 mph across most of the area lead to blowing and drifting snow that resulted in significant travel disruptions.

As a strong storm system worked away from the Great Lakes, west-northwest winds spread across the region and generated lake effect snow across most of northwest lower and eastern upper Michigan. Cold air over the unusually warm Great Lakes waters supported robust lake effect snow bands across parts of the area, dropping over a foot of snow and resulting in rapid drops in visibility to 1/4 mile or less at times.

Storms developed during the afternoon hours over the Flint Hills on Friday, April 26th along an eastward moving dryline. As the storms progressed east they started to produce five tornadoes. Two of the tornadoes were rated an EF-2. One of them struck southwest of Fredonia and the other southwest of Yates Center. Luckily there were no injuries or fatalities with these tornadoes. The other tornadoes were rated EF1, EF0 and EFU. Large hail ranging from quarter size to ping pong ball size was reported.

Upper-level disturbances moving through moist southwest flow aloft brought showers and thunderstorms to eastern Arkansas during the evening hours of January 23rd. A warm front pushed north creating areas of dense fog over eastern Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to two inches of rain fell across Poinsett County.  Patchy dense fog was also reported.

Several rounds of heavy rain across southeast Arkansas produced flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Streets in town were flooded, and floodwaters approached or entered several of the businesses along US Highway 65.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving cold front came through California on January 31, bringing widespread rain and high winds. A narrow cold frontal rainband (NCFR) developed during the afternoon and evening commute, with moderate to heavy rain across the region as a result. Impacts and post-frontal showers continued through February 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Standing water was reported in the slow lane on California Route 221 at California Route 29.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A father and son were pulled from the ocean near Pacifica on January 14. At 12:52 PM, two fire companies, a rescue unit, a CHP helicopter, state park personnel and Coast Guard air and water units responded to the two people struggling in the water north of Mori Point. Rescue swimmers pulled the two people from the water and took them to ambulances, which transported them to San Francisco General Hospital. At the time of the rescue, the San Francisco buoy (46026) reported waves of 2.7 meters (9 feet) at 15 seconds, with a water temperature of 12.5 degrees Celsius (54.5 degrees Fahrenheit).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A father and son were pulled from the ocean near Pacifica on January 14. At 12:52 PM, two fire companies, a rescue unit, a CHP helicopter, state park personnel and Coast Guard air and water units responded to the two people struggling in the water north of Mori Point. Rescue swimmers pulled the two people from the water and took them to ambulances, which transported them to San Francisco General Hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong troughing worked across the Mississippi Valley and over the southern Great Lakes 1/12 into 1/13, providing impressive forcing aloft to rapidly deepen a cyclone near 980mb as it worked across the southern half of Michigan and over Lake Huron by the morning of 1/13. This system produced a swath of 7 to 12 inches of snowfall across most of northern lower Michigan away from the Lake Michigan shoreline, with localized totals of 15 inches in West Branch and Hale. Wind gusts exceeding 40 mph across most of the area lead to blowing and drifting snow that resulted in significant travel disruptions.

Low pressure pushed northeast from the Tennessee Valley and moved along and off the coast. An accumulating snow took place across portions of the Lower Hudson Valley of Interior Southeastern New York. Orange and Putnam counties reached Winter Storm Criteria, while locations further south did not as snow totals dropped quickly southeast of Orange and Putnam counties as only advisory criteria was reached across portions of Westchester and Rockland counties where the snow mixed with, and even changed to rain in places.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals varied across Orange County from west to east.  Cocorahs observers reported of 13.1 inches in Port Jervis and 10.3 inches in Warwick. A trained spotter reported 11.7 inches in Walden.  The public reporte 10.2 inches in Newburgh, 10.2 inches in Pine Bush, and 9.5 inches in Florida. A trained spotter reported 9.2 inches in Salisbury Mills.||Snowfall totals averaged over 6.0 inches across the county, although amounts varied greatly with some western locations generally receiving less being on the outer edge of the precipitation shield when colder air arrived. Trained spotters reported 15.5 inches at 1 WNW Monroe and 6.1 inches at Salisbury Mills. Public reports included 9.4 inches in Chester and 6.5 inches at 2 SW Greenwood Lake. Cocorahs reports included 8.5 inches in Port Jervis, but only 2.2 inches in Walden.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small plane with four people onboard crashed near Moss Beach in San Mateo County, around 1 mile southwest of Half Moon Bay Airport, on January 14 at 7:34 PM. Witnesses saw the plane sputtering before the crash. Wreckage from the plane was found near Ross Cove. Search efforts for survivors continued until 11 AM the next day. The San Mateo County Sheriff's Office stated that a commercial fishing boat discovered a woman's body in the water. The body was later identified to be connected to the crash.||At the time of the accident, Half Moon Bay Airport reported scattered low ceilings and misty skies. The last observation before the incident reported scattered clouds at 300 feet and visibilities at 6 miles. Separate observations from the previous two hours reported broken clouds at 300 feet and visibilities of 2.5 miles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small plane with four people onboard crashed near Moss Beach in San Mateo County, around 1 mile southwest of Half Moon Bay Airport, on January 14 at 7:34 PM. Witnesses saw the plane sputtering before the crash. Wreckage from the plane was found near Ross Cove. Search efforts for survivors continued until 11 AM the next day. The San Mateo County Sheriff's Office stated that a commercial fishing boat discovered a woman's body in the water. The body was later identified to be connected to the crash.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure pushed northeast from the Tennessee Valley and moved along and off the coast. An accumulating snow took place across portions of Fairfield County, with far northern sections towards the Litchfield border receiving heavy snow in the vicinity of New Fairfield. Further south and east where the snow mixed with, and even changed to rain amounts were much lower.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An accumulating snow fell across Northern New Haven County with 5 inch totals reported at 1 N Cheshire and Middlebury by the public, and 4.6 inches in Waterbury and 4.0 inches in Hamden from Cocorahs. Amounts further south ranged from under an inch along the Sound shore, to most 1 to 3 inches across the southern part of Northern New Haven County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure pushed northeast from the Tennessee Valley and moved along and off the coast. An accumulating snow took place across portions of the Lower Hudson Valley of Interior Southeastern New York. Orange and Putnam counties reached Winter Storm Criteria, while locations further south did not as snow totals dropped quickly southeast of Orange and Putnam counties as only advisory criteria was reached across portions of Westchester and Rockland counties where the snow mixed with, and even changed to rain in places.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An accumulating snow occurred across Rockland County before a mix and changeover to a wintery mix and rain. Amounts averaged between 3 and 4 inches across much of the zone and fell short of warning criteria. Cocorahs reported 4.1 inches at 1.7 SSW Spring Valley, 4.0 inches in Stony Point, and 3.6 inches at 0.6 SE New Hempstead. A Trained spotter reported 3.0 inches in New City. The public reported 3.0 inches at 2 W Buchanan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An accumulating snow took place across northern portions of Middlesex County, with a mix and change to rain. Trained spotters reported 6.5 inches in Cromwell and 3.9 inches at 3 WNW Cromwell.  Cocorahs reported 3.2 inches in Durham, 3.0 inches in Middlefield, and 1.9 inches in Higganum. Amounts decreased sharply from here going south and southeast. Amounts averaged well below warning criteria across Northern Middlesex County.

An exterior wall in the garage was|bowed out; however, a lower wind speed was assigned due to the|failure mode being the garage door and absolute lack of any other|damage surrounding the house. The tornado then crossed northwest|across Brighton Dr and dissipated near Brandy Ct while snapping some|large hardwood branches and a fence blown inward resulting in a |convergent path.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds downed trees on Barton-Agricola Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Photos relayed on social media of roof damage to a home off Georgetown Chunchula Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe line of thunderstorms moved across the Gulf Coast during the day. This line of storms produced large and damaging winds along with a couple of tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bayou La Batre Police Department reported that Shell Belt road is impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved across Santa Rosa County producing damaging wind gusts near Navarre.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power line blown down in Holley. Verified by Holley-Navarre Fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved across Santa Rosa County producing damaging wind gusts near Navarre.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Steel gazebo was lifted into the air and damaged the gutter/and part of the roof of a home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving cold front came through California on January 31, bringing widespread rain and high winds. A narrow cold frontal rainband (NCFR) developed during the afternoon and evening commute, with moderate to heavy rain across the region as a result. Impacts and post-frontal showers continued through February 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported on southbound Interstate 280 north of California Highway 87 and on the ramp to Highway 87.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving cold front came through California on January 31, bringing widespread rain and high winds. A narrow cold frontal rainband (NCFR) developed during the afternoon and evening commute, with moderate to heavy rain across the region as a result. Impacts and post-frontal showers continued through February 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three feet of water was reported at the intersection between Old Stage Road and Zabala Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low surface pressure developed over the Panhandles of Texas and Oklahoma on the 4th and 5th of January, lifting moist air northward into colder air at the surface over western Kansas. Snow developed on the overnight of the 4th into the 5th, with many first measured reports coming in around 7 am. Snowfall amounts of 3 to 5 inches were common before the snow tapered off during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inches of snow (4.0) was measured at Bucklin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low surface pressure developed over the Panhandles of Texas and Oklahoma on the 4th and 5th of January, lifting moist air northward into colder air at the surface over western Kansas. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Blizzard brought widespread heavy Blowing and Drifting snow, zero visibility, as well as winds commonly around 60 mph beginning in the late morning hours of January 8th and winding down toward midnight. The heavy accumulations and drifting caused many stranded vehicles on area highways.||Blizzard warning criteria was met by around 12 to 1 pm as several southwest Kansas reached the 3 hours criteria of one quarter mile visibility in snow and blowing snow, with wind gusts commonly reaching 55 to 62 mph. The snow band then rotated to the east through the afternoon, with quarter mile or less visibility, and heavy drifting of snow which resulted in the widespread closure of highways in the blizzard warned area.||Numerous wind gusts well in excess of high wind warning criteria were observed by METARS.  Wind gusts to 67 mph were recorded at non asos/awos sites in Morton and Finney counties, and one 70 mph gusts was reported by the similar network in Seward county near Hayne. Snowfall totals, which many were called in on the 9th, averaged from 4 to 9 inches across the major area, and as much as 14.2 inches measured by a cooperative observer near Scott City.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three hours of Visibility less than one quarter mile in heavy snow and blowing snow, with winds sustained at least 36 mph and gusts to 46 mph. The ASOS observation was lost on the 3rd hour. Observed at Dodge City (KDDC).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced wind damage and hail across parts of Mississippi.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several power poles were blown down in the Midnight and Silver City areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rain across southeast Arkansas produced flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A quick burst of heavy rainfall caused flooding along a creek where it passed under Ashley 12 Road near the intersection with Ashley 283 Road. Video from the area showed two to three feet of water rushing over the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A father and son were pulled from the ocean near Pacifica on January 14. At 12:52 PM, two fire companies, a rescue unit, a CHP helicopter, state park personnel and Coast Guard air and water units responded to the two people struggling in the water north of Mori Point. Rescue swimmers pulled the two people from the water and took them to ambulances, which transported them to San Francisco General Hospital. At the time of the rescue, the San Francisco buoy (46026) reported waves of 2.7 meters (9 feet) at 15 seconds, with a water temperature of 12.5 degrees Celsius (54.5 degrees Fahrenheit).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A dog and its owner were swept out to sea at Sharp Point near Pacifica. The dog was swept out and the owner went in after the dog. The dog made it back to shore, but the owner struggled to return. Video taken at the scene showed rescue swimmers assisting the man onto shore, and the owner was taken to the hospital as a precautionary measure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong troughing worked across the Mississippi Valley and over the southern Great Lakes 1/12 into 1/13, providing impressive forcing aloft to rapidly deepen a cyclone near 980mb as it worked across the southern half of Michigan and over Lake Huron by the morning of 1/13. This system produced a swath of 7 to 12 inches of snowfall across most of northern lower Michigan away from the Lake Michigan shoreline, with localized totals of 15 inches in West Branch and Hale. Wind gusts exceeding 40 mph across most of the area lead to blowing and drifting snow that resulted in significant travel disruptions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three hours of reduced visibility in heavy snow and blowing snow, with sustained winds as high as 38 mph and gusts to 44 mph. Observed at Liberal (KLBL).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of frontal systems with a weak subtropical tap led to widespread rainfall and nuisance flooding across the Bay Area and Central Coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported at SB 160 over Main Street. Lane 1 was partially flooded with 2 inches of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure pushed northeast from the Tennessee Valley and moved along and off the coast. An accumulating snow took place across portions of the Lower Hudson Valley of Interior Southeastern New York. Orange and Putnam counties reached Winter Storm Criteria, while locations further south did not as snow totals dropped quickly southeast of Orange and Putnam counties as only advisory criteria was reached across portions of Westchester and Rockland counties where the snow mixed with, and even changed to rain in places.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An accumulating snow took place across Northern Westchester. Amounts ranged mostly between 3 and 5 inches. Trained spotters reported 4.6 inches in Peekskill, and 4.0 inches at 1 SE Croton-on-Hudson. Cocorahs reported 4.0 inches in Shrub Oak. Amounts were less going south and east with a quicker mix and changeover to rain. Amounts fell short of warning criteria.

CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving cold front came through California on January 31, bringing widespread rain and high winds. A narrow cold frontal rainband (NCFR) developed during the afternoon and evening commute, with moderate to heavy rain across the region as a result. Impacts and post-frontal showers continued through February 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell onto a house, vehicle, and power lines in Saratoga, trapping one person inside the vehicle, who was taken to a hospital with non-life threatening injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A robust upper trough that dug across the interior West Saturday and Sunday, |aligned with the left exit region of a meridional jet favoring large scale ascent across the Sierra and western Nevada. This setup for strong winds and widespread precipitation across the region. This included the potential for heavy Sierra snowfall with light snow accumulation on valley floors. As the first snow arrived Saturday morning wind observations over Sierra ridges showed gusts ranging 70-80 mph. This system was considered the coldest and most impactful storm up to this point this season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter located 5.0 mi WNW of Susanville, CA, reported a 24 hour storm total snowfall amount of 7.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon and evening hours of April 27, severe storms impacted much of the WFO Kansas City county warning area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS Storm Survey confirmed a relatively long-track QLCS EF-1 tornado. This EF1 tornado began just south of Route 18 east of Passaic. Some of the worst damage of the tornado affected a farm property, where one outbuilding collapsed, another had a garage door blown off, and multiple trees were damaged or uprooted. Large debris from the damaged property was blown well northeast, in some cases over 100 yards. The tornado tracked northeast, damaging a grove of trees to the south of SH 18 and producing minor damage to an outbuilding and mobile home on the north side of the highway. The tornado then tracked northeast to Route T, producing sporadic tree damage and some minor property damage. The damage track continues east-northeast along County Road 13004, with continued sporadic tree damage. One of the larger trees fell onto a residence, damaging the property as well as to power lines. Intermittent tree damage continues northeast to Route BB and County Road 13003, with more significant tree damage eastward along Sunset Drive just west of the Henry County line. Damage becomes more intermittent eastward into Henry County, with no damage observed a half mile past the county line. However, much of this area north of 400 Road in Henry County is inaccessible, so it is possible the tornado continued a short distance longer to the north or northeast of the end of the track.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flash flooding in the vicinity of Dermott, Arkansas during the morning of April 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flash flooding in the vicinity of Dermott, Arkansas during the morning of April 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple streets were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a strong storm system worked away from the Great Lakes, west-northwest winds spread across the region and generated lake effect snow across most of northwest lower and eastern upper Michigan. Cold air over the unusually warm Great Lakes waters supported robust lake effect snow bands across parts of the area, dropping over a foot of snow and resulting in rapid drops in visibility to 1/4 mile or less at times.

As a strong storm system worked away from the Great Lakes, west-northwest winds spread across the region and generated lake effect snow across most of northwest lower and eastern upper Michigan. Cold air over the unusually warm Great Lakes waters supported robust lake effect snow bands across parts of the area, dropping over a foot of snow and resulting in rapid drops in visibility to 1/4 mile or less at times.

A stronger and colder more classic winter storm followed Wednesday through|early Thursday, bringing additional wind and snow impacts to the Sierra and western NV. This storm systems trajectory allowed it to drop southward into eastern California and western Nevada Wednesday-Wednesday night. This storm started with a short round of strong winds followed by bursts of heavier snow. Although this storm appeared to have a more overland trajectory with liquid precipitation totals a little lower, the forcing from this low and attendant cold front remained sufficiently intact to produce additional snow with at least an even chance of 6 or more inches in the Tahoe basin southward to western Mono County, and an additional foot or more along the Sierra crest. Plenty of winter travel hazards at all elevations continued into the Thursday AM commute.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public located at Heavenly Ski Base, CA, the Palisades Tahoe Ski Base, CA, and the Northstar Ski Base, CA, reported 24 hour storm total snowfall amounts of 21.0 inches, 14.0 inches and 9.0 inches respectively.

A strong storm moved up the east coast passing near the 70/40 benchmark brought heavy snow to southern New England beginning late Monday night and continuing on Sunday. The first round of heavy snow fell overnight followed by a lull in the snow and mixing with rain Sunday morning. Comma head snow then filled back into eastern MA and RI bringing moderate to heavy snow Sunday afternoon and evening. Snow amounts ranged from 2 to 18 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Generally 8 to 15 inches of snow fell. Some higher amounts included 15 inches in Montague and 10.2 inches in New Salem.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary draped across northern NY and northern VT in a marginally unstable airmass led to the development of scattered thunderstorms during the afternoon of May 21st. A few of these thunderstorms intensified to deliver isolated damaging winds and hail up to one inch in diameter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree and wires down along Route 207 between Cook road and Woods Hill road  intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stronger and colder more classic winter storm followed Wednesday through|early Thursday, bringing additional wind and snow impacts to the Sierra and western NV. This storm systems trajectory allowed it to drop southward into eastern California and western Nevada Wednesday-Wednesday night. This storm started with a short round of strong winds followed by bursts of heavier snow. Although this storm appeared to have a more overland trajectory with liquid precipitation totals a little lower, the forcing from this low and attendant cold front remained sufficiently intact to produce additional snow with at least an even chance of 6 or more inches in the Tahoe basin southward to western Mono County, and an additional foot or more along the Sierra crest. Plenty of winter travel hazards at all elevations continued into the Thursday AM commute.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station (XMPC1-Mean Peak) located 6.0 mi NNE of Leavitt Meadows, CA, and mesonet station (MTH01-MAMMOTH) located 0.9 mi S of Mammoth Mountain, CA,  reported a peak wind gusts of 83 mph, and 129 mph respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved from the southeast United States on March 22nd up the eastern seaboard to the NJ/DE coast by midday on March 24th and offshore by Cape Cod late at night on March 24th. ||Snow overspread Vermont, south to north, during the early morning hours of March 23rd and then exiting from west to east during the evening hours of March 23rd. The higher snowfall accumulations were across south central and southern VT, except along the MA/VT border where some mixed precipitation types occurred.||Snowfall totals ranged from 3 to 6 inches in northwest VT, 6 to 12 inches across the rest of the Champlain Valley and northern VT, 12 to 18 inches in central VT with 18 to 24+ inches across south central VT with these higher totals mainly across Windsor and eastern Rutland counties.||Impacts were largely travel related.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals were generally 4 to 6 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This storm was allowed to tap into Pacific moisture for a longer period of time that nudged it just enough north to make a more direct landfall into the central OR coast.  This next storm Friday evening into Saturday brought more gusty winds, Sierra snow, and valley rain/snow showers. This storms warmer nature raised snow levels a bit higher(5500-6500 feet) with the potential for mixed precipitation in the valley areas and foothills. The lower-end ensemble snow scenarios showed a bit more confident projection for at least a foot of snow in the Sierra with potential for 18-24 inches along the Sierra crest. Regardless, this contributed to another bout of travel disruptions, especially for ski commutes during the upcoming holiday weekend. Wind speeds have trended up a bit with this storm as well with the potential for wind gusts 40 to 50 mph for the valley areas. Sierra ridge wind gusts got a boost with potential for gusts 90+ mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter(WA-12) located 1.0 mi NNW of Incline Village, and the public located at the Mount Rose Ski Base reported 24 hour storm snowfall totals of 4.5 inches and 4.0 inches respectively.

As the first snow arrived Saturday morning wind observations over Sierra ridges showed gusts ranging 70-80 mph. This system was considered the coldest and most impactful storm up to this point this season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station (HVRGM Mid Station Gondola) located 1.0 mi ENE of the Heavenly Ski Summit, CA, reported a peak wind gust of 79 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the Great Lakes produced moderate snow over mainly northern portions of Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 3 and 5 inches of snow fell across Keweenaw County over 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper disturbances moving across a cold and unstable air mass generated moderate to locally heavy lake effect snow across the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 27th into the morning of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snowfall totals over 72 hours included 15.4 inches at two miles south of Baraga, 14.5 inches at Herman, 14.3 inches at 7 miles northwest of Baraga and 12 inches nearly 18 miles southeast of L'Anse.

The first round of heavy snow fell overnight followed by a lull in the snow and mixing with rain Sunday morning. Comma head snow then filled back into eastern MA and RI bringing moderate to heavy snow Sunday afternoon and evening. Snow amounts ranged from 2 to 18 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Generally 9 to 17.5 inches of snow fell. Some accumulations included 17.5 inches in Ashburnham, 17.4 inches in Leominster, and 16.5 inches in Fitchburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stronger and colder more classic winter storm followed Wednesday through|early Thursday, bringing additional wind and snow impacts to the Sierra and western NV. This storm systems trajectory allowed it to drop southward into eastern California and western Nevada Wednesday-Wednesday night. This storm started with a short round of strong winds followed by bursts of heavier snow. Although this storm appeared to have a more overland trajectory with liquid precipitation totals a little lower, the forcing from this low and attendant cold front remained sufficiently intact to produce additional snow with at least an even chance of 6 or more inches in the Tahoe basin southward to western Mono County, and an additional foot or more along the Sierra crest. Plenty of winter travel hazards at all elevations continued into the Thursday AM commute.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station located at the Alpine Meadows summit, CA, and mesonet station located at Palisades Tahoe summit, CA,  reported peak wind gusts of 110 mph, and 94 mph respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A robust upper trough that dug across the interior West Saturday and Sunday, |aligned with the left exit region of a meridional jet favoring large scale ascent across the Sierra and western Nevada. This setup for strong winds and widespread precipitation across the region. This included the potential for heavy Sierra snowfall with light snow accumulation on valley floors. As the first snow arrived Saturday morning wind observations over Sierra ridges showed gusts ranging 70-80 mph. This system was considered the coldest and most impactful storm up to this point this season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public located at Mammoth Mountain Ski main lodge reported storm total snowfall of 9.0 inches at the main lodge, and 11.0 inches at the summit height.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper disturbances moving across a cold and unstable air mass generated moderate to locally heavy lake effect snow across the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 27th into the morning of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nature's Kennel 7 miles north of McMillan measured 27.5 inches of lake effect snow over 72 hours.  Occasional power outages were reported from the heavy snowfall from McMillan and Newberry to Pine Stump Junction.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper disturbances moving across a cold and unstable air mass generated moderate to locally heavy lake effect snow across the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 27th into the morning of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow totals over 72 hours included 27 inches 7 miles north-northeast of Ironwood, 15 inches at Bessemer, 14 inches 5 miles north of Ironwood and 9-11 inches within the city of Ironwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary draped across northern NY and northern VT in a marginally unstable airmass led to the development of scattered thunderstorms during the afternoon of May 21st. A few of these thunderstorms intensified to deliver isolated damaging winds and hail up to one inch in diameter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail reported by spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary draped across northern NY and northern VT in a marginally unstable airmass led to the development of scattered thunderstorms during the afternoon of May 21st. A few of these thunderstorms intensified to deliver isolated damaging winds and hail up to one inch in diameter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: West Enosburg road closed due to multiple trees down with poles and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slider-type shortwave and attendant moisture were forecast to bring a modest |with Sierra snowfall staying on the lighter side compared to previous February winter storms. Snowfall totals along the Sierra crest were expected to vary from 3-6 inches with lower elevation Sierra communities (Truckee, South Lake Tahoe, Bridgeport, Mammoth Lakes) seeing only 1-3 inches through Thursday morning. There was a 10% chance for these locales seeing up to 6 inches of snow in a boom scenario. Bands of moderate snowfall with this winter system in fact did bring a modest Boom storm total snowfall to some areas south of US-50 to include the Eastern Sierra, Mono County, southern Lyon County, and Mineral County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station (SLIDE-DRI) located 0.9 mi E of Mount Rose Summit  reported a peak wind gust of 78 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow developed in the late morning hours of March 25th over west central Kansas and expanded west through the late afternoon. The snow tapered off in the mid evening after leaving anywhere from 1 to 3 inches of new fallen snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three inches of snow was measured 4 ENE Ulysses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorm associated with a surface trough produced damaging winds across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree was downed near the intersection of River Road and Williamsville Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm moved up the east coast passing near the 70/40 benchmark brought heavy snow to southern New England beginning late Monday night and continuing on Sunday. The first round of heavy snow fell overnight followed by a lull in the snow and mixing with rain Sunday morning. Comma head snow then filled back into eastern MA and RI bringing moderate to heavy snow Sunday afternoon and evening. Snow amounts ranged from 2 to 18 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Generally 7 to 15 inches of snow fell. Some accumulations included 15.5 inches at the Worcester Airport, 14.6 inches in Westborough, and 13.2 inches in Charlton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a brief period of otherwise quieter and dry conditions, a weaker appetizer storm pushed through the region February 16, that brought more wind than either rain or snow to the region. Periods of travel difficulties, however, were still expected for Sierra passes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station  (NEMNV-NV DOT) located 4.0 mi SSE of Dayton, NV, and mesonet station (STGNV-NV DOT.) located 3.0 mi ENE of Stagecoach, NV, reported peak wind gusts of 64 mph and 62 mph respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stronger and colder more classic winter storm followed Wednesday through|early Thursday, bringing additional wind and snow impacts to the Sierra and western NV. Although this storm appeared to have a more overland trajectory with liquid precipitation totals a little lower, the forcing from this low and attendant cold front remained sufficiently intact to produce additional snow with at least an even chance of 6 or more inches in the Tahoe basin southward to western Mono County, and an additional foot or more along the Sierra crest. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This storm was allowed to tap into Pacific moisture for a longer period of time that nudged it just enough north to make a more direct landfall into the central OR coast.  This next storm Friday evening into Saturday brought more gusty winds, Sierra snow, and valley rain/snow showers. This storms warmer nature raised snow levels a bit higher(5500-6500 feet) with the potential for mixed precipitation in the valley areas and foothills. The lower-end ensemble snow scenarios showed a bit more confident projection for at least a foot of snow in the Sierra with potential for 18-24 inches along the Sierra crest. Regardless, this contributed to another bout of travel disruptions, especially for ski commutes during the upcoming holiday weekend. Wind speeds have trended up a bit with this storm as well with the potential for wind gusts 40 to 50 mph for the valley areas. Sierra ridge wind gusts got a boost with potential for gusts 90+ mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station (DYLC1-Doyle) located 3.0 mi N of Doyle, CA,  reported a peak wind gust 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warmer storm brought more rain, high elevation snow, and gusty southwesterly winds late Tuesday into Wednesday. An upper-level low moving into the Pacific Northwest flattened a persistent ridge on Tuesday afternoon, and allowed warmer subtropical moisture to be transported into our region with the increased more zonally directed westerly flow aloft. Higher ridge level winds increased late Tuesday morning as an upper jet oriented over the region bringing peak overnight wind gusts to around 80-100 mph. Ridge winds remained elevated through Wednesday, with breezy SW winds mixing down to valleys by Wednesday afternoon. The main precipitation band moved into the region by Tuesday PM wrapping up by late Wednesday AM. Snow levels remained a bit higher than previous storms due to the subtropical tap. Snow levels will hovered between 8000-8500 feet during the main precipitation event, briefly topping upwards to 9000 feet at times. Snow accumulations were confined to the high Sierra, with predicted storm totals ranging 2-6 inches above 8000 feet. In terms of liquid totals, the highest values expected stayed along the Sierra crest, generally between 0.75-1 inches. A sharp gradient in liquid precipitation persisted east of the crest due to stronger rain shadowing with 0.25-0.5 inches generally west of US-395 and trace-0.1 inch east of Highway 395.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station (MPRJN - Mid Mtn Chalet.) located 1.0 mi SE of June Mountain, CA, and mesonet station  (MTH01-MAMMOTH) located 0.9 mi S of Mammoth Mountain, CA,  reported peak wind gusts of 127 mph and 96 mph respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An otherwise major winter storm that pushed through the region closed out the Month of February. This storm increased the potential for damaging winds (gusts 55+ mph) February 29 that preceded the passage of a strong cold front through the region March 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This comparatively weaker winter storm opened up another active weather pattern that tracked through the Sierra and western Nevada late in the evening February 17-18. Mainly spillover rainfall fell over lower western Nevada valleys that included periods of gusty winds as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCORAHS station (NV-CC-23) located 1.0 mi W of Carson City, NV, and a trained spotter located 2.0 mi N of Stewart, NV, reported a 24 hr rainfall storm total of 1.33 inches and 1.23 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The active weather returns Wednesday afternoon to close out the month of January. Therefore, strong and gusty winds especially over higher mountain elevations was followed with mountain snow and valley rain showers. Wind was the first hazard expected starting over the Sierra and NE CA, then spreading into western Nevada with south winds between 30-50 mph, and gusts over 60-80 mph across higher mountain ridges and passes. Valley winds were projected to be 15-35 mph with gusts up to 55 mph. The probability of 60 mph winds across mountain areas in CA was 60% or greater and 10-20% over W NV. Lake winds were around 15-25 mph with gusts to 35-45 mph.||Valley rain and mountain snow showers were projected to move into the region   Wednesday PM. Global models and their respective ensemble members initially dug the trough and a deeper layer of sub-tropical IVT moisture will quickly sweep east and south across portions of northeast California, before descending into the Sierra, western Nevada, and Mono Co. Snow levels started near 7000 feet on Wednesday, then dropped to 6000 feet by Thursday. Most higher elevation areas received mostly rain initially before transitioning to mostly snow Thursday evening. Snow levels dropped to 5500 ft on Thursday afternoon, and dropped further to below 4000 feet by Friday morning. The Sierra above 7000 and Mono Co were given even chances for about 1-2 feet of new snow with 6-12 inches below 7000 feet. For northeast California 4-10 inches of accumulated snow, and up to 20 inches in the higher mountain passes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station (MTH22-MAMMOTH) located 1.0 mi ESE of Mammoth Mountain, CA reported a peak wind gust of 99 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry and mild weather pattern gave way to a more active weather pattern starting late night on February 14, which brought periods of gusty winds, mountain snow, and valley rain showers. This latest storm system brought  impacts to travel over Sierra passes to include mountain communities Wednesday night through Thursday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public located at the Palisades Tahoe Ski Base, CA, and Homewood Mountain Ski Base, CA, reported storm total snowfall of 12.0 inches and 10.0 inches respectively. The Northstar Ski Base , CA, and  Heavenly Ski Base, CA, both reported 24 hour storm total snowfall amounts of 9.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry and mild weather pattern gave way to a more active weather pattern starting late night on February 14, which brought periods of gusty winds, mountain snow, and valley rain showers. This latest storm system brought  impacts to travel over Sierra passes to include mountain communities Wednesday night through Thursday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public located at the Mammoth Mountain Ski Base, CA, reported a 24 hour storm total snowfall amount of 13.0 inches at the summit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front draped across central North Carolina served as a focus for thunderstorm redevelopment during the afternoon as the cold front shifted slowly south. Supercells developed across the southern Piedmont, Sandhills, and southern Coastal Plain Counties. The severe storms went on to produce prolific hail ranging from ping pong to just over hen egg size across southern portions of central North Carolina. One supercell thunderstorm went on to produce 3-4 inch hail in nearby Robeson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter inch hail was reported along McCaskill Rd near Candor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm moved up the east coast passing near the 70/40 benchmark brought heavy snow to southern New England beginning late Monday night and continuing on Sunday. The first round of heavy snow fell overnight followed by a lull in the snow and mixing with rain Sunday morning. Comma head snow then filled back into eastern MA and RI bringing moderate to heavy snow Sunday afternoon and evening. Snow amounts ranged from 2 to 18 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts generally ranged from 8 to 18.2 inches. Some accumulation amounts included 18.2 inches in Tyngsboro, 17.5 inches in Dunstable, and 16.6 inches in Lowell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm moved up the east coast passing near the 70/40 benchmark brought heavy snow to southern New England beginning late Monday night and continuing on Sunday. The first round of heavy snow fell overnight followed by a lull in the snow and mixing with rain Sunday morning. Comma head snow then filled back into eastern MA and RI bringing moderate to heavy snow Sunday afternoon and evening. Snow amounts ranged from 2 to 18 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Generally 15 to 18 inches of snow fell. Some accumulations included 18 inches in Haverhill, 17 inches in Groveland, and 17 inches in Methuen.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow developed in the late morning hours of March 25th over west central Kansas and expanded west through the late afternoon. The snow tapered off in the mid evening after leaving anywhere from 1 to 3 inches of new fallen snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three inches of new snow was estimated at Ulysses.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of three inches was measured 5 SE Ash Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Attention then turned to a significant winter storm that brought widespread snow impacts across the Sierra and western Nevada Sunday into early next week.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public located at the Mammoth Mountain Ski Base, CA, the June Lake Ski Base, CA, and a trained spotter located 1.0 mi SW of Tom's Place, CA, reported 24 hour storm total snowfall amounts of 33.0 inches, 31.0 inches, 12.0 inches respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This comparatively weaker winter storm opened up another active weather pattern that tracked through the Sierra and W.Nevada late in the evening February 17-18. This storm brought higher elevation snowfall that was heavy at times above 7000 feet. This storm also included the possibility of an additional several feet of snowfall.  Mainly spillover rainfall fell over lower western Nevada valleys that included periods of gusty winds as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public located at the June Lake Ski Base, CA, Main Lodge, reported a 24 hour storm total snowfall amounts of 12.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Attention then turned to a significant winter storm that brought widespread snow impacts across the Sierra and western Nevada Sunday into early next week.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CO-OP observer (HTHN2) located 0.6 mi S of Hawthorne, NV reported a storm total snowfall of 6.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above-normal rainfall continued into January, bringing an end to the Short-Term Drought over Georgia. At the start of the year, conditions had improved such that Fall 2023's D4 Exceptional Drought had been completed eliminated, and D3 Extreme Drought was close behind. Persistent rainy conditions were chipping away at the remaining D2 Severe Drought through the month. Statistically speaking, at the start of January, 11.5 percent of the state was in D2 Severe Drought or worse, with 0.1 percent being D3 Extreme Drought. By the end of January, only 1.3 percent of the state was in D1 Moderate Drought conditions, and no areas were in a D2 Severe Drought or higher category. ||In total, January's rainfall generally ranged from 3 to 10 inches over north and central Georgia. Far northeast Georgia received the highest amounts, with accumulations of 8 to 12 inches (100 to 200 percent of normal). The lowest rainfall amounts were observed over east central Georgia, where accumulations generally amounted to 2 to 4 inches (50 to 90 percent of normal). The remainder of the area received 6 to 8 inches of rain (125 to 300 percent of normal). In general, these rainfall amounts fell during only 2-3 impactful weather events during the month, with a bulk falling January 9-10, 2024. ||In the January 25 Drought Information Statement issued by the NWS Atlanta office, 30-day rainfall totals were included for some of the climate record locations: Rome (RMG) reported 5.70 inches (121 percent of normal), Atlanta (ATL) reported 4.84 inches (113 percent of normal), Gainesville (GVL) reported 8.42 inches (174 percent of normal), Athens (AHN) reported 9.52 inches (221 percent of normal), Peachtree-DeKalb (PDK) reported 4.70 inches (106 percent of normal), Peachtree City (FFC) reported 5.18 inches (123 percent of normal), and Columbus (CSG) reported 4.20 inches (99 percent of normal). These 30-day totals show a marked difference from the abnormally low Fall 2023 monthly rainfall totals. ||By the end of January, soil moisture normal to above normal for the state, and the Crop Moisture Index indicated all nine Georgia climatological zones were Favorably Moist to Wet. The USDA's Crop Progress and Conditions report from the early January indicated livestock was reported to be in good condition, though hay supplies continued to run low due to the fall drought conditions. Cattle farmers were still having to supplement food to extend limited hay supplies. Additionally, the overall crop update for cotton and winter wheat was favorable. ||The drought ended statewide by January 30, 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: According to the Drought Monitor, D2 Severe Drought conditions were present in Gilmer county at the beginning of January. Above-normal January rainfall rapidly improved conditions to D1 Moderate Drought on January 16, ending the short-term drought over Gilmer county. ||In total, Gilmer county was under D2 Severe Drought or worse conditions for approximately 12 weeks, beginning on or about October 24, 2023, and ending January 16, 2024. At the peak, Gilmer county was under D3 Extreme Drought conditions for approximately 8 weeks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bora wind event resulted in strong winds for southeast Wyoming wind-prone locations gusting around 60 MPH late on the 18th into early morning on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple wind sensors near Burford reported wind gusts around 60 mph. UPR mesonet station SHERWS (UR535) measured maximum wind gust 2 miles west-northwest of Buford at 12:48 AM MST on 2/19.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved southeast through the region during the morning hours of the 28th.  The thunderstorms produce strong and gusty winds at points along the line, with several reports of trees, power lines and minor structural damage reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and a power pole were knocked down on Riverton Rose Trace near the TVA campground. A power pole fell on a vehicle temporarily trapping an occupant. Time estimated by radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved southeast through the region during the morning hours of the 28th.  The thunderstorms produce strong and gusty winds at points along the line, with several reports of trees, power lines and minor structural damage reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A power line was knocked down or leaning along Spring Valley Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system over the southern Plains strengthened significantly as it reached the eastern Great Lakes. This placed New England on the warm side of the storm with strong SE winds and rain instead of snow. This lead to widespread river flooding and coastal flooding on both the south and east coasts of southern New England. The heaviest rain fell over eastern CT, RI, and eastern MA with totals of 1 to 3 inches which added to already saturated ground from previous storms. A storm surge of 2 to 3 feet occurred on the east coast of MA even with offshore winds. Coastal flooding was minor to moderate on both coasts. This led to the 4th highest crest on record for Boston Harbor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Foxborough at 6:39 AM EST a tree and wires were down on Water St.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon and evening hours of April 27th, severe storms impacted northeast and eastern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado was reported by emergency management 2 miles west southwest of White Cloud at 215 pm on 4/27. A mutual aid storm survey conducted by NWS Topeka indicated no damage in the vicinity of the tornado. Therefore, the tornado is rated EF-Unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon hours of April 18th, Henry and Pettis County received severe hail and wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ping pong ball sized hail reported on far west side of Clinton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon hours of April 18th, Henry and Pettis County received severe hail and wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail reported at Wilder RV in northeast Clinton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours of April 18th, storms brought damaging wind gusts to eastern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported near Piper.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours of April 18th, storms brought damaging wind gusts to eastern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported near Piper.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours of April 18th, storms brought damaging wind gusts to eastern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed power lines and power outages in Kansas City, Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours of April 18th, storms brought damaging wind gusts to eastern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed power lines and power outages in Kansas City, Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours of April 18th, storms brough damaging wind gusts and a few hail reports to Missouri.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A barn was largely destroyed near the intersection of 208th and Raum Road north of Lawson. This was part of a large swath of wind damage in the Lawson area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow spread across the region on the 12th. As the snow was ending, northwest winds increased and temperatures dropped below zero on the 13th. There was blowing snow across western and central Minnesota, but the lack of snow on the ground kept travel impacts to a minimum. Overnight wind chills fell to near 40 below across western and central Minnesota the night of the 13th into the 14th.||Based on discussions with other forecasters, emergency managers, and Minnesota Department of Transportation, this would have been a high-impact blizzard if there was a deep snow pack.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted to 31 mph at the Albert Lea airport, with blowing snow and reduced visibilities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours of April 18th, storms brough damaging wind gusts and a few hail reports to Missouri.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A barn was largely destroyed near the intersection of 208th and Raum Road north of Lawson. This was part of a large swath of wind damage in the Lawson area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A negatively tilted mid level trough swung through New England while at the surface a low pressure center passed directly over southern New England. This inland runner brought warm air so that all precipitation fell as rain, along with strong winds. There was a good deal of tree damage from the winds and widespread river flooding with many rivers going into major flood stage. Coastal flooding was also a problem. Minor to moderate coastal flooding impacted both the south and east coasts of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Weatherflow site at Dread Ledge gusted to 58 mph at 2:04 AM EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system over the southern Plains strengthened significantly as it reached the eastern Great Lakes. This placed New England on the warm side of the storm with strong SE winds and rain instead of snow. This lead to widespread river flooding and coastal flooding on both the south and east coasts of southern New England. The heaviest rain fell over eastern CT, RI, and eastern MA with totals of 1 to 3 inches which added to already saturated ground from previous storms. A storm surge of 2 to 3 feet occurred on the east coast of MA even with offshore winds. Coastal flooding was minor to moderate on both coasts. This led to the 4th highest crest on record for Boston Harbor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Chelmsford at 6:55 AM EST a tree and wires were down on Water St.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This comparatively weaker winter storm opened up another active weather pattern that tracked through the Sierra and western Nevada late in the evening February 17-18. This storm brought higher elevation snowfall that was heavy at times above 7000 feet. This storm also included the possibility of an additional several feet of snowfall.  Mainly spillover rainfall fell over lower western Nevada valleys that included periods of gusty winds as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public located at the Mount Rose Ski Base summit, a trained spotter(WA-12) located 1.0 mi NNW of Incline Village, and the public located at the Diamond Peak Ski resort reported 24 hour storm snowfall totals of 14.0 inches, 9.0 inches, and 7.0 inches respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This storm was allowed to tap into Pacific moisture for a longer period of time that nudged it just enough north to make a more direct landfall into the central OR coast.  This next storm Friday evening into Saturday brought more gusty winds, Sierra snow, and valley rain/snow showers. This storms warmer nature raised snow levels a bit higher(5500-6500 feet) with the potential for mixed precipitation in the valley areas and foothills. The lower-end ensemble snow scenarios showed a bit more confident projection for at least a foot of snow in the Sierra with potential for 18-24 inches along the Sierra crest. Regardless, this contributed to another bout of travel disruptions, especially for ski commutes during the upcoming holiday weekend. Wind speeds have trended up a bit with this storm as well with the potential for wind gusts 40 to 50 mph for the valley areas. Sierra ridge wind gusts got a boost with potential for gusts 90+ mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CO-OP Observer located 1.0 mi W of Donner, CA reported 24 hour storm total snowfall amounts of 9.6 inches. The public located 1.0 mi NNW of Truckee, CA, and 1.0 mi SSW of Northstar Ski Base both reported 24 hour storm total snowfall amounts of 9.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following summer-like, record warmth, severe thunderstorms developed in the late afternoon of February 27th over northwest Illinois and spread east through the evening across the Chicago metro area. A total of 11 tornadoes touched down in Illinois. There were 11 tornadoes in total across the NWS Chicago area of responsibility, which is the most in a February event since official NWS tornado records began in 1950. In addition to the tornadoes, the storms produced numerous instances of severe hail and damaging straight-line wind.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado had a very short path with damage confined primarily to a single two-story apartment building. Most of the roof was removed from the building, and a portion of the brick facade also collapsed when the roof was removed. Two large softwood trees in the parking lot east of the building were uprooted. Debris was deposited to the east across the street, where a few tree branches were also snapped. In the apartment building south of the main one that was damaged, a resident described seeing a second story glass patio door on the east side being pulled out and shattered by the winds. One 13 year old resident sustained bad bruising after part of his ceiling collapsed and struck him in the arm.

In general, these rainfall amounts fell during only 2-3 impactful weather events during the month, with a bulk falling January 9-10, 2024. ||In the January 25 Drought Information Statement issued by the NWS Atlanta office, 30-day rainfall totals were included for some of the climate record locations: Rome (RMG) reported 5.70 inches (121 percent of normal), Atlanta (ATL) reported 4.84 inches (113 percent of normal), Gainesville (GVL) reported 8.42 inches (174 percent of normal), Athens (AHN) reported 9.52 inches (221 percent of normal), Peachtree-DeKalb (PDK) reported 4.70 inches (106 percent of normal), Peachtree City (FFC) reported 5.18 inches (123 percent of normal), and Columbus (CSG) reported 4.20 inches (99 percent of normal). These 30-day totals show a marked difference from the abnormally low Fall 2023 monthly rainfall totals. ||By the end of January, soil moisture normal to above normal for the state, and the Crop Moisture Index indicated all nine Georgia climatological zones were Favorably Moist to Wet. The USDA's Crop Progress and Conditions report from the early January indicated livestock was reported to be in good condition, though hay supplies continued to run low due to the fall drought conditions. Cattle farmers were still having to supplement food to extend limited hay supplies. Additionally, the overall crop update for cotton and winter wheat was favorable. ||The drought ended statewide by January 30, 2024.

Above-normal January rainfall rapidly improved conditions to D1 Moderate Drought on January 9, ending the short-term drought over Banks county. ||In total, Banks county was under D2 Severe Drought or worse conditions for approximately 7 weeks, beginning on or about November 21, 2023, and ending January 9, 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Nor'easter passed offshore of southern New England bringing widespread heavy rainfall, high elevation snow and sleet, as well as strong winds to the region. There was minor flooding on some rivers as well as minor to moderate coastal flooding along the east coast of MA. This was a late season snow storm with very elevation dependent snowfall totals from 0 to over 8 inches. Wind damage was sporadic and mostly minor, with over 25,000 power outages reported in western MA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Kalmus at 3:07 PM EDT a Weatherflow site reported a gust to 67 mph. In Hyannis the airport ASOS (KHYA) reported a gust to 58 mph at 2:37 AM EDT. At Hatch Beach at 9:49 AM EDT a Weatherflow site reported a gust to 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure brought a burst of moderate to heavy snow to southern WI as it tracked from the northern Great Lakes to central Lake MI. Several inches of snowfall combined with west northwest wind gusts of 25-45 mph made for hazardous winter travel. Numerous vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred due to snow covered roads and reduced visibility.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulation of 2-4 inches, highest amounts in the far southeastern portion of the county. West northwest wind gusts of 30-40 mph with visibility as low as 1/2-1 mile.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulation of 1-2 inches. West northwest wind gusts of 25-35 mph with visibility as low as 1/2-1 mile.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulation of 2-3 inches. West northwest wind gusts of 25-35 mph with visibility as low as 1/4-1/2 mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system over the southern Plains strengthened significantly as it reached the eastern Great Lakes. This placed New England on the warm side of the storm with strong SE winds and rain instead of snow. This lead to widespread river flooding and coastal flooding on both the south and east coasts of southern New England. The heaviest rain fell over eastern CT, RI, and eastern MA with totals of 1 to 3 inches which added to already saturated ground from previous storms. A storm surge of 2 to 3 feet occurred on the east coast of MA even with offshore winds. Coastal flooding was minor to moderate on both coasts. This led to the 4th highest crest on record for Boston Harbor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Sandwich at 7:22 AM EST there was a tree down on Old Country Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon of May 27th, a relatively strong pressure gradient created a low-level jet stream of >50 knots with portions of northern New York being in the warm, slightly unstable sector. A weak cold front approached the region in the late afternoon and evening hours producing isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms. A few thunderstorms, although not strong by normal standards were able to tap into the strong low level winds and produce isolated wind gusts that caused some damage to trees and utilities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed tree and limbs into powerlines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few downed powerlines caused by downed trees onto lines.

CZ_NAME: HAWK CHANNEL FROM OCEAN REEF TO CRAIG KEY OUT TO THE REEF
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered gale-force wind gusts and a couple waterspouts in association with thunderstorm outflows were observed during the morning of May 20th over the lower and middle Florida Keys as a cold front slowly approached the Florida Keys from the north.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 37 knots was measured by a WeatherFlow station at Alligator Reef Light.

In general, these rainfall amounts fell during only 2-3 impactful weather events during the month, with a bulk falling January 9-10, 2024. ||In the January 25 Drought Information Statement issued by the NWS Atlanta office, 30-day rainfall totals were included for some of the climate record locations: Rome (RMG) reported 5.70 inches (121 percent of normal), Atlanta (ATL) reported 4.84 inches (113 percent of normal), Gainesville (GVL) reported 8.42 inches (174 percent of normal), Athens (AHN) reported 9.52 inches (221 percent of normal), Peachtree-DeKalb (PDK) reported 4.70 inches (106 percent of normal), Peachtree City (FFC) reported 5.18 inches (123 percent of normal), and Columbus (CSG) reported 4.20 inches (99 percent of normal). These 30-day totals show a marked difference from the abnormally low Fall 2023 monthly rainfall totals. ||By the end of January, soil moisture normal to above normal for the state, and the Crop Moisture Index indicated all nine Georgia climatological zones were Favorably Moist to Wet. The USDA's Crop Progress and Conditions report from the early January indicated livestock was reported to be in good condition, though hay supplies continued to run low due to the fall drought conditions. Cattle farmers were still having to supplement food to extend limited hay supplies. Additionally, the overall crop update for cotton and winter wheat was favorable. ||The drought ended statewide by January 30, 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: According to the Drought Monitor, D2 Severe Drought conditions were present in Walker county at the beginning of January. Above-normal January rainfall rapidly improved conditions to D1 Moderate Drought on January 30, ending the short-term drought over Walker county. ||In total, Walker county was under D2 Severe Drought or worse conditions for approximately 16 weeks, beginning on or about October 10, 2023, and ending January 30, 2024. At the peak, Walker County was under D4 Exceptional Drought conditions for approximately 3 weeks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm moved up the east coast passing near the 70/40 benchmark brought heavy snow to southern New England beginning late Monday night and continuing on Sunday. The first round of heavy snow fell overnight followed by a lull in the snow and mixing with rain Sunday morning. Comma head snow then filled back into eastern MA and RI bringing moderate to heavy snow Sunday afternoon and evening. Snow amounts ranged from 2 to 18 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Generally 5 to 7 inches of snow fell. Some accumulations included 6.5 inches in West Warwick and 5.6 inches at T.F. Green Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A negatively tilted mid level trough swung through New England while at the surface a low pressure center passed directly over southern New England. This inland runner brought warm air so that all precipitation fell as rain, along with strong winds. There was a good deal of tree damage from the winds and widespread river flooding with many rivers going into major flood stage. Coastal flooding was also a problem. Minor to moderate coastal flooding impacted both the south and east coasts of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NDBC site reported a gust of 63 mph at 12:18 AM EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A negatively tilted mid level trough swung through New England while at the surface a low pressure center passed directly over southern New England. This inland runner brought warm air so that all precipitation fell as rain, along with strong winds. There was a good deal of tree damage from the winds and widespread river flooding with many rivers going into major flood stage. Coastal flooding was also a problem. Minor to moderate coastal flooding impacted both the south and east coasts of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Weatherflow site at Deer Island in Boston Harbor gusted to 63 mph at 2:00 AM EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure brought a burst of moderate to heavy snow to southern WI as it tracked from the northern Great Lakes to central Lake MI. Several inches of snowfall combined with west northwest wind gusts of 25-45 mph made for hazardous winter travel. Numerous vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred due to snow covered roads and reduced visibility.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulation of 1-4 inches, highest amounts in the eastern portion of the county. West northwest wind gusts of 25-35 mph with visibility as low as 1/4-1/2 mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This comparatively weaker winter storm opened up another active weather pattern that tracked through the Sierra and W.Nevada late in the evening February 17-18. This storm brought higher elevation snowfall that was heavy at times above 7000 feet. This storm also included the possibility of an additional several feet of snowfall.  Mainly spillover rainfall fell over lower western Nevada valleys that included periods of gusty winds as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station located at Palisades Tahoe Alpine Meadows summit, CA,  reported a peak wind gust of 128 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above-normal rainfall continued into January, bringing an end to the Short-Term Drought over Georgia. At the start of the year, conditions had improved such that Fall 2023's D4 Exceptional Drought had been completed eliminated, and D3 Extreme Drought was close behind. Persistent rainy conditions were chipping away at the remaining D2 Severe Drought through the month. Statistically speaking, at the start of January, 11.5 percent of the state was in D2 Severe Drought or worse, with 0.1 percent being D3 Extreme Drought. By the end of January, only 1.3 percent of the state was in D1 Moderate Drought conditions, and no areas were in a D2 Severe Drought or higher category. ||In total, January's rainfall generally ranged from 3 to 10 inches over north and central Georgia. Far northeast Georgia received the highest amounts, with accumulations of 8 to 12 inches (100 to 200 percent of normal). The lowest rainfall amounts were observed over east central Georgia, where accumulations generally amounted to 2 to 4 inches (50 to 90 percent of normal). The remainder of the area received 6 to 8 inches of rain (125 to 300 percent of normal). In general, these rainfall amounts fell during only 2-3 impactful weather events during the month, with a bulk falling January 9-10, 2024. ||In the January 25 Drought Information Statement issued by the NWS Atlanta office, 30-day rainfall totals were included for some of the climate record locations: Rome (RMG) reported 5.70 inches (121 percent of normal), Atlanta (ATL) reported 4.84 inches (113 percent of normal), Gainesville (GVL) reported 8.42 inches (174 percent of normal), Athens (AHN) reported 9.52 inches (221 percent of normal), Peachtree-DeKalb (PDK) reported 4.70 inches (106 percent of normal), Peachtree City (FFC) reported 5.18 inches (123 percent of normal), and Columbus (CSG) reported 4.20 inches (99 percent of normal). These 30-day totals show a marked difference from the abnormally low Fall 2023 monthly rainfall totals. ||By the end of January, soil moisture normal to above normal for the state, and the Crop Moisture Index indicated all nine Georgia climatological zones were Favorably Moist to Wet. The USDA's Crop Progress and Conditions report from the early January indicated livestock was reported to be in good condition, though hay supplies continued to run low due to the fall drought conditions. Cattle farmers were still having to supplement food to extend limited hay supplies. Additionally, the overall crop update for cotton and winter wheat was favorable. ||The drought ended statewide by January 30, 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: According to the Drought Monitor, D2 Severe Drought conditions were present in Chattooga county at the beginning of January. Above-normal January rainfall rapidly improved conditions to D1 Moderate Drought on January 30, ending the short-term drought over Chattooga county. ||In total, Chattooga county was under D2 Severe Drought or worse conditions for approximately 15 weeks, beginning on or about October 17, 2023, and ending January 30, 2024. At the peak, Chattooga county was under D4 Exceptional Drought conditions for approximately 3 weeks.
