EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low pressure system dropped southeast over the Great Basin on January 3 which pushed a cold front across central California. This system produced moderate to locally heavy rainfall for a short time over the lower elevations and 12 to 18 inches of new snowfall above 6000 feet from Fresno County northward as well as 5 to 10  inches of next snow above 6000 feet in Tulare County. Rainfall amounts were generally a half inch to an inch of rain in the Sierra foothills, a quarter to half inch of rainfall in the central San Joaquin Valley and a tenth to a quarter inch in the south San Joaquin Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Blue Max RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 65 mph.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE OF FRESNO AND KINGS COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Skies cleared out overnight across the San Joaquin Valley during the early morning of January 1. This allowed for areas of dense fog to form by sunrise as winds remined light. The fog lifted into a low cloud deck by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Lemoore.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Skies cleared out overnight across the San Joaquin Valley during the early morning of January 1. This allowed for areas of dense fog to form by sunrise as winds remined light. The fog lifted into a low cloud deck by late morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the departure of a storm which brought light to moderate precipitation to the  area between the morning of January 20 and the early afternoon of January 21, a second system moved through central California between the late evening of January 21 and the afternoon of January 22. This system produced three quarters to an inch and a half of rainfall over Merced County and a half inch to an inch of liquid precipitation the the Sierra Nevada with the snow level around 8000 feet. Much of the remainder of the San Joaquin Valley and the Tehachapi Mountains picked up between a half inch and an inch of rainfall which produced some localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported flooding on SR 59 with two vehicles spun out near Fields Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure moved into central California on January 17 which resulted in clearing skies and light winds over the area by the evening. With low level moisture present in the San Joaquin Valley due to recent rainfall, dense fog formed overnight and continued through the late morning hours of January 18 until it lifted into a low cloud deck. The fog was responsible for a 6 vehicle accident near Chowchilla which resulted in one fatality and several injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several webcams showed visibility below 1000 feet.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Reedley, Visalia and Porterville. Several webcams showed visibility below 1000 feet.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE OF FRESNO AND KINGS COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog formed along the Interstate 5 corridor in Fresno and Kings Counties during the early morning of January 25, reducing visibility to a few hundred feet in some spots. The fog dissipated shortly after sunrise.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Web cameras indicated visibility below 1000 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure strengthened off the California coast overnight and pushed inland during the early morning of January 26. With mainly clear skies and light winds prevailing in the San Joaquin Valley, areas of dense fog formed in the central portion of the valley towards daybreak most noticeably along the SR 198 corridor between Visalia and Hanford and along SR 99 in Tulare. the fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford. Web cameras indicated visibility below 500 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mixing ahead of an incoming trough resulted in mainly clear skies across the San Joaquin Valley during the morning of January 10. With light winds also prevailing over the lower elevations, areas of dense fog formed near sunrise in portions of the San Joaquin Valley, most noticeably along the SR 99 corridor north of Fresno where travel was impacted by visibilities below 500 feet in places. The fog prevailed through late morning before mixing  out.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Reedley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strengthening high pressure over central California brought clearing skies and light winds to the area during the morning of January 28. This allowed for areas of dense fog to form along the SR 99 corridor and traffic was impacted between Merced and Bakersfield by sunrise, with visibility be0ing reduced below 500 feet in some locations. The fog completely dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Web cameras indicated visibility below 500 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold upper low pressure system pushed into the Pacific Northwest on January 6 then dropped southeast into the Great Basin by the morning of January 7, A cold front that accompanied this system crossed central California during the evening of January 6 bringing a period of light to moderate precipitation and strong winds to the area. Several stations in the mountains and deserts of Kern County measured gusts exceeding 45 mph with a few stations exceeding 70 mph. Precipitation amounts were generally a quarter to a half inch from Fresno County northward and a tenth to a quarter inch further south. Elevations above 6000 feet generally picked up between 5  to 10 inches of new snowfall with a few locations in the south end of the Sierra Nevada picking up 12 inches or more. The snow level lowered to 2500 feet before the precipitation ended during the morning of January 7 with several locations in the Sierra foothills and Tehachapi Mountains picking up between 1 and 3 inches of new snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several SNOTEL stations picked up an estimated 5 to 10 inches of new snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold upper trough moved across central California during the evening of January 10 and the early morning of January 11. This system brought another half inch to an inch of liquid precipitation to the Sierra Nevada and adjacent foothills north of Kings Canyon with many locations picking up 5 to 10 inches of new snow with a few SNOTELs estimating a foot of new snowfall. Areas further south in the Sierra Nevada and much of the Tehachapi Mountains picked up between a quarter and a half inch while much of the San Joaquin Valley received between a tenth and a quarter inch of rainfall. This system also produced a period of strong wind gusts with several stations in the Tehachapi area and the Mojave Deserts slopes measuring gusts exceeding 50 mph and a few low impact indicator sites reporting gusts exceeding 75 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jawbone Canyon RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 80 mph.

CZ_NAME: SOUTH END OF THE UPPER SIERRA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold upper trough moved across central California during the evening of January 10 and the early morning of January 11. This system brought another half inch to an inch of liquid precipitation to the Sierra Nevada and adjacent foothills north of Kings Canyon with many locations picking up 5 to 10 inches of new snow with a few SNOTELs estimating a foot of new snowfall. Areas further south in the Sierra Nevada and much of the Tehachapi Mountains picked up between a quarter and a half inch while much of the San Joaquin Valley received between a tenth and a quarter inch of rainfall. This system also produced a period of strong wind gusts with several stations in the Tehachapi area and the Mojave Deserts slopes measuring gusts exceeding 50 mph and a few low impact indicator sites reporting gusts exceeding 75 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bear Peak RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 80 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave coupled with modest instability, strong shear, and steep mid level lapse rates resulted in several severe thunderstorms from western MA to eastern CT to RI to southeast MA. All the severe reports were large hail reports. The cool marine layer prevented any wind damage and tornado risk. The largest hail stone to fall was 2 inches in Narragansett, RI.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In West Warwick 1.25 inch hail was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late-season, storm brought significant rainfall to the area along with strong thunderstorms. Rainfall totals across the area ranged from 0.50 to 1.50 inches across San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties to 1 to 2 inches across Ventura and Los Angeles counties. Unstable air, associated with the storm, brought scattered strong thunderstorms to the area, producing gusty winds, large hail and even some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong thunderstorms generated heavy rainfall in the Monrovia area. This heavy rain generated flash flooding. Several business on Huntington Drive between Santa Anita Avenue and 2nd Avenue reported significant flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving storm system produced snow in the mountains and light rain across the coast and valleys. Several inches of snow were reported in the mountains, and thundersnow occurred in the Riverside County Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow fell across the San Bernardino County Mountains on January 3, with accumulations as low as 4900 feet reported. Most areas saw 1-3 inches, with locations near Snow Summit, Snow Valley, Green Valley Lake and Forest Falls seeing up to 4 inches in accumulations. Numerous vehicle incidents were reported in the mountains as a result of snow covered roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving storm system produced snow in the mountains and light rain across the coast and valleys. Several inches of snow were reported in the mountains, and thundersnow occurred in the Riverside County Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow fell across the Riverside County Mountains on January 3, with accumulations as low as 5400 feet reported. Most areas saw 1-3 inches, with Long Valley Mount San Jacinto seeing up to 6 inches of snow. Thundersnow was reported near Mount San Jacinto 4-6pm on January 3.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving storm system produced snow in the mountains and light rain across the coast and valleys. Several inches of snow were reported in the mountains, and thundersnow occurred in the Riverside County Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to 1 inch of snow fell as low as 5700 feet in the San Diego County Mountains on January 3.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved northeast from the Mid-Atlantic Region to southern New England during the night of January 9, 2024 into the early morning hours of January 10, 2024. Its center passed just north of the region during this period. The pressure gradient tightened as the center of the storm approached, producing high winds over Southeastern New York during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple occurrences of downed trees or downed large limbs were reported. The Department of Highways reported a downed tree on the Northern State Parkway eastbound, west of exit 58 in Melville, NY at 956 PM Local Standard Time on January 9, 2024. The public reported a very large limb landing on cars in Centerport, NY at 1155 PM Local Standard Time on January 9, 2024. A trained spotter reported a large tree limb down at Old Field Road and Brambletye Lane in Old Field, NY at 1225 AM Local Standard Time on January 10, 2024.

CZ_NAME: WESTERN SAN GABRIEL MOUNTAINS INCLUDING THE HIGHWAY 14 CORRIDOR
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second, late season, storm rolled across Southwestern California. This storm brought strong north to northeast winds as well as strong thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds  and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north to northeast winds were observed across the western San Gabriel Mountains. Some peak gusts include: Magic Mountain Truck Trail (gust 86 MPH), Chilao RAWS (gust 75 MPH), Camp Nine RAWS (gust 69 MPH) and Sierra Pelona (gust 70 MPH).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved northeast from the Mid-Atlantic Region to southern New England during the night of January 9, 2024 into the early morning hours of January 10, 2024. Its center passed just north of the region during this period. The pressure gradient tightened as the center of the storm approached, producing high winds over Southeastern New York during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple high wind gusts were measured, including a sustained wind of 40 mph along with a gust of 59 mph at 1140 PM Local Standard Time on January 9, 2024 at ASOS reporting station KFRG, Farmingdale Airport in Farmingdale, NY. A measured wind gust of 60 mph was recorded at 1149 PM Local Standard Time on January 9, 2024 at a mesonet site located at the Fire Island Campgrounds near Captree State Park, NYC. Additionally, a wind gust of 58 mph was recorded at 1201 AM Local Standard Time at ASOS reporting station KISP, Islip Airport in Ronkonkoma, NY.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An occluded low pressure system brought heavy rain on the front end, with a change to heavy wet accumulating snow in higher elevations as the upper level low approached. Their were much lower amounts in lower elevations. The upper low swung through on the back end of the system early on the 22nd resulted in height falls and colder air working in changing the precipitation to mainly wet snow across portions of the interior, especially in elevated locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A cocorahs observer reported 4.5 inches in Cold Spring.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An occluded low pressure system brought heavy rain on the front end, with a change to heavy wet accumulating snow in higher elevations as the upper level low approached. EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported 7.5 inches at 5 N West Milford and a cocorahs observer reported 3.4 inches in West Milford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an Arctic air mass moved south through Mississippi, light to moderate precipitation was quick to freeze as it fell through the cold surface air. Although light accumulations of freezing rain, and sleet fell across much of the state of Mississippi, more significant accumulations of sleet over one half inch fell primarily north and west of the Natchez Trace corridor. Accumulations of 2 to 3 inches of sleet were measured in the Greenville to Cleveland areas. Area roads were impacted by slick conditions due to the glaze of ice and accumulated sleet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around one quarter to one half inch of mainly sleet fell across the county, but light snow and freezing rain also fell. Area roads were covered by the glaze of ice and sleet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture increased over the area by a fast moving clipper system on January 1st which allowed dense freezing fog to form during the morning of January 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the Wolf Point Airport ASOS site (KOLF), intermittent visibilities of a quarter mile or less was recorded for about 6 3/4 hours from early to mid morning on the 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Enough moisture remained around northeast Montana to generate another round of Dense Freezing Fog on the night of the 4th which lasted through the morning of the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the Glendive Airport ASOS site (KGDV), visibility of a quarter mile or less was recorded for about 3 1/4 hours during the morning of the 5th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second, late season, storm rolled across Southwestern California. This storm brought strong north to northeast winds as well as strong thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds  and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north to northeast winds were observed across the western San Fernando Valley. Some peak gusts include: Pacoima (gust 63 MPH) and Van Nuys (gust 61 MPH).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second, late season, storm rolled across Southwestern California. This storm brought strong north to northeast winds as well as strong thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds  and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north to northeast winds were observed across the eastern range of the San Gabriel Mountains. Some peak gusts include: Mount Lukens Truck Trail (gust 83 MPH), Clear Creek RAWS (gust 72 MPH) and Barley Flats (gust 64 MPH).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second, late season, storm rolled across Southwestern California. This storm brought strong north to northeast winds as well as strong thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds  and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north to northeast winds were observed across the Santa Clarita Valley. Some peak gusts include: Solemint Canyon (gust 59 MPH) and Newhall Pass RAWS (gust 58 MPH).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The coldest Arctic air mass in many years settled into the region with widespread temperatures of 20 to 40 degrees below zero and wind chills measuring between 40 and 70 degrees below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the Navajo MT-5 DOT site (MTRED), temperatures in the teens to 30s below zero and breezy winds created intermittent periods of wind chills of 40 degrees below zero or colder from the night of the 11th into the morning of the 16th. The peak wind chill of 71 degrees below zero was recorded at 12:30 AM, 1:00 AM, 6:45 AM and 7:15 AM on the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second, late season, storm rolled across Southwestern California. This storm brought strong north to northeast winds as well as strong thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds  and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north to northeast winds were observed across the Malibu Coast. Some peak gusts include: Escondido Canyon (gust 65 MPH), Malibu Creek (gust 64 MPH) and Ramirez Canyon (gust 60 MPH).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Nor'easter passed offshore of southern New England bringing widespread heavy rainfall, high elevation snow and sleet, as well as strong winds to the region. There was minor flooding on some rivers as well as minor to moderate coastal flooding along the east coast of MA. This was a late season snow storm with very elevation dependent snowfall totals from 0 to over 8 inches. Wind damage was sporadic and mostly minor, with over 25,000 power outages reported in western MA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Dread Ledge a weather flow site gusted to 59 mph at 1:29 AM EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure brought a burst of moderate to heavy snow to southern WI as it tracked from the northern Great Lakes to central Lake MI. Several inches of snowfall combined with west northwest wind gusts of 25-45 mph made for hazardous winter travel. Numerous vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred due to snow covered roads and reduced visibility.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulation of 4-6 inches. West northwest wind gusts of 25-35 mph with visibility as low as 1/4-1/2 mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large low pressure system impacted the area late on January 9th and into the 10th with long duration persistent moderate to heavy rainfall. In addition to widespread river flooding, some localized areas of flash flooding occurred as the heaviest rainfall associated with convection moved through. Precipitable water values of 1.2-1.4 inches were record levels for early January. The anomalous moisture and heavy rainfall resulted in a widespread 2 - 4 inches of rainfall, much of it occurring over a several hour timeframe before the cold frontal passage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Marcus Avenue closed due to flooding in Manhasset Hills.

CZ_NAME: SAXON HARBOR WI TO UPPER ENTRANCE OF PORTAGE CANAL MI 5NM OFFSHORE TO US/CANADIAN BORDER INC ISLE ROYAL NP
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through northern Ontario produced storm force west-southwest winds over the west half of Lake Superior during the evening of the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak storm force west wind gust of 57 mph recorded at Rock of Ages Light.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening low pressure system passing through northern Ontario produced a strong west wind gust to 58 mph at the Houghton County Airport on the evening of the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: West winds briefly gusted to 58 mph at the Houghton County Airport ASOS on the evening of the 7th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another complex of thunderstorms moved southeast through North and Central Texas during the day on May 30, producing scattered wind damage and severe hail along with some flash flooding. A second round of storms initiated along the dryline Thursday evening, producing more severe weather and flash flooding overnight into the early morning hours of May 31. After above normal rainfall throughout the month, grounds were so saturated that it didn't take much to cause flash flooding or knock down trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported a couple of roads flooded in south Fort Worth.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper air analysis depicted a negatively tilted trough over the western CONUS, with its axis extending from the central Rocky Mountains northwest into the Pacific Northwest. At the surface, a low-pressure center was deepening over the northern High Plains along with a secondary surface low in western Nebraska. Extending south out of these pressure centers was a Pacific cold front. At 21 UTC, a warm front was noted to extend southeast from southwest Nebraska into northeast Oklahoma. As the evening progressed, strong warm air advection ahead of the mature low-pressure pushed the warm front north into eastern Nebraska by 00 UTC. ||Along this warm front and ahead of the Pacific cold front, several lines of strong to severe thunderstorms moved through eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. The first line of strong storms moved through central and northeast Nebraska after 4:30 PM CDT. No severe reports were associated with these storms in the OAX CWA. Another intensifying segment of the same line moved into southeast Nebraska by 7:30 PM CDT, this time south of the northward advancing warm front. These storms tracked northeast through southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa, producing numerous severe wind gusts across the area and multiple spin-up tornadoes. The vast majority of wind gusts recorded with these storms ranged from 55 to 70 miles per hour. The strongest wind gust was measured at 71 miles per hour in Richardson County. 2 EF-0 tornadoes were confirmed in southeast Nebraska, both in Gage County. There were also an additional 3 tornadoes confirmed in southwest Iowa, all EF-1 tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report was received by the public of 4-inch tree branches blown down in Millard. The time was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Skies cleared out overnight across the San Joaquin Valley during the early morning of January 1. This allowed for areas of dense fog to form by sunrise as winds remined light. The fog lifted into a low cloud deck by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Skies cleared out overnight across the San Joaquin Valley during the early morning of January 1. This allowed for areas of dense fog to form by sunrise as winds remined light. The fog lifted into a low cloud deck by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Reedley, Visalia and Porterville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog developed in the San Joaquin Valley and Tehachapi Mountains by late evening on January 1. The dense fog became more prevalent across the San Joaquin  Valley overnight and remained persistent in the south end of the valley until late morning on January 2. The fog also contributed to a serious accident on SR 99 during the late morning south of  Bakersfield which injured a motorist. The fog lifted into a low cloud deck by midday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in the west side of Fresno.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mixing took place ahead of an incoming storm during the early morning of January 3 allowing for skies to clear out and some patches of dense fog to briefly form and impact travel along portions of SR 99. The fog mixed out by late morning as the storm moved into the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Merced.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low pressure system dropped southeast over the Great Basin on January 3 which pushed a cold front across central California. This system produced moderate to locally heavy rainfall for a short time over the lower elevations and 12 to 18 inches of new snowfall above 6000 feet from Fresno County northward as well as 5 to 10  inches of next snow above 6000 feet in Tulare County. Rainfall amounts were generally a half inch to an inch of rain in the Sierra foothills, a quarter to half inch of rainfall in the central San Joaquin Valley and a tenth to a quarter inch in the south San Joaquin Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported debris on southbound Interstate 5 at the Grapevine Commercial Vehicle Enforcement Facility.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Some patches of dense fog formed in the south San Joaquin Valley during the morning of January 6. This resulted in impacts to travel along the SR 198 corridor between Visalia and Hanford and also along Interstate 5 west of Bakersfield where a 35 vehicle accident  took place and resulted in two fatalities. The fog dissipated by late morning as strong mixing took place ahead of an incoming storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Lemoore.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the departure of a storm which brought light to moderate precipitation to the  area between the morning of January 20 and the early afternoon of January 21, a second system moved through central California between the late evening of January 21 and the afternoon of January 22. This system produced three quarters to an inch and a half of rainfall over Merced County and a half inch to an inch of liquid precipitation the the Sierra Nevada with the snow level around 8000 feet. Much of the remainder of the San Joaquin Valley and the Tehachapi Mountains picked up between a half inch and an inch of rainfall which produced some localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several SNOTEL stations picked up an estimated 4 to 8 inches of new snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strengthening high pressure over central California brought clearing skies and light winds to the area during the morning of January 28. This allowed for areas of dense fog to form along the SR 99 corridor and traffic was impacted between Merced and Bakersfield by sunrise, with visibility be0ing reduced below 500 feet in some locations. The fog completely dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Bakersfield. Web cameras indicated visibility below 500 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mixing ahead of an incoming trough resulted in mainly clear skies across the San Joaquin Valley during the morning of January 10. With light winds also prevailing over the lower elevations, areas of dense fog formed near sunrise in portions of the San Joaquin Valley, most noticeably along the SR 99 corridor north of Fresno where travel was impacted by visibilities below 500 feet in places. The fog prevailed through late morning before mixing  out.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Atwater, Merced and Madera.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold upper low pressure system pushed into the Pacific Northwest on January 6 then dropped southeast into the Great Basin by the morning of January 7, A cold front that accompanied this system crossed central California during the evening of January 6 bringing a period of light to moderate precipitation and strong winds to the area. Several stations in the mountains and deserts of Kern County measured gusts exceeding 45 mph with a few stations exceeding 70 mph. Precipitation amounts were generally a quarter to a half inch from Fresno County northward and a tenth to a quarter inch further south. Elevations above 6000 feet generally picked up between 5  to 10 inches of new snowfall with a few locations in the south end of the Sierra Nevada picking up 12 inches or more. The snow level lowered to 2500 feet before the precipitation ended during the morning of January 7 with several locations in the Sierra foothills and Tehachapi Mountains picking up between 1 and 3 inches of new snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Southern California Edison station at Tehachapi East Valley measured a peak wind gust of 64 mph.

CZ_NAME: SOUTH END OF THE UPPER SIERRA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold upper low pressure system pushed into the Pacific Northwest on January 6 then dropped southeast into the Great Basin by the morning of January 7, A cold front that accompanied this system crossed central California during the evening of January 6 bringing a period of light to moderate precipitation and strong winds to the area. Several stations in the mountains and deserts of Kern County measured gusts exceeding 45 mph with a few stations exceeding 70 mph. Precipitation amounts were generally a quarter to a half inch from Fresno County northward and a tenth to a quarter inch further south. Elevations above 6000 feet generally picked up between 5  to 10 inches of new snowfall with a few locations in the south end of the Sierra Nevada picking up 12 inches or more. The snow level lowered to 2500 feet before the precipitation ended during the morning of January 7 with several locations in the Sierra foothills and Tehachapi Mountains picking up between 1 and 3 inches of new snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bear Peak RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 84 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold upper trough moved across central California during the evening of January 10 and the early morning of January 11. This system brought another half inch to an inch of liquid precipitation to the Sierra Nevada and adjacent foothills north of Kings Canyon with many locations picking up 5 to 10 inches of new snow with a few SNOTELs estimating a foot of new snowfall. Areas further south in the Sierra Nevada and much of the Tehachapi Mountains picked up between a quarter and a half inch while much of the San Joaquin Valley received between a tenth and a quarter inch of rainfall. This system also produced a period of strong wind gusts with several stations in the Tehachapi area and the Mojave Deserts slopes measuring gusts exceeding 50 mph and a few low impact indicator sites reporting gusts exceeding 75 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Poison Ridge SNOTEL (9688 feet) picked up an estimated 12 inches of new snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a tree down on SR 99 south of Ave 48.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold and dry airmass settled in over the San Joaquin Valley behind the winter storm which moved to the east of the area on January 11. With clear skies, light winds and inversion conditions, temperatures dropped below the freezing mark across most of the San Joaquin Valley during the morning on January 12. Increasing clouds spread southward into the valley during the morning of January 13 which kept minimum temperatures above the freezing mark across the central San Joaquin Valley. Portions of the south valley dropped below the freezing mark again during the morning of January 13 as skies remained mainly clear until late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 27 and 31 degrees on January 12.

CZ_NAME: SOUTH END OF THE UPPER SIERRA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system that moved across northern California during the evening of January 16 and the early morning of January 17 brought some light precipitation to the area with much of the Sierra Nevada picking up between a quarter and a half inch of liquid precipitation with the snow level near 7000 feet. Several SNOTELs picked up an estimated 3 to 6 inches of new snowfall. Most of the central San Joaquin Valley picked up between a tenth and a quarter inch of rain while the south valley and the Kern County Mountains and Deserts generally had a tenth of an inch or less. This system also produced a brief period of strong wind gusts in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts with several stations reporting gusts exceeding 40 mph and a few locations measuring gusts exceeding 55 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bear Peak RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 75 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure moved into central California on January 17 which resulted in clearing skies and light winds over the area by the evening. With low level moisture present in the San Joaquin Valley due to recent rainfall, dense fog formed overnight and continued through the late morning hours of January 18 until it lifted into a low cloud deck. The fog was responsible for a 6 vehicle accident near Chowchilla which resulted in one fatality and several injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Atwater, Merced and Madera. Several webcams showed visibility below 1000 feet. A 6 vehicle accident with three tractor trailers and three cars occurred at 557 PST on Westbound SR 152 at Road 9. The accident resulted in one fatality and several serious injuries. Visibility was below 1000 feet during the time of the accident.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Some patches of dense fog formed toward daybreak in the central portion of the San Joaquin Valley during the morning of February 16 where skies had cleared out. The fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford.

CZ_NAME: SOUTH END OF THE UPPER SIERRA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system that moved across northern California during the evening of January 16 and the early morning of January 17 brought some light precipitation to the area with much of the Sierra Nevada picking up between a quarter and a half inch of liquid precipitation with the snow level near 7000 feet. Several SNOTELs picked up an estimated 3 to 6 inches of new snowfall. Most of the central San Joaquin Valley picked up between a tenth and a quarter inch of rain while the south valley and the Kern County Mountains and Deserts generally had a tenth of an inch or less. This system also produced a brief period of strong wind gusts in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts with several stations reporting gusts exceeding 40 mph and a few locations measuring gusts exceeding 55 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Walker Pass RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper trough dropped out of the Gulf of Alaska on February 29 and had deepened off the Pacific Northwest coast on March 1 spreading widespread precipitation as far south a central California. The trough then slowly moved east across the Pacific Northwest on March 2 and 3 before moving east of the region on March 4. This system brought moderate to heavy precipitation to the Sierra Nevada which picked up between 2 and 4 inches of liquid precipitation north of Kings Canyon and 1 to 2 inches further south. The precipitation fell as snow above 5000 feet for the duration of the event and produced 2 to 4 feet on new snowfall north of Kings Canyon and 1.5 to 3 feet of snow further south. This system also produced a half inch to an inch of rainfall in Merced County and a quarter to half inch across most of the remainder of the San Joaquin Valley. Most of the Kern County Mountains and Deserts picked up 1 to 2 tenths of an inch of rainfall. In addition to the precipitation, strong winds also accompanied this system and combined with the snow to produce near blizzard conditions over the Sierra Nevada north of Kings Canyon between the morning of March 1 and the morning of March 3. Scattered thunderstorms also broke out during the afternoons of March 1 and March 2 over parts of the San Joaquin Valley. While the thunderstorms were not heavy rain producers, several funnel clouds were observed and one cell produced a weak tornado in northeast Madera during the afternoon of March 1. In addition to the precipitation, several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts measured wind gusts exceeding 45 mph between the evening of March 2 and the early morning of March 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The co-op station 4SSW Ridgecrest measured a peak wind gust of 59 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved northeast from the Mid-Atlantic Region to southern New England during the night of January 9, 2024 into the early morning hours of January 10, 2024. Its center passed just north of the region during this period. The pressure gradient tightened as the center of the storm approached, producing high winds over Southeastern New York during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple occurrences of downed trees were reported. The Department of Highways reported a downed tree in Orangeburg, NY on the southbound Palisades Interstate Parkway at West Orangeburg Road at 1120 PM Local Standard Time. A trained spotter reported that the local fire department responded to a tree down on a house on Roosevelt Street in Tappan, NY at 1100 PM Local Standard Time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved northeast from the Mid-Atlantic Region to southern New England during the night of January 9, 2024 into the early morning hours of January 10, 2024. Its center passed just north of the region during this period. The pressure gradient tightened as the center of the storm approached, producing high winds over Southeastern New York during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Department of Highways reported multiple instances of downed trees. A downed tree closed all lanes of Route 9 in both directions in at Scarborough Road in Briarcliff Manor, NY at 1007 PM Local Standard Time. Also in Briarcliff Manor, a downed tree caused a road closure of Route 9A in both directions at Parkway Road at 1028 Local Standard Time. Additionally, a downed tree caused a road closure of Route 129 in both directions at Saw Mill Road in Yorktown Heights, NY at 1119 PM Local Standard time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large low pressure system impacted the area late on January 9th and into the 10th with long duration persistent moderate to heavy rainfall. In addition to widespread river flooding, some localized areas of flash flooding occurred as the heaviest rainfall associated with convection moved through. Precipitable water values of 1.2-1.4 inches were record levels for early January. The anomalous moisture and heavy rainfall resulted in a widespread 2 - 4 inches of rainfall, much of it occurring over a several hour timeframe before the cold frontal passage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flower Road near Forest Road Elementary school closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an Arctic air mass moved south through Louisiana, light to moderate precipitation was quick to freeze as it fell through the cold surface air. Locations in northeast Louisiana to the north of Interstate 20 received over one quarter to one half inch of accumulating sleet, and the Oak Grove area measured up to 2 inches of mostly sleet. Some light snow and freezing rain fell as well. Area roads were impacted by slick conditions due to the glaze of ice and accumulated sleet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Accumulations of sleet and light freezing rain fell across the parish, with sleet totals of up to 0.7 inches in Lake Providence. Area roads were covered by sleet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an Arctic air mass moved south through Mississippi, light to moderate precipitation was quick to freeze as it fell through the cold surface air. Although light accumulations of freezing rain, and sleet fell across much of the state of Mississippi, more significant accumulations of sleet over one half inch fell primarily north and west of the Natchez Trace corridor. Accumulations of 2 to 3 inches of sleet were measured in the Greenville to Cleveland areas. Area roads were impacted by slick conditions due to the glaze of ice and accumulated sleet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Accumulations of sleet, light snow, light freezing rain fell across the county, with 3 inch accumulations of mostly sleet in Cleveland. Area roads were covered by sleet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an Arctic air mass moved south through Mississippi, light to moderate precipitation was quick to freeze as it fell through the cold surface air. Although light accumulations of freezing rain, and sleet fell across much of the state of Mississippi, more significant accumulations of sleet over one half inch fell primarily north and west of the Natchez Trace corridor. Accumulations of 2 to 3 inches of sleet were measured in the Greenville to Cleveland areas. Area roads were impacted by slick conditions due to the glaze of ice and accumulated sleet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Accumulations of 0.8 inches of sleet fell across the county, but light snow and freezing rain also fell. Area roads were covered by the sleet and caused a multi-vehicle accident near Davis Wade Stadium.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture increased over the area by a fast moving clipper system on January 1st which allowed dense freezing fog to form during the morning of January 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the Glasgow Airport ASOS site (KGGW), intermittent visibilities of a quarter mile or less was recorded for about 10 hours from the late night of the 1st to the mid morning of the 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Nor'easter passed offshore of southern New England bringing widespread heavy rainfall, high elevation snow and sleet, as well as strong winds to the region. There was minor flooding on some rivers as well as minor to moderate coastal flooding along the east coast of MA. This was a late season snow storm with very elevation dependent snowfall totals from 0 to over 8 inches. Wind damage was sporadic and mostly minor, with over 25,000 power outages reported in western MA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Vineyard Haven at 7:13 AM EDT Seaview Ave and Beach Rd were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper disturbances moving across a cold and unstable air mass generated moderate to locally heavy lake effect snow across the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 27th into the morning of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a Facebook report at Allouez of 18 inches of lake effect snow over an approximate 30-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A probable hypothermia death was reported by the Milwaukee County Medical Examiner's Office. A man was found deceased in an unheated home.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A probable hypothermia death was reported by the Milwaukee County Medical Examiner's Office. A man was found deceased in an unheated home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The coldest Arctic air mass in many years settled into the region with widespread temperatures of 20 to 40 degrees below zero and wind chills measuring between 40 and 70 degrees below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the Bluff Creek RAWS site (BLUM8), temperatures in the teens to 40s below zero and breezy winds created intermittent periods of wind chills of 40 degrees below zero or colder from the night of the 11th to the morning of the 15th. The peak wind chill of 61 degrees below zero was recorded at 3:44 AM on the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the late afternoon hours of March 12th, a supercell developed over the Lee's Summit/Greenwood area, dropping golf ball or larger hail across portions of Greenwood, Lone Jack, and up toward Oak Grove. Storms continued into the late evening hours, with a total of 21 severe thunderstorm warnings issued and 27 total local storm reports for severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail just southeast of Cowgill.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the late afternoon hours of March 12th, a supercell developed over the Lee's Summit/Greenwood area, dropping golf ball or larger hail across portions of Greenwood, Lone Jack, and up toward Oak Grove. Storms continued into the late evening hours, with a total of 21 severe thunderstorm warnings issued and 27 total local storm reports for severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail in Oak Grove.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The coldest Arctic air mass in many years settled into the region with widespread temperatures of 20 to 40 degrees below zero and wind chills measuring between 40 and 70 degrees below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: For multiple sites across Dawson County, temperatures in the teens to 30s below zero and breezy winds created intermittent periods of wind chills of 40 degrees below zero or colder beginning on the early morning of the 12th and lasting as long as the morning of the 16th. The peak wind chill of 67 degrees below zero was recorded at 7:45 AM on the 13th at the Lindsay Divide MT-200 DOT site (MTLND).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The coldest Arctic air mass in many years settled into the region with widespread temperatures of 20 to 40 degrees below zero and wind chills measuring between 40 and 70 degrees below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: For multiple sites across the Little Rocky Mountains, temperatures in the teens to 30s below zero and breezy winds created intermittent periods of wind chills of 40 degrees below zero or colder from the evening of the 11th into the morning of the 15th. The peak wind chill of 58 degrees below zero was recorded at 8:00 AM, 7:15 PM to 7:30 PM on the 12th, and 12:00 AM to 12:15 AM on the 13th at the Hays MT-66 DOT site (MTHAY), at 7:41 AM on the 13th at the Manning Corral RAWS site (MCDM8), and at 2:00 PM and 8:30 PM on the 12th at the Malta South US-191 DOT site (MTMAL).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The coldest Arctic air mass in many years settled into the region with widespread temperatures of 20 to 40 degrees below zero and wind chills measuring between 40 and 70 degrees below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: For multiple sites across Western Roosevelt County, temperatures in the teens to 30s below zero and breezy winds created intermittent periods of wind chills of 40 degrees below zero or colder from the night of the 11th into the morning of the 16th. The peak wind chill of 70 degrees below zero was recorded from 7:30 AM to 7:45 AM on the 13th at the McDonald's MT-13 DOT site (MTMCD).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific Storm moved into the region bringing heavy snow to the Little Rocky Mountains and Petroleum County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured 5.5 inches of snow in Zortman.  Times are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front brought a round of strong storms through southern New England. Training storms moving over New Bedford caused flash flooding in addition to Providence, Rhode Island.  Earlier in the day it caused wind damage in Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In New Bedford, Rt 18 was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Nor'easter passed offshore of southern New England bringing widespread heavy rainfall, high elevation snow and sleet, as well as strong winds to the region. There was minor flooding on some rivers as well as minor to moderate coastal flooding along the east coast of MA. This was a late season snow storm with very elevation dependent snowfall totals from 0 to over 8 inches. Wind damage was sporadic and mostly minor, with over 25,000 power outages reported in western MA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Cohasset at 7:04 AM EDT Margin St at Howard Gleason Rd was flooded and closed. In Hingham at 7:10 AM EDT Kilby St at Rockland St was closed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One half inch of sleet fell in the Bastrop area, but greater amounts fell in northern portions of the parish. Area roads were covered by sleet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This comparatively weaker winter storm opened up another active weather pattern that tracked through the Sierra and W.Nevada late in the evening February 17-18. This storm brought higher elevation snowfall that was heavy at times above 7000 feet. This storm also included the possibility of an additional several feet of snowfall.  Mainly spillover rainfall fell over lower western Nevada valleys that included periods of gusty winds as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station (MTH03-MAMMOTH) located 1.7 mi S of Mammoth Mountain, CA reported a peak wind gust of 112 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Additional snow chances continued mid-week, mostly for the northern Sierra. Conditions continued to be treacherous over the Sierra overnight on the 4th with breezy winds, snow, and blowing snow. Conditions briefly improved over the Sierra the morning through the afternoon of the 5th with additional snow shower chances continuing thereafter, especially for the Sierra north of US-50.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station (MTH15-Chair 9 Tower 11) located 1.0 mi E of Mammoth Mountain Ski resort reported a peak wind gust of 62 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Additional snow chances continued mid-week, mostly for the northern Sierra. Conditions continued to be treacherous over the Sierra overnight on the 4th with breezy winds, snow, and blowing snow. Conditions briefly improved over the Sierra the morning through the afternoon of the 5th with additional snow shower chances continuing thereafter, especially for the Sierra north of US-50.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public located the Mount Rose Ski Base, a trained spotter (WA-12) located 1.0 mi NNW of Incline Village, and the public at the Diamond Peak Ski Base, NV, reported 24 hour storm snowfall totals of 12.0 inches, 9.0 inches, and 7 inches respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This first of two impactful weather systems arrived in the area during afternoon on the 27th with the passage of a cold front. Gusty to strong winds across the region as well as valley rain and mountain snow accompanied this initial storm system through the morning of the 28th. Following a brief, a second impactful system brought additional precipitation chances for mountain snow and valley rain that started overnight on the 29th that continued through the Easter weekend.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public located at Homewood Mountain Ski Base, CA, and 4.0 mi NW of Truckee, CA, reported 24 hour snowfall amounts of 10.0 inches and 6.0 inches respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding at Tualatin River at Farmington, Pudding River at Aurora, and Luckiamute River near Suver.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain brought minor flooding to Tualatin River at Farmington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding at Tualatin River at Farmington, Pudding River at Aurora, and Luckiamute River near Suver.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused minor flooding along the Pudding River near Aurora.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of fronts brought heavy snow to the Cascades.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 8 and 16 inches of snow fell for elevations above 2000 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of fronts brought heavy snow to the Cascades.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 16 and 24 inches of snow fell for elevations above 2500-3000 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog developed in the San Joaquin Valley and Tehachapi Mountains by late evening on January 1. The dense fog became more prevalent across the San Joaquin  Valley overnight and remained persistent in the south end of the valley until late morning on January 2. The fog also contributed to a serious accident on SR 99 during the late morning south of  Bakersfield which injured a motorist. The fog lifted into a low cloud deck by midday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Merced and Madera.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Some patches of dense fog formed in the south San Joaquin Valley during the morning of January 6. This resulted in impacts to travel along the SR 198 corridor between Visalia and Hanford and also along Interstate 5 west of Bakersfield where a 35 vehicle accident  took place and resulted in two fatalities. The fog dissipated by late morning as strong mixing took place ahead of an incoming storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Bakersfield television station reported a 35 vehicle accident (18 of the vehicles were  tractor trailers) on southbound Interstate 5 just north of the SR 223 exchange around 730 PST. The accident resulted in two fatalities and 9 injuries. Visibility was below 500 feet at the time of the accident.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold and dry airmass settled over central California behind the departed storm on January 7. This resulted in sub-freezing overnight temperatures across much of the San Joaquin Valley on the morning of January 8 and again on the morning of January 9.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 28 and 31 degrees on January 8 and January 9.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold and dry airmass settled over central California behind the departed storm on January 7. This resulted in sub-freezing overnight temperatures across much of the San Joaquin Valley on the morning of January 8 and again on the morning of January 9.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 28 and 31 degrees on January 8 and January 9.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold and dry airmass settled over central California behind the departed storm on January 7. This resulted in sub-freezing overnight temperatures across much of the San Joaquin Valley on the morning of January 8 and again on the morning of January 9.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 28 and 31 degrees on January 8 and January 9.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the departure of a storm which brought light to moderate precipitation to the  area between the morning of January 20 and the early afternoon of January 21, a second system moved through central California between the late evening of January 21 and the afternoon of January 22. This system produced three quarters to an inch and a half of rainfall over Merced County and a half inch to an inch of liquid precipitation the the Sierra Nevada with the snow level around 8000 feet. Much of the remainder of the San Joaquin Valley and the Tehachapi Mountains picked up between a half inch and an inch of rainfall which produced some localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several SNOTEL stations picked up an estimated 4 to 8 inches of new snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strengthening high pressure over central California brought clearing skies and light winds to the area during the morning of January 28. This allowed for areas of dense fog to form along the SR 99 corridor and traffic was impacted between Merced and Bakersfield by sunrise, with visibility be0ing reduced below 500 feet in some locations. The fog completely dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in west Fresno. Web cameras indicated visibility below 500 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog formed along the Interstate 5 corridor in Fresno and Kings Counties during the early morning of January 25, reducing visibility to a few hundred feet in some spots. The fog dissipated shortly after sunrise.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Web cameras indicated visibility below 1000 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold upper low pressure system pushed into the Pacific Northwest on January 6 then dropped southeast into the Great Basin by the morning of January 7, A cold front that accompanied this system crossed central California during the evening of January 6 bringing a period of light to moderate precipitation and strong winds to the area. Several stations in the mountains and deserts of Kern County measured gusts exceeding 45 mph with a few stations exceeding 70 mph. Precipitation amounts were generally a quarter to a half inch from Fresno County northward and a tenth to a quarter inch further south. Elevations above 6000 feet generally picked up between 5  to 10 inches of new snowfall with a few locations in the south end of the Sierra Nevada picking up 12 inches or more. The snow level lowered to 2500 feet before the precipitation ended during the morning of January 7 with several locations in the Sierra foothills and Tehachapi Mountains picking up between 1 and 3 inches of new snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Southern California Edison station at Paradise Cove measured a peak wind gust of 62 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold upper trough moved across central California during the evening of January 10 and the early morning of January 11. This system brought another half inch to an inch of liquid precipitation to the Sierra Nevada and adjacent foothills north of Kings Canyon with many locations picking up 5 to 10 inches of new snow with a few SNOTELs estimating a foot of new snowfall. Areas further south in the Sierra Nevada and much of the Tehachapi Mountains picked up between a quarter and a half inch while much of the San Joaquin Valley received between a tenth and a quarter inch of rainfall. This system also produced a period of strong wind gusts with several stations in the Tehachapi area and the Mojave Deserts slopes measuring gusts exceeding 50 mph and a few low impact indicator sites reporting gusts exceeding 75 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Southern California Edison station at Walker Basin Ox Court measured a peak wind gust of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold and dry airmass settled in over the San Joaquin Valley behind the winter storm which moved to the east of the area on January 11. With clear skies, light winds and inversion conditions, temperatures dropped below the freezing mark across most of the San Joaquin Valley during the morning on January 12. Increasing clouds spread southward into the valley during the morning of January 13 which kept minimum temperatures above the freezing mark across the central San Joaquin Valley. Portions of the south valley dropped below the freezing mark again during the morning of January 13 as skies remained mainly clear until late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 27 and 31 degrees on January 12.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE OF FRESNO AND KINGS COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The high pressure center which brought record high temperatures to much of the area on January 29 shifted eastward on January 30. Unseasonably warm temperatures prevailed again over the area, but with a weaker inversion over the valley in the San Joaquin Valley in the morning the fog was not as prevalent as it was during the previous day and only patches of dense fog were observed. The fog dissipated shortly after sunrise.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Lemoore.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system approached central California on January 31. Gusty southerly winds ahead of this system resulted in some tress being downed and several reports of gusts exceeding 40 mph. Many wind prone locations in the higher elevations measured gusts exceeding 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a large tree down blocking both lanes of SR 184 at the Panama Rd. crossing.

CZ_NAME: YOSEMITE NP OUTSIDE OF THE VALLEY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system that moved through the Pacific Northwest on January 13 brought precipitation as far south as central California between the early morning of January 13 and the morning of January 14. While precipitation amounts were fairly light, the system did produce 4 to 8 inches of snow above 7000 feet in the Yosemite Park area. Several stations further south picked up an estimated 1 to 4 inches of snowfall above 7000 feet. Rainfall amounts were generally a tenth of an inch or less in the San Joaquin Valley and West Side Hills and a tenth to a quarter inch in the Sierra Nevada and adjacent foothills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several SNOTEL's picked up an estimated 4 to 8 inches of new snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog formed in the south San Joaquin Valley and the valley facing slopes of the Tehachapi Mountains during the evening of January 15 lowering visibility in some locations to be low a quarter mile. Enough mixing took place during the early morning of January 16 for the fog to lift into a low cloud deck which minimized travel impacts by the morning commute.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper trough dropped out of the Gulf of Alaska on February 29 and had deepened off the Pacific Northwest coast on March 1 spreading widespread precipitation as far south a central California. The trough then slowly moved east across the Pacific Northwest on March 2 and 3 before moving east of the region on March 4. This system brought moderate to heavy precipitation to the Sierra Nevada which picked up between 2 and 4 inches of liquid precipitation north of Kings Canyon and 1 to 2 inches further south. The precipitation fell as snow above 5000 feet for the duration of the event and produced 2 to 4 feet on new snowfall north of Kings Canyon and 1.5 to 3 feet of snow further south. This system also produced a half inch to an inch of rainfall in Merced County and a quarter to half inch across most of the remainder of the San Joaquin Valley. Most of the Kern County Mountains and Deserts picked up 1 to 2 tenths of an inch of rainfall. In addition to the precipitation, strong winds also accompanied this system and combined with the snow to produce near blizzard conditions over the Sierra Nevada north of Kings Canyon between the morning of March 1 and the morning of March 3. Scattered thunderstorms also broke out during the afternoons of March 1 and March 2 over parts of the San Joaquin Valley. While the thunderstorms were not heavy rain producers, several funnel clouds were observed and one cell produced a weak tornado in northeast Madera during the afternoon of March 1. In addition to the precipitation, several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts measured wind gusts exceeding 45 mph between the evening of March 2 and the early morning of March 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter observed a funnel cloud in northeast Madera.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lifting warm front in conjunction with an approaching cold front from the northwest creating a recipe for convective severe weather as severe thunderstorms developed late in the evening of January 11th across central and northeast Arkansas leading to spotty wind damage and hail reports. However, transitioning into the early morning hours of the 12th, a line of storms swept across southern Arkansas producing damaging straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS station at Stuttgart Municipal Airport measured a thunderstorm wind gust of 72 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated a thunderstorm wind gust of 60 mph in the community of Perryville, AR.

CZ_NAME: NORTHWESTERN LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS INCLUDING THE INTERSTATE 5 CORRIDOR
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second, late season, storm rolled across Southwestern California. This storm brought strong north to northeast winds as well as strong thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds  and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north to northeast winds were observed across the Interstate 5 Corridor in the Northwest Los Angeles County Mountains. The Sandberg ASOS reported gusts up to 62 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second, late season, storm rolled across Southwestern California. This storm brought strong north to northeast winds as well as strong thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds  and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north to northeast winds were observed across the western range of the Santa Monica Mountains. Some peak gusts include: Deer Creek Canyon (gust 68 MPH), Rancho Del Cielo (gust 59 MPH) and Corral Canyon (gust 58 MPH).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough followed by amplified W/NW flow aloft brought heavy snow to the Cascades, eastern foothills, and the eastern mountains between the 16th and 19th of January.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained weather spotter recorded 7 inches of storm total snowfall ending at 12:38 PM on the 18th 9 miles SE of Cle Elum. Another weather spotter also recorded 7 inches of storm total snow at 3:00 PM on the 18th 8 miles NNW of Ellensburg.

CZ_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY SAN GABRIEL VALLEY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late-season, storm brought significant rainfall to the area along with strong thunderstorms. Rainfall totals across the area ranged from 0.50 to 1.50 inches across San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties to 1 to 2 inches across Ventura and Los Angeles counties. Unstable air, associated with the storm, brought scattered strong thunderstorms to the area, producing gusty winds, large hail and even some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weather spotter in the Monrovia area reported thunderstorm winds with estimated gusts of 50 MPH. The winds knocked down numerous tree branches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-hitting storm system produced strong winds over the mountains and desert slopes as well as mountain snow on January 7. Chain controls were in effect across the San Bernardino County Mountains through the late morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds impacted the San Gorgonio Pass near Banning from the evening of January 6 through the morning on January 7. Widespread wind gusts over 35 mph were reported in this area, with a number of gusts over 50 knots. The following are the strongest wind reports in this zone:||Whitewater (SCE1015): 63 mph|Whitewater RAWS: 63 mph|Whitewater Cyn (SCE581): 61 mph|Snowcreek Cyn (SCE577): 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper trough dropped out of the Gulf of Alaska on February 29 and had deepened off the Pacific Northwest coast on March 1 spreading widespread precipitation as far south a central California. The trough then slowly moved east across the Pacific Northwest on March 2 and 3 before moving east of the region on March 4. This system brought moderate to heavy precipitation to the Sierra Nevada which picked up between 2 and 4 inches of liquid precipitation north of Kings Canyon and 1 to 2 inches further south. The precipitation fell as snow above 5000 feet for the duration of the event and produced 2 to 4 feet on new snowfall north of Kings Canyon and 1.5 to 3 feet of snow further south. This system also produced a half inch to an inch of rainfall in Merced County and a quarter to half inch across most of the remainder of the San Joaquin Valley. Most of the Kern County Mountains and Deserts picked up 1 to 2 tenths of an inch of rainfall. In addition to the precipitation, strong winds also accompanied this system and combined with the snow to produce near blizzard conditions over the Sierra Nevada north of Kings Canyon between the morning of March 1 and the morning of March 3. Scattered thunderstorms also broke out during the afternoons of March 1 and March 2 over parts of the San Joaquin Valley. While the thunderstorms were not heavy rain producers, several funnel clouds were observed and one cell produced a weak tornado in northeast Madera during the afternoon of March 1. In addition to the precipitation, several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts measured wind gusts exceeding 45 mph between the evening of March 2 and the early morning of March 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud which had been previously reported by a trained spotter spawned a small tornado in northeast Madera which was on the ground for around 5 minutes and moved eastward around a half mile. The tornado damaged some portable classrooms at Berenda Elementary School in Madera.

However, transitioning into the early morning hours of the 12th, a line of storms swept across southern Arkansas producing damaging straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Pine Bluff/Grider Field Airport measured a thunderstorm wind gust of 74 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-hitting storm system produced strong winds over the mountains and desert slopes as well as mountain snow on January 7. Chain controls were in effect across the San Bernardino County Mountains through the late morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow fell through the overnight hours on January 7, resulting in 1-3 inches of accumulations in the Riverside County Mountains and SR 243.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving storm system produced strong winds across much of Southern California January 10-11, with the highest winds recorded in the mountains and along the desert slopes the morning of January 11. Scattered showers occurred mainly across San Diego County, and several inches of snow were recorded in the San Bernardino and Riverside County Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds impacted the San Bernardino County Mountains from the afternoon of January 10 through the late morning hours on January 11. The strongest winds occurred from early to mid-morning on January 11. The following are the strongest winds recorded across the zone:||Burns Canyon: 70 MPH (6284')|Marshall Peak (SDHGPA): 68 MPH (3973')|Big Bear Airport: 62 MPH (6760')|Running Springs: 59 MPH (5445').||A downed tree blocked a lane at Pleasant Drive and Rim of the World SR-18.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper low-pressure system moved east across Kansas and into Missouri overnight on January 8th and into the morning hours of January 9th, placing north central Kansas in the left exit region of an upper jet stream which increased lift over the area. Moisture was advected into the area from a low-level jet with a surface low over Texas, Oklahoma, and then southern Missouri. Snow began during the day on January 8th across the local area and started to decrease from west to east after midnight on January 9th and ended across the area during the day on the 9th. Widespread snow totals of 4-8 inches, with locally higher amounts of 9-12 inches, were reported across the area. Winds started to increase across the region during the evening on January 8th and into the overnight hours on January 9th which resulted in blizzard conditions. Northerly wind gusts of 40-45 MPH were common, with a few gusts over 50 MPH reported. Temperatures dropped into the teens during the overnight period with wind chill values dropping into the negative single digits. Winds began to decrease from west to east during the day on January 9th. ||The heavy snow and strong winds resulted in near white-out to blizzard conditions, resulting in widespread road closures, as well as school and event cancellations. A light wintry mix was reported ahead of the main snow event, also contributing to slick conditions across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 5 to 9 inches across the county. Highest totals included 8.5 inches, reported by NWS Cooperative Observer located in Lebanon, and 7.0 inches, reported by the NWS Cooperative Observer located in Smith Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough moved from over the Rocky Mountains to the Central Plains to the Midwest. Shortwave troughs associated with the upper trough moved over Nebraska and Kansas. An Arctic cold front began moving across central and south central Nebraska during the early morning hours of January 11th. Snow started to develop and move across the area during the late morning and early afternoon hours of January 11th. The snow gradually ended from west to east beginning the morning of January 12th and continued into the afternoon hours. ||An upper trough over Canada and Montana plunged southward and moved over the Central Plains by the morning of January 13th. This trough brought a reinforcing shot of colder air along with stronger northerly winds gusting to 30 to 40 mph which continued on through the day on the 13th. Additional lift from this upper trough resulted in light snow during the night of January 12th and into the morning of January 13th. This resulted in additional blowing and drifting snow, and hazardous travel due to near-blizzard conditions.||This heavy snow event resulted in widespread road closures and school/activity cancellations, and even several business closures. The heaviest snow affected areas mainly along/east of Highway 281 and along/north of Highway 6, where totals reached 6-12 inches in spots. Amounts tapered off to closer to an inch for areas further west and south. The brunt of accumulating snow fell from mid-late afternoon on the 11th through around midday on the 12th, with north-northwest winds gusting to around 30-35 MPH. Grand Island tied the liquid equivalent precipitation and snowfall records. Hastings set new records for liquid equivalent precipitation, snowfall, and cold high temperature.||Along with county and rural roads, Highways 281, 4, 136, 78, 28, and 9 were considered impassable or closed outright due to near-blizzard conditions. While Interstate 80 was not closed, travel was discouraged by officials. Multiple counties pulled their plows off the roads during the worst of the conditions due to safety concerns. Several rescues were done on the morning of the 13th due to people being trapped in vehicles out in open areas. Due to the cumulative impacts across central and eastern Nebraska from the winter storm on January 8-9th and this one, the Governor of Nebraska declared a state of emergency, and the Nebraska Emergency Management Agency activated its Emergency Operations Center to coordinate efforts. Over the week, Nebraska Department of Transportation put in at least 35,000 man-hours, and even received some support from South Dakota. The Nebraska State Patrol responded to more than 1,200 stranded vehicles between the two storms across the region, close to 100 crashes, and over 400 motorist assists. Bitterly cold air and continued gusty winds brought dangerous wind chill values of -30 to -45 to the entire region for several days following the departure of this storm system.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts of 2 to 5 inches fell across the county. A total of 4.0 inches was measured by a CoCoRaHS observer located six miles southwest of Lexington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes produced brief strong north wind gusts to 58 mph at the Houghton County Airport on the morning of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: North winds briefly gusted to 58 mph at the Houghton County Airport ASOS around 7 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the late afternoon hours of March 12th, a supercell developed over the Lee's Summit/Greenwood area, dropping golf ball or larger hail across portions of Greenwood, Lone Jack, and up toward Oak Grove. Storms continued into the late evening hours, with a total of 21 severe thunderstorm warnings issued and 27 total local storm reports for severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Photos of golf ball sized hail just east of Greenwood about 1 mile east of Ranson Road.

CZ_NAME: MANITOU ISLAND TO MARQUETTE MI BEYOND 5NM FROM SHORE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes generated brief storm force north wind gusts over portions of central Lake Superior during the early morning of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: North storm force wind gusts to 55 mph were briefly recorded at the Granite Island Light station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved southeast through the region during the morning hours of the 28th.  The thunderstorms produce strong and gusty winds at points along the line, with several reports of trees, power lines and minor structural damage reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was knocked down at 2903 Mulberry Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front moved through bringing cold air into northeast Montana, which |generated areas of fog during the night of January 2nd which lasted into the morning of January 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the Beach, ND airport ASOS site (K20U), visibility of a quarter mile or less was recorded for about 9 3/4 hours from early to mid morning on the 3rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Enough moisture remained around northeast Montana to generate another round of Dense Freezing Fog on the night of the 4th which lasted through the morning of the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the Malta Airport AWOS site (KM75), intermittent visibility of a quarter mile or less was recorded for about 5 1/4 hours from the night of the 4th to just after midnight on the 5th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was knocked down near the intersection of Gate 6 Road and 2nd Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an Arctic air mass moved south through Mississippi, light to moderate precipitation was quick to freeze as it fell through the cold surface air. Although light accumulations of freezing rain, and sleet fell across much of the state of Mississippi, more significant accumulations of sleet over one half inch fell primarily north and west of the Natchez Trace corridor. Accumulations of 2 to 3 inches of sleet were measured in the Greenville to Cleveland areas. Area roads were impacted by slick conditions due to the glaze of ice and accumulated sleet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Accumulations of up to one half inch of sleet fell across the county, but light snow and freezing rain also fell. Area roads were impacted by the sleet and glaze of ice.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an Arctic air mass moved south through Mississippi, light to moderate precipitation was quick to freeze as it fell through the cold surface air. Although light accumulations of freezing rain, and sleet fell across much of the state of Mississippi, more significant accumulations of sleet over one half inch fell primarily north and west of the Natchez Trace corridor. Accumulations of 2 to 3 inches of sleet were measured in the Greenville to Cleveland areas. Area roads were impacted by slick conditions due to the glaze of ice and accumulated sleet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light accumulations of freezing rain and sleet caused slick road conditions across the county, and a single car accident occurred on Interstate 59 near Exit 90 due to slick road conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A continuous period of below-freezing temperatures in the area began on the evening of January 14th and did not end until the afternoon of January 17th, and temperatures fell below freezing again the night of January 17th. Wind chills as low as 9 degrees were measured by the ASOS site KJAN at Jackson-Medgar Wiley Evers Airport. A 67-year old woman in the Cleary Heights area was found to have died of hypothermia.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail just southeast of Browning in far northern Linn County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The last round of freezing rain in the Columbia River Gorge as the arctic air mass retreated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulation of 0.25 to 0.75 inch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of May 1st, an upper-level trough was noted over the Rockies, with diffluent flow over the central Plains. At the surface, a zonal frontal boundary extended along the Kansas-Nebraska border. Over the course of the night, this boundary slowly lifted north as widespread thunderstorms developed across much of the central Plains and upper Midwest. At 2 AM, a line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved into the southwestern part of the OAX CWA (County Warning Area) producing wind gusts ranging from 50 to 65 miles per hour. These storms began to weaken as they moved east of US Highway 77.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 62 mph wind gust was measured at a personal weather station. There was another 55 mph wind gust measured at a separate but nearly collocated station at the same time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front pushed through a modestly unstable environment with MLCAPE up to 1500 J/kg. However, weak mid-level flow resulted in small hodographs and lesser shear, which limited storm organization and resulted in only a little marginally severe hail in a crowded storm environment.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind at Automated Surface Observing System site KSUX in Sergeant Bluff reached a peak gust of 58 mph.
