EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Skies cleared out overnight across the San Joaquin Valley during the early morning of January 1. This allowed for areas of dense fog to form by sunrise as winds remined light. The fog lifted into a low cloud deck by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Madera.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Skies cleared out overnight across the San Joaquin Valley during the early morning of January 1. This allowed for areas of dense fog to form by sunrise as winds remined light. The fog lifted into a low cloud deck by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Delano.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog developed in the San Joaquin Valley and Tehachapi Mountains by late evening on January 1. The dense fog became more prevalent across the San Joaquin  Valley overnight and remained persistent in the south end of the valley until late morning on January 2. The fog also contributed to a serious accident on SR 99 during the late morning south of  Bakersfield which injured a motorist. The fog lifted into a low cloud deck by midday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Bakersfield. California Highway Patrol reported a vehicle overturned on northbound SR 99 near The Union Ave. exchange south of Bakersfield at 1030 PST in visibility below a quarter of a mile. The driver of the vehicle was injured in the accident.

The fog also contributed to a serious accident on SR 99 during the late morning south of  Bakersfield which injured a motorist. The fog lifted into a low cloud deck by midday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Tehachapi.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mixing took place ahead of an incoming storm during the early morning of January 3 allowing for skies to clear out and some patches of dense fog to briefly form and impact travel along portions of SR 99. The fog mixed out by late morning as the storm moved into the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Bakersfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Skies cleared out over the San Joaquin valley during the evening of January 18 and areas of dense of formed overnight during the early morning of January 19. The fog dissipated by late morning as mixing took place ahead of an incoming storm system.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Skies cleared out over the San Joaquin valley during the evening of January 18 and areas of dense of formed overnight during the early morning of January 19. The fog dissipated by late morning as mixing took place ahead of an incoming storm system.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported visibility around 100 feet in fog along Interstate 5 south of the SR 58 exchange at 330 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak low pressure system moved through central California during the early morning of January 17 producing widespread light precipitation in the area. Skies cleared out behind this system and allowed for areas of dense fog to form near daybreak in the center portion of the San Joaquin Valley and in the Tehachapi area. The fog lifted by late morning except in the far south end of the valley and around Tehachapi where the fog hung around into the afternoon before lifting.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Tehachapi.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure moved into central California on January 17 which resulted in clearing skies and light winds over the area by the evening. With low level moisture present in the San Joaquin Valley due to recent rainfall, dense fog formed overnight and continued through the late morning hours of January 18 until it lifted into a low cloud deck. The fog was responsible for a 6 vehicle accident near Chowchilla which resulted in one fatality and several injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno. Several webcams showed visibility below 1000 feet.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE OF FRESNO AND KINGS COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold and dry airmass settled over central California behind the departed storm on January 7. This resulted in sub-freezing overnight temperatures across much of the San Joaquin Valley on the morning of January 8 and again on the morning of January 9.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 28 and 31 degrees on January 8 and January 9.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure remained over central California on January 29 bringing near record high  temperatures to much of our area. Clear skies and light winds during the early morning resulted in areas of dense fog forming in the San Joaquin Valley. The fog reduced visibility to a few hundred feet in some locations and was responsible for a two vehicle accident in southeast Fresno which resulted in two fatalities. The fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Web cameras indicated visibility below 500 feet.

CZ_NAME: SOUTH END OF THE UPPER SIERRA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold upper low pressure system pushed into the Pacific Northwest on January 6 then dropped southeast into the Great Basin by the morning of January 7, A cold front that accompanied this system crossed central California during the evening of January 6 bringing a period of light to moderate precipitation and strong winds to the area. Several stations in the mountains and deserts of Kern County measured gusts exceeding 45 mph with a few stations exceeding 70 mph. Precipitation amounts were generally a quarter to a half inch from Fresno County northward and a tenth to a quarter inch further south. Elevations above 6000 feet generally picked up between 5  to 10 inches of new snowfall with a few locations in the south end of the Sierra Nevada picking up 12 inches or more. The snow level lowered to 2500 feet before the precipitation ended during the morning of January 7 with several locations in the Sierra foothills and Tehachapi Mountains picking up between 1 and 3 inches of new snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Walker Pass RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure strengthened off the California coast overnight and pushed inland during the early morning of January 26. With mainly clear skies and light winds prevailing in the San Joaquin Valley, areas of dense fog formed in the central portion of the valley towards daybreak most noticeably along the SR 198 corridor between Visalia and Hanford and along SR 99 in Tulare. the fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Visalia. Web cameras indicated visibility below 500 feet.

CZ_NAME: YOSEMITE NP OUTSIDE OF THE VALLEY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the departure of a storm which brought light to moderate precipitation to the  area between the morning of January 20 and the early afternoon of January 21, a second system moved through central California between the late evening of January 21 and the afternoon of January 22. This system produced three quarters to an inch and a half of rainfall over Merced County and a half inch to an inch of liquid precipitation the the Sierra Nevada with the snow level around 8000 feet. Much of the remainder of the San Joaquin Valley and the Tehachapi Mountains picked up between a half inch and an inch of rainfall which produced some localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several SNOTEL stations picked up an estimated 4 to 8 inches of new snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold upper trough moved across central California during the evening of January 10 and the early morning of January 11. This system brought another half inch to an inch of liquid precipitation to the Sierra Nevada and adjacent foothills north of Kings Canyon with many locations picking up 5 to 10 inches of new snow with a few SNOTELs estimating a foot of new snowfall. Areas further south in the Sierra Nevada and much of the Tehachapi Mountains picked up between a quarter and a half inch while much of the San Joaquin Valley received between a tenth and a quarter inch of rainfall. This system also produced a period of strong wind gusts with several stations in the Tehachapi area and the Mojave Deserts slopes measuring gusts exceeding 50 mph and a few low impact indicator sites reporting gusts exceeding 75 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Southern California Edison station at Cottonwood Creek West measured a peak wind gust of 71 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system approached central California on January 31. Gusty southerly winds ahead of this system resulted in some tress being downed and several reports of gusts exceeding 40 mph. Many wind prone locations in the higher elevations measured gusts exceeding 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a large tree blocking the intersection of Rose Ave. and Robin Ave.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE OF FRESNO AND KINGS COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Skies cleared out in portions of the San Joaquin Valley during the morning of February 15 following the departure of a fast moving frontal system which had earlier moved through the area. Some patchy fog formed toward daybreak where skies had cleared out and winds had diminished. The fog completely dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Lemoore.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system approached central California on January 31. Gusty southerly winds ahead of this system resulted in some tress being downed and several reports of gusts exceeding 40 mph. Many wind prone locations in the higher elevations measured gusts exceeding 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The PG&E station at Beartrap Rd. measured a peak wind gust of 61 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system approached central California on January 31. Gusty southerly winds ahead of this system resulted in some tress being downed and several reports of gusts exceeding 40 mph. Many wind prone locations in the higher elevations measured gusts exceeding 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Southern California Edison station at Beartrap Rd. measured a peak wind gust of 70 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold and dry airmass settled in over the San Joaquin Valley behind the winter storm which moved to the east of the area on January 11. With clear skies, light winds and inversion conditions, temperatures dropped below the freezing mark across most of the San Joaquin Valley during the morning on January 12. Increasing clouds spread southward into the valley during the morning of January 13 which kept minimum temperatures above the freezing mark across the central San Joaquin Valley. Portions of the south valley dropped below the freezing mark again during the morning of January 13 as skies remained mainly clear until late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 27 and 31 degrees on January 12.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure remained over central California on January 29 bringing near record high  temperatures to much of our area. Clear skies and light winds during the early morning resulted in areas of dense fog forming in the San Joaquin Valley. The fog reduced visibility to a few hundred feet in some locations and was responsible for a two vehicle accident in southeast Fresno which resulted in two fatalities. The fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in west Fresno. Web cameras indicated visibility below 500 feet. At 743 PST a two vehicle accident occurred at the intersection of Chestnut Ave. and Annadale Ave. in southeast Fresno involving a pickup truck and a semi-truck. There were two fatalities as a result of the accident.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog formed in the south San Joaquin Valley and the valley facing slopes of the Tehachapi Mountains during the evening of January 15 lowering visibility in some locations to be low a quarter mile. Enough mixing took place during the early morning of January 16 for the fog to lift into a low cloud deck which minimized travel impacts by the morning commute.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Tehachapi.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system that moved across northern California during the evening of January 16 and the early morning of January 17 brought some light precipitation to the area with much of the Sierra Nevada picking up between a quarter and a half inch of liquid precipitation with the snow level near 7000 feet. Several SNOTELs picked up an estimated 3 to 6 inches of new snowfall. Most of the central San Joaquin Valley picked up between a tenth and a quarter inch of rain while the south valley and the Kern County Mountains and Deserts generally had a tenth of an inch or less. This system also produced a brief period of strong wind gusts in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts with several stations reporting gusts exceeding 40 mph and a few locations measuring gusts exceeding 55 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Southern California Edison station at Paradise Cove measured a peak wind gust of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lifting warm front in conjunction with an approaching cold front from the northwest creating a recipe for convective severe weather as severe thunderstorms developed late in the evening of January 11th across central and northeast Arkansas leading to spotty wind damage and hail reports. However, transitioning into the early morning hours of the 12th, a line of storms swept across southern Arkansas producing damaging straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were blown down near the community of Perryville, AR.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper trough dropped out of the Gulf of Alaska on February 29 and had deepened off the Pacific Northwest coast on March 1 spreading widespread precipitation as far south a central California. The trough then slowly moved east across the Pacific Northwest on March 2 and 3 before moving east of the region on March 4. This system brought moderate to heavy precipitation to the Sierra Nevada which picked up between 2 and 4 inches of liquid precipitation north of Kings Canyon and 1 to 2 inches further south. The precipitation fell as snow above 5000 feet for the duration of the event and produced 2 to 4 feet on new snowfall north of Kings Canyon and 1.5 to 3 feet of snow further south. This system also produced a half inch to an inch of rainfall in Merced County and a quarter to half inch across most of the remainder of the San Joaquin Valley. Most of the Kern County Mountains and Deserts picked up 1 to 2 tenths of an inch of rainfall. In addition to the precipitation, strong winds also accompanied this system and combined with the snow to produce near blizzard conditions over the Sierra Nevada north of Kings Canyon between the morning of March 1 and the morning of March 3. Scattered thunderstorms also broke out during the afternoons of March 1 and March 2 over parts of the San Joaquin Valley. While the thunderstorms were not heavy rain producers, several funnel clouds were observed and one cell produced a weak tornado in northeast Madera during the afternoon of March 1. In addition to the precipitation, several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts measured wind gusts exceeding 45 mph between the evening of March 2 and the early morning of March 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Southern California Edison station on Grapevine Canyon Rd. measured a peak wind gust of 63 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of disturbances moved across the area resulting in numerous flash flood events that resulted in the flooding of many homes, extensive high water rescues, and a flood-related fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding on Blackshear Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-hitting storm system produced strong winds over the mountains and desert slopes as well as mountain snow on January 7. Chain controls were in effect across the San Bernardino County Mountains through the late morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds impacted the High Desert from the evening of January 6 through the afternoon on January 7. Widespread wind gusts over 35 mph were reported in this area, with a number of gusts over 50 knots. The following are the strongest wind reports in this zone:||Lucerne Valley (SCE262): 63 mph|Lucerne Valley (SCE266): 61 mph|Lucerne Valley (SCE484): 61 mph|Cushenbury Springs (SCE269): 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-hitting storm system produced strong winds over the mountains and desert slopes as well as mountain snow on January 7. Chain controls were in effect across the San Bernardino County Mountains through the late morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow fell through the overnight hours on January 7, resulting in 2-4 inches of accumulations in the San Bernardino County Mountains. Chain controls were in effect for Highway 2, Highway 243, Highway 18, Highway 330, Highway 38 and Highway 189.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving storm system produced strong winds across much of Southern California January 10-11, with the highest winds recorded in the mountains and along the desert slopes the morning of January 11. Scattered showers occurred mainly across San Diego County, and several inches of snow were recorded in the San Bernardino and Riverside County Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds impacted the San Gorgonio Pass near Banning from the evening of January 10 through the late morning hours on January 11. The strongest winds occurred from early to mid-morning on January 11. The following are the strongest winds recorded across the zone:||Whitewater (SCE1015): 80 MPH (1681')|Whitewater RAWS: 70 MPH (2545')|Desert Hot Springs (SCE566): 64 MPH (1518')|Whitewater (SCE1289): 62 MPH (2192')|Snowcreek Cyn (SCE577): 62 MPH (1180')|Whitewater Cyn (SCE581): 62 MPH (1403')|Whitewater South: 60 MPH (1133')|Banning (SCE1645): 58 MPH (2442').

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very cold, Arctic air mass moved into the region in the middle of January. The combination of strong winds and very cold temperatures dropped wind chill values to dangerous levels.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values dropped to as low as 25 below zero with the coldest values during the nighttime hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very cold Arctic air mass, the second in one week, moved into the region and brought very cold temperatures and strong winds. The combination led to dangerously cold wind chill values, mainly during the nighttime hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values dropped to as low as 25 below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A North Pacific low pushed a front across the Alaska Peninsula on the evening of January 12. The resulting southeasterly gap flow led to a prolonged period of several hours during which high wind gusts were observed in Cold Bay. The low tracked across the eastern Bering Sea on January 13, pushing into the Kuskokwim Delta that evening. Northwesterly flow brought in cold air behind the low as it continued north, which led to gusty winds and blowing snow on Nunivak Island and along the Kuskokwim Delta coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blowing snow led to half mile visibility recorded at the Mekoryuk AWOS from 8:15 pm January 13 through 12:50 am January 14. Winds gusted as high as 44 knots (51 mph) during this period. Visibility improved through the morning hours of January 14 as snow intensity decreased with the low exiting into the Yukon Delta.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper air analysis depicted a negatively tilted trough over the western CONUS, with its axis extending from the central Rocky Mountains northwest into the Pacific Northwest. At the surface, a low-pressure center was deepening over the northern High Plains along with a secondary surface low in western Nebraska. Extending south out of these pressure centers was a Pacific cold front. At 21 UTC, a warm front was noted to extend southeast from southwest Nebraska into northeast Oklahoma. As the evening progressed, strong warm air advection ahead of the mature low-pressure pushed the warm front north into eastern Nebraska by 00 UTC. ||Along this warm front and ahead of the Pacific cold front, several lines of strong to severe thunderstorms moved through eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. The first line of strong storms moved through central and northeast Nebraska after 4:30 PM CDT. No severe reports were associated with these storms in the OAX CWA. Another intensifying segment of the same line moved into southeast Nebraska by 7:30 PM CDT, this time south of the northward advancing warm front. These storms tracked northeast through southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa, producing numerous severe wind gusts across the area and multiple spin-up tornadoes. The vast majority of wind gusts recorded with these storms ranged from 55 to 70 miles per hour. The strongest wind gust was measured at 71 miles per hour in Richardson County. 2 EF-0 tornadoes were confirmed in southeast Nebraska, both in Gage County. There were also an additional 3 tornadoes confirmed in southwest Iowa, all EF-1 tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 58 miles per hour wind gust was measured by a personal weather station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved across Georgia during the morning and early afternoon hours of the 9th. Most of the severe thunderstorms was collocated with the greatest instability across South-Central and East-Central Georgia. However, increased shear along the base of CAD was enough to organize an embedded cell which traversed the Atlanta Metro Area. This cell developed a brief circulation, necessitating a tornado warning. ||In total, rainfall amounts of 2 to 3.5 inches were common, with isolated amounts of 4.5 to 8 inches. These amounts produced flooding and flash flooding over the area, and contributed to the improvement of drought conditions over north Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Emergency Manager reported Broad Street at US 78 was closed due to water over the roadway. Radar estimates indicate between 4 and 5 inches of rain occurred over the area, resulting in the flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quasi-linear convective system (QLCS) developed along a strong cold front which pushed through a very high shear (80 knots of effective bulk shear)/low CAPE (500-1000 J/kg MLCAPE) environment across  the area and the nearby coastal waters. A few discrete storms also developed ahead of the main line. A Wind Advisory was in effect for the entire area except for coastal counties where a High Wind Warning was in effect. A Storm Warning was in effect for our marine zones.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple large trees down on homes and blocking roadways in and near the 900 block of Jones Avenue/NC-41. In addition, a large brick wall in main street commons in downtown Marion separated from a building and collapsed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The strong low pressure system which approached the area on January 31 pulled up a deep surge of tropical moisture which brought moderate to heavy precipitation to much of the area on February 1 through the morning of February 2. Much of the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Tehachapi Mountains measured between 0.75 inches and 1.50 inches of rainfall while the Sierra Foothills picked up 1 to 2 inches of rainfall ands the higher elevations of the Sierra Nevada picked up 1.5 to 3 inches of liquid precipitation. The precipitation fell as snow above 6000 feet for much of this event with several higher elevation SNOTELs picking up an estimated 1 to 2 feet of new snow. In addition to the precipitation, there were several reports of wind gusts exceeding 60 mph near Tehachapi and in the Grapevine area during the early morning of February 1. When the main cold front from this system moved across central California during the afternoon of February 1, scattered thunderstorms broke out over the San Joaquin Valley and Sierra foothills. Some of the storms produced small hail and there were several reports of roadway flooding in Bakersfield. The precipitation tapered off by the morning of February 2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Upper Tyndall Creek SNOTEL (11443 feet) picked up an estimated 12 inches of new snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep fetch of tropical moisture pushed into central California during the late evening of February 3 and spread inland during the morning of February 4 ahead of a strong low pressure center off the Southern California coast. By the time the precipitation had ended by the evening of February 5, much of the Sierra Nevada above 6000 feet had picked up between 1.5 and 3 feet of new snowfall. Moderate to locally heavy rainfall occurred in the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra as well as across the Kern County Mountains and Deserts where there were several reports of 0.75 to 1.5 inches of rainfall. In addition to the precipitation, strong downslope winds caused considerable damage during on February 4 with several stations reporting gusts exceeding 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The PG&E station at Pampa Peak measured a peak wind gust of76 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak storm system moved across central California between the afternoon of February 17 and the early morning of February 18. Skies cleared out behind this system as it moved east of the area, and with abundant low level moisture, clearing skies and light winds, areas of dense fog formed in the south end of the San Joaquin Valley near daybreak and resulted in travel impacts along interstate 5 as well as along portions of SR 99 and SR 58 in the Bakersfield area. The fog completely dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Delano. Web cameras indicated visibility below 1000 feet along SR 99.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Most areas of southern New Mexico had near average or above average precipitation in January.  This moisture helped to improve drought conditions slightly for portions of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The month started out with Extreme(D3) drought across the zone except the far north where it was Severe(D2) drought. By the end of the month, the south was in Extreme(D3) drought and the northern half was in Severe(D2) drought.  The Cooperative Observer at White Sands National Park reported 0.76 inches of precipitation, which was 0.28 inches above normal.

CZ_NAME: RIO GRANDE VALLEY OF EASTERN EL PASO/WESTERN HUDSPETH COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Near average precipitation for far west Texas in January led to no change in Severe(D2) to Extreme(D3) drought conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe(D2) drought continued across the entire zone in January.  The Cooperative Observer in Tornillo reported 0.36 inches of precipitation, which was exactly normal for the month.

CZ_NAME: RIO GRANDE VALLEY OF EASTERN HUDSPETH COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Near average precipitation for far west Texas in January led to no change in Severe(D2) to Extreme(D3) drought conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The entire zone remained in Severe(D2) drought through the month of January.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low moved through the Four Corners region with a 120 knot jet rounding it's base.  Plenty of upslope flow brought up to 10 inches of snow to the Cloudcroft area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cloudcroft Cooperative Observer about 2 miles south of town recorded 10 inches of snow.  A CoCoRaHs observer 2 miles southwest of town recorded 9 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving trough moved through the central Rockies with a 100 knot jet across much of New Mexico south to the International Border. Strong southwest winds ahead of a cold front gusted up to 71 mph in El Paso County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak gust of 60 mph was recorded at the Sierra Blanca - Texas Tech Mesonet site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of heavy lake effect snow affected far northwest Indiana early January 19th into early January 20th. Snowfall totals of 1 to 3 feet were common, mainly over La Porte County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow showers with brief intense snowfall rates and reduced visibilities developed during the afternoon and evening hours of January 19th. Additional periods of snow continued into the morning hours of January 20th. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 3 and 6 inches. There were reports of a few accidents and slide-offs across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of heavy lake effect snow affected far northwest Indiana early January 19th into early January 20th. Snowfall totals of 1 to 3 feet were common, mainly over La Porte County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow showers with brief intense snowfall rates and reduced visibilities developed during the evening hours of January 19th, with additional periods of snow persisting into the next day. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 3 and 6 inches. There were reports of a few accidents and slide-offs across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving trough moved through the central Rockies with a 100 knot jet across much of New Mexico south to the International Border. Strong southwest winds ahead of a cold front gusted up to 71 mph in El Paso County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak gust of 71 mph was recorded at South Franklin Peak.  Other gusts included 67 mph at the El Paso International Airport and 62 mph at Biggs Field. Damages across the zone included a roof blown off at the Joshua's Court Apartments which also damaged nearby vehicles in northeast El Paso.  Roof and AC units were damaged in portions of downtown El Paso.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air was already in place across northwestern Arkansas as a strong upper level disturbance approached the area of the 21st. Precipitation spread into the area during the evening of the 21st, as warm and moist air was lifted over the shallow cold air near the surface, resulting in widespread freezing rain. The freezing rain continued across the region into the afternoon of the 22nd, with surface temperatures slowly rising above 32 degrees. Some areas received 0.25 to 0.40 inches of ice accumulation. There were some power outages reported across the region, and roads became ice-covered and treacherous.

Strong thunderstorms developed across northeastern Oklahoma during the evening of the 11th, ahead of a cold front that pushed into the area. Low level moisture increased ahead of the front, supporting moderately strong instability. Wind shear was very strong across the area with the approach of a strong upper level disturbance. The strongest thunderstorms produced hail up to nickel size.

Low level moisture increased ahead of the front, supporting moderately strong instability. Wind shear was very strong across the area with the approach of a strong upper level disturbance. Strong thunderstorms developed across northeastern Oklahoma during the evening of the 11th, ahead of a cold front that pushed into the area. Low level moisture increased ahead of the front, supporting moderately strong instability. Wind shear was very strong across the area with the approach of a strong upper level disturbance. The thunderstorms intensified as they approached the Arkansas border late in the evening, resulting in the strongest thunderstorms producing damaging wind and hail up to quarter size.

CZ_NAME: SOUTH END OF THE UPPER SIERRA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper trough dropped out of the Gulf of Alaska on February 29 and had deepened off the Pacific Northwest coast on March 1 spreading widespread precipitation as far south a central California. The trough then slowly moved east across the Pacific Northwest on March 2 and 3 before moving east of the region on March 4. This system brought moderate to heavy precipitation to the Sierra Nevada which picked up between 2 and 4 inches of liquid precipitation north of Kings Canyon and 1 to 2 inches further south. The precipitation fell as snow above 5000 feet for the duration of the event and produced 2 to 4 feet on new snowfall north of Kings Canyon and 1.5 to 3 feet of snow further south. This system also produced a half inch to an inch of rainfall in Merced County and a quarter to half inch across most of the remainder of the San Joaquin Valley. Most of the Kern County Mountains and Deserts picked up 1 to 2 tenths of an inch of rainfall. In addition to the precipitation, strong winds also accompanied this system and combined with the snow to produce near blizzard conditions over the Sierra Nevada north of Kings Canyon between the morning of March 1 and the morning of March 3. Scattered thunderstorms also broke out during the afternoons of March 1 and March 2 over parts of the San Joaquin Valley. While the thunderstorms were not heavy rain producers, several funnel clouds were observed and one cell produced a weak tornado in northeast Madera during the afternoon of March 1. In addition to the precipitation, several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts measured wind gusts exceeding 45 mph between the evening of March 2 and the early morning of March 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bear Peak RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 66 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold air and winter weather overspread a large portion of the state from the 14th through 15th with lingering snow and cold through the 17th. Snowfall totals across portions of northern Arkansas exceeded 6-8 inches in some locations. Elsewhere, snow and sleet totals exceeded 1-2 inches across much of the rest of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow was measured at 3.5 inches in Heber Springs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area high pressure was departing the region to the east as a new storm system approached from the west. It was cold enough across the northwest half of Arkansas to begin as mainly snow, but precipitation changed over to rain by early afternoon. In total, snowfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches was common over portions of central, western, northern, and much of northwest Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow was measured at 3.0 inches in Omaha.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Most of South Central Texas had above normal precipitation in January, but the western Hill Country and Edwards Plateau had another month of below normal rainfall. Most of the area saw drought conditions improve. Blanco, Gillespie, Guadalupe, Medina, and Williamson Counties improved from Extreme (D3) drought to Severe (D2). Bandera and Kendall remained in D3 and Kerr remained in D2. Area reservoirs continued to be below normal conservation pool level. Medina Lake dropped 0.3 feet and was 89.6 feet below normal. The Edwards Aquifer rose 6.4 feet but was still 23.6 feet below normal. Most public water systems encouraged at least voluntary water restrictions and many had mandatory restrictions in effect. Some of the larger services had the following: Fredericksburg Stage 4, Georgetown, and Kerrville Stage 2. At the end of the month, the 7-day average streamflow was much below (<10%) normal on the Medina and upper Guadalupe Rivers. The San Gabriel River was above normal. Of the counties in D2 or worse drought only Medina had an outdoor burn ban in effect at the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of South Central Texas had above normal precipitation in January, but the western Hill Country and Edwards Plateau had another month of below normal rainfall. Most of the area saw drought conditions improve. Blanco, Gillespie, Guadalupe, Medina, and Williamson Counties improved from Extreme (D3) drought to Severe (D2). Bandera and Kendall remained in D3 and Kerr remained in D2. Area reservoirs continued to be below normal conservation pool level. Medina Lake dropped 0.3 feet and was 89.6 feet below normal. The Edwards Aquifer rose 6.4 feet but was still 23.6 feet below normal. Most public water systems encouraged at least voluntary water restrictions and many had mandatory restrictions in effect. Some of the larger services had the following: Fredericksburg Stage 4, Georgetown, and Kerrville Stage 2. At the end of the month, the 7-day average streamflow was much below (<10%) normal on the Medina and upper Guadalupe Rivers. The San Gabriel River was above normal. Of the counties in D2 or worse drought only Medina had an outdoor burn ban in effect at the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary surface boundary draped across northern NY/VT, during the evening and overnight hours of January 24th, was the focusing mechanism for moisture that entrained along the boundary and across the area. Temperatures were below freezing across much of central and eastern VT that allowed for several hours of light freezing rain during the evening and overnight hours. Flat ice accumulations were generally 0.1 to 0.2 inches with isolated amounts around 0.25 inches. The main impacts were icy, hazardous travel.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flat ice accumulations of 0.1 to 0.2 inches were observed in sections of the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quasi-linear convective system (QLCS) developed along a strong cold front which pushed through a very high shear (80 knots of effective bulk shear)/low CAPE (500-1000 J/kg MLCAPE) environment across  the area and the nearby coastal waters. A few discrete storms also developed ahead of the main line. A Wind Advisory was in effect for the entire area except for coastal counties where a High Wind Warning was in effect. A Storm Warning was in effect for our marine zones.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust of 65 mph estimated in the town of Lydia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak storm system moved across central California between the afternoon of February 17 and the early morning of February 18. Skies cleared out behind this system as it moved east of the area, and with abundant low level moisture, clearing skies and light winds, areas of dense fog formed in the south end of the San Joaquin Valley near daybreak and resulted in travel impacts along interstate 5 as well as along portions of SR 99 and SR 58 in the Bakersfield area. The fog completely dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Web cameras indicated visibility below 1000 feet along Interstate 5.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across the area and brough heavy snow to portions of western Wyoming and strong wind to southern and central Wyoming. The heaviest snow well in the Tetons where 22 inches of new snow fell at the Jackson Hole Ski Resort. In areas East of the Divide, high wind was main concern. Wind gusts over 70 mph occurred in Natrona County with a maximum wind gust of 78 mph along Wyoming Boulevard. In Sweetwater County, a snow squall moved west to east across the country, bringing wind gusts up to 66 mph and visibility under one quarter mile at times, disrupting traffic along Interstate 80.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell though much of the Tetons. The highest amount reported was 22 inches the top of Jackson Hole Ski Resort.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to 8 inches of snow fell in the northern portions of the Jackson Valley. Amounts dropped further south with only 3 to 4 inches in the town of Jackson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep fetch of tropical moisture pushed into central California during the late evening of February 3 and spread inland during the morning of February 4 ahead of a strong low pressure center off the Southern California coast. By the time the precipitation had ended by the evening of February 5, much of the Sierra Nevada above 6000 feet had picked up between 1.5 and 3 feet of new snowfall. Moderate to locally heavy rainfall occurred in the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra as well as across the Kern County Mountains and Deserts where there were several reports of 0.75 to 1.5 inches of rainfall. In addition to the precipitation, strong downslope winds caused considerable damage during on February 4 with several stations reporting gusts exceeding 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a large tree in the roadway 3WNW Pine Mountain Club.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving storm system produced strong winds across much of Southern California January 10-11, with the highest winds recorded in the mountains and along the desert slopes the morning of January 11. Scattered showers occurred mainly across San Diego County, and several inches of snow were recorded in the San Bernardino and Riverside County Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds impacted the High Desert from the afternoon of January 10 through the late morning hours on January 11. The strongest winds occurred from early to mid-morning on January 11. The following are the strongest winds recorded across the zone:||Lucerne Valley (SCE266): 65 MPH (3938')|Cushenbury Springs (SCE269): 65 MPH (4099')|Lucerne Valley (SCE262): 61 MPH (3946')|Lucerne Valley (SCE484): 61 MPH (4490')|Johnson Valley (SCE400): 60 MPH (3107').

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds impacted the Coachella Valley from the late evening of January 10 through the late morning hours on January 11. The strongest winds occurred from early to mid-morning on January 11. The following are the strongest winds recorded across the zone:||Palm Springs Airport: 53 MPH (392')|Boyd Deep Cyn Reserve: 52 MPH (979')|Palm Springs Tram (SCE361): 49 MPH (2200')|Palm Canyon (49 MPH).||Gene Autry and Vista Chino at the wash were closed due to blowing sand and reduced visibility early in the morning on January 11. A big rig was overturned at the I-10 W/Dillon Road onramp, resulting in a closure of the onramp.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An EF-0 tornado tracked eight miles through Martin County, causing minor damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down to the south and west of I-95 before crossing the interstate around 4:43 PM EST. The system moved to the north-northeast into Palm City, where numerous trees were felled on properties between I-95 and SW Martin Hwy. The |circulation continued to the northeast in Stuart where numerous residents submitted videos of the tornado impacting portions of the Canopy Creek residential subdivision, though little in the way of damage was noted. Additional intermittent reports of downed |trees were reported along the path as it moved across Florida's Turnpike and into Stuart. ||The circulation eventually went on to produce a waterspout over the St. Lucie River that then pushed onshore and into the North River Shores subdivision before lifting and dissipating. The tornado produced minor damage here, including a few fallen trees |near the intersection of NW Pine Lake Dr and NW Fork Rd.

In total, snowfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches was common over portions of central, western, northern, and much of northwest Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow was measured at 1.0 inch near Kay and Oxley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: FM 1371 was closed near Caney Creek.

CZ_NAME: SOUTH END OF THE UPPER SIERRA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper trough dropped out of the Gulf of Alaska on February 29 and had deepened off the Pacific Northwest coast on March 1 spreading widespread precipitation as far south a central California. The trough then slowly moved east across the Pacific Northwest on March 2 and 3 before moving east of the region on March 4. This system brought moderate to heavy precipitation to the Sierra Nevada which picked up between 2 and 4 inches of liquid precipitation north of Kings Canyon and 1 to 2 inches further south. The precipitation fell as snow above 5000 feet for the duration of the event and produced 2 to 4 feet on new snowfall north of Kings Canyon and 1.5 to 3 feet of snow further south. This system also produced a half inch to an inch of rainfall in Merced County and a quarter to half inch across most of the remainder of the San Joaquin Valley. Most of the Kern County Mountains and Deserts picked up 1 to 2 tenths of an inch of rainfall. In addition to the precipitation, strong winds also accompanied this system and combined with the snow to produce near blizzard conditions over the Sierra Nevada north of Kings Canyon between the morning of March 1 and the morning of March 3. Scattered thunderstorms also broke out during the afternoons of March 1 and March 2 over parts of the San Joaquin Valley. While the thunderstorms were not heavy rain producers, several funnel clouds were observed and one cell produced a weak tornado in northeast Madera during the afternoon of March 1. In addition to the precipitation, several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts measured wind gusts exceeding 45 mph between the evening of March 2 and the early morning of March 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Walker Pass RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 76 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold air and winter weather overspread a large portion of the state from the 14th through 15th with lingering snow and cold through the 17th. Snowfall totals across portions of northern Arkansas exceeded 6-8 inches in some locations. Elsewhere, snow and sleet totals exceeded 1-2 inches across much of the rest of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow was measured at 1.5 inches in Hot Springs.

CZ_NAME: NORTHWESTERN LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS INCLUDING THE INTERSTATE 5 CORRIDOR
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A third round of strong and gusty north winds impacted many sections of Southwestern California. Wind gusts, up to 78 MPH, were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A third round of strong and gusty north winds impacted many sections of Southwestern California. Wind gusts, up to 78 MPH, were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blast of winter weather cross through northeast Kentucky during the late evening hours of January 18th under the influence of a strong low pressure system. Even after its departure, northwesterly flow invited moisture and cold air from the Great Lakes region to progress downward and promoted continued snow showers through the day on the 19th and into the morning hours of January 20th. Generally 2 to 4 inches of snow fell across eastern Kentucky during this time.

Most of South Central Texas had above normal precipitation in January, but the western Hill Country and Edwards Plateau had another month of below normal rainfall. Most of the area saw drought conditions improve. Blanco, Gillespie, Guadalupe, Medina, and Williamson Counties improved from Extreme (D3) drought to Severe (D2). Bandera and Kendall remained in D3 and Kerr remained in D2. Area reservoirs continued to be below normal conservation pool level. Medina Lake dropped 0.3 feet and was 89.6 feet below normal. The Edwards Aquifer rose 6.4 feet but was still 23.6 feet below normal. Most public water systems encouraged at least voluntary water restrictions and many had mandatory restrictions in effect. Some of the larger services had the following: Fredericksburg Stage 4, Georgetown, and Kerrville Stage 2. At the end of the month, the 7-day average streamflow was much below (<10%) normal on the Medina and upper Guadalupe Rivers. The San Gabriel River was above normal. Of the counties in D2 or worse drought only Medina had an outdoor burn ban in effect at the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of South Central Texas had above normal precipitation in January, but the western Hill Country and Edwards Plateau had another month of below normal rainfall. Most of the area saw drought conditions improve. Blanco, Gillespie, Guadalupe, Medina, and Williamson Counties improved from Extreme (D3) drought to Severe (D2). Bandera and Kendall remained in D3 and Kerr remained in D2. Area reservoirs continued to be below normal conservation pool level. Medina Lake dropped 0.3 feet and was 89.6 feet below normal. The Edwards Aquifer rose 6.4 feet but was still 23.6 feet below normal. Most public water systems encouraged at least voluntary water restrictions and many had mandatory restrictions in effect. Some of the larger services had the following: Fredericksburg Stage 4, Georgetown, and Kerrville Stage 2. At the end of the month, the 7-day average streamflow was much below (<10%) normal on the Medina and upper Guadalupe Rivers. The San Gabriel River was above normal. Of the counties in D2 or worse drought only Medina had an outdoor burn ban in effect at the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a highly unstable airmass in place, a meandering front, a dryline, and a shortwave trough all worked together to generate multiple rounds of thunderstorms May 23 and 24. In addition to large hail and damaging winds, multiple tornadoes also occurred along with a few instances of flash flooding. A total of 6 tornadoes occurred in Central and East Texas: 2 EF-1s, 3 EF-0s, and 1 EF-U.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media relayed a report of 1 inch hail in Hillsboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved across Georgia during the morning and early afternoon hours of the 9th. Most of the severe thunderstorms was collocated with the greatest instability across South-Central and East-Central Georgia. However, increased shear along the base of CAD was enough to organize an embedded cell which traversed the Atlanta Metro Area. This cell developed a brief circulation, necessitating a tornado warning. ||In total, rainfall amounts of 2 to 3.5 inches were common, with isolated amounts of 4.5 to 8 inches. These amounts produced flooding and flash flooding over the area, and contributed to the improvement of drought conditions over north Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree downed along Dennis Creek Road at Monroe St.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: By mid week, after a rather tranquil start to the New Year, a weak occluded low split from the broader trough, then elongated as it drove south west of the Sierra crest limiting QPF totals over our region. Guidance showed that frontogenetic forcing, however, would amplify in central Nevada, and stretch west into the eastern Sierra and Mono County. The enhanced lift, coupled with precipitation banding, as projected by EC EFI/SOT and blended guidance showed a snowfall Boom potential  for at least moderate snow south of US-50 in western NV.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CO-OP Observer (TAAC1) located in Tahoma, CA, and a CoCoRaHS station (CA-ED-9) located 0.5 mi S of Tahoma, CA both reported a 24 hour snowfall total of 6.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak coastal storm moved passed southern New England on January 16th. Light snow overspread northern New York by mid-morning and ended by early evening. Snowfall totals ranged from 1 to 3 inches in St. Lawrence county to 3 to 6 inches in Essex county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals of 3 to 6 inches were observed and accounted for some hazardous travel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak coastal storm moved passed southern New England on January 16th. Light snow overspread Vermont during the morning and ended during the evening. Snowfall totals ranged from 3 to 7 inches across the region with the higher totals in the higher terrain of central VT. The main impacts were numerous traffic accidents, despite the dryness of the snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals of 4 to 7 inches were observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure over the eastern Pacific Ocean, and strong high pressure well inland resulted in a tight gradient with south to southwest winds reaching warning criteria.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Deer Mountain reported peak winds of 35 mph with gusts to 70 mph. Van Bremmer reported peak winds of 26 mph with gusts to 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass had previously invaded the Ohio Valley just a couple days prior to this heavy snowfall event. Bitterly cold air and breezy winds at times dropped wind chills below zero. From the 14th into the 15th of January, a couple weak upper level shortwave troughs supplied enhanced mid-level moisture to the region while increased meridional flow allowed more low-level moisture to advect northward from the Gulf of Mexico. Sufficient lift beneath the exit region of strong mid- and upper-level jet streaks allowed widespread snowfall to develop in two waves Sunday evening through Monday evening. The heavier snow bands set up across south-central Kentucky, with 3 to 6 inches of accumulation roughly south of a line from Bowling Green to Richmond. Localized 6+ inch totals were noted in the Lake Cumberland region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Total snowfall accumulation of 3 to 5 inches occurred across Adair County ending the evening of January 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across the area and brough heavy snow to portions of western Wyoming and strong wind to southern and central Wyoming. The heaviest snow well in the Tetons where 22 inches of new snow fell at the Jackson Hole Ski Resort. In areas East of the Divide, high wind was main concern. Wind gusts over 70 mph occurred in Natrona County with a maximum wind gust of 78 mph along Wyoming Boulevard. In Sweetwater County, a snow squall moved west to east across the country, bringing wind gusts up to 66 mph and visibility under one quarter mile at times, disrupting traffic along Interstate 80.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were sustained over 50 mph for over an hour at the Fales Rock RAWS site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific system moved into western Wyoming and brought another round of heavy snow to western Wyoming. The heaviest snow fell in southwestern Wyoming with up to 20 inches of new snow in the Salt and Wyoming Range. Several locations in the Tetons also received over a foot of snow. Amounts in the western valleys were generally 7 to 13 inches in the Star Valley and 6 to 9 inches in the Jackson Valley. The snow combined with gusty wind that brought difficult travel and some road closures. Some areas East of the Divide had high winds, with gusts as high as 75 mph around Buffalo.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over a foot of new snow fell through most of the Salt and Wyoming Range, with a maximum of 20 inches to the east of Smoot.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific system moved into western Wyoming and brought another round of heavy snow to western Wyoming. The heaviest snow fell in southwestern Wyoming with up to 20 inches of new snow in the Salt and Wyoming Range. Several locations in the Tetons also received over a foot of snow. Amounts in the western valleys were generally 7 to 13 inches in the Star Valley and 6 to 9 inches in the Jackson Valley. The snow combined with gusty wind that brought difficult travel and some road closures. Some areas East of the Divide had high winds, with gusts as high as 75 mph around Buffalo.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell through the Star Valley, with 6 to 12 inches of new snow in most locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong, early-season area of low pressure and accompanying cold front helped to initiate and organize a line of strong to severe thunderstorms across portions of the Trans Pecos.

A disturbance aloft combined with a lee trough over western North Carolina led to isolated to scattered showers and storms over the Piedmont, Sandhills, and Coastal Plain in the early evening hours. Most of the storms were sub-severe, but a few damaging wind reports and flash flooding were reported in Wake and Johnston Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Raleigh dispatch reported that a tree fell on powerlines, knocking out power. This was near the intersection of Shepard School Rd and Rosinburg Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to scattered showers and storms ahead of a surface cold front draped over the Tennessee Valley developed early in the morning over the eastern Piedmont, Sandhills, and Coastal Plain. Additional scattered storms developed over the northeast Piedmont and northern Coastal Plain in the afternoon hours. Several reports of wind damage were noted with the thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported quarter inch hail near the town of Enfield.

Winter weather kept its grip on southwest Virginia as a second low pressure system in a matter of days crossed through the region. Snow began to fall during the late evening hours of January 18th and would remain the case through the morning of January 20th thanks to lake enhanced moisture continuing snow showers from the northwest. A trained spotter in Buchanan County measured 4 inches of snow at their home in Grundy, while generally 1 to 2 inches fell across southwest Virginia. Snow would finally come to an end on the 20th as high pressure established residency over the area.

Winter weather kept its grip on southwest Virginia as a second low pressure system in a matter of days crossed through the region. Snow began to fall during the late evening hours of January 18th and would remain the case through the morning of January 20th thanks to lake enhanced moisture continuing snow showers from the northwest. A trained spotter in Buchanan County measured 4 inches of snow at their home in Grundy, while generally 1 to 2 inches fell across southwest Virginia. Snow would finally come to an end on the 20th as high pressure established residency over the area.
A cold front caused flooding and wind damage over portions of the islands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Kaneohe had approximately 4,990 customers without power. Haleiwa had approximately 1,510 customers without power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front caused flooding and wind damage over portions of the islands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A NWS employee reported a power pole down along with tree branches on Lilipuna Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Most of South Central Texas had above normal precipitation in January, but the western Hill Country and Edwards Plateau had another month of below normal rainfall. Most of the area saw drought conditions improve. Blanco, Gillespie, Guadalupe, Medina, and Williamson Counties improved from Extreme (D3) drought to Severe (D2). Bandera and Kendall remained in D3 and Kerr remained in D2. Area reservoirs continued to be below normal conservation pool level. Medina Lake dropped 0.3 feet and was 89.6 feet below normal. The Edwards Aquifer rose 6.4 feet but was still 23.6 feet below normal. Most public water systems encouraged at least voluntary water restrictions and many had mandatory restrictions in effect. Some of the larger services had the following: Fredericksburg Stage 4, Georgetown, and Kerrville Stage 2. At the end of the month, the 7-day average streamflow was much below (<10%) normal on the Medina and upper Guadalupe Rivers. The San Gabriel River was above normal. Of the counties in D2 or worse drought only Medina had an outdoor burn ban in effect at the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of South Central Texas had above normal precipitation in January, but the western Hill Country and Edwards Plateau had another month of below normal rainfall. Most of the area saw drought conditions improve. Blanco, Gillespie, Guadalupe, Medina, and Williamson Counties improved from Extreme (D3) drought to Severe (D2). Bandera and Kendall remained in D3 and Kerr remained in D2. Area reservoirs continued to be below normal conservation pool level. Medina Lake dropped 0.3 feet and was 89.6 feet below normal. The Edwards Aquifer rose 6.4 feet but was still 23.6 feet below normal. Most public water systems encouraged at least voluntary water restrictions and many had mandatory restrictions in effect. Some of the larger services had the following: Fredericksburg Stage 4, Georgetown, and Kerrville Stage 2. At the end of the month, the 7-day average streamflow was much below (<10%) normal on the Medina and upper Guadalupe Rivers. The San Gabriel River was above normal. Of the counties in D2 or worse drought only Medina had an outdoor burn ban in effect at the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Nearly all of the eastern half of South Central Texas had above normal precipitation in January with large swaths of the I-35 corridor and Coastal Plains seeing three and four times normal rainfall. Drought conditions improved. Bexar, Comal, Hays, and Travis Counties all improved from Extreme (D3) drought to less than Severe (D2). Atascosa, Bastrop, Burnet, Caldwell, Gonzales, Karnes, Llano, and Wilson all improved from D2 to less than D2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly all of the eastern half of South Central Texas had above normal precipitation in January with large swaths of the I-35 corridor and Coastal Plains seeing three and four times normal rainfall. Drought conditions improved. Bexar, Comal, Hays, and Travis Counties all improved from Extreme (D3) drought to less than Severe (D2). Atascosa, Bastrop, Burnet, Caldwell, Gonzales, Karnes, Llano, and Wilson all improved from D2 to less than D2.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong system affected the region with steady southerly flow pushing water up into coastal communities both along the ocean and within the Delaware River/Bay and Chesapeake Bay. Water levels on the tidal Delaware River were higher due to 2 to 4+ inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding was reported in the tidal areas of the county, and there were numerous road closures. Many homes and other buildings were surrounded by flood waters with some minor property damage occurring. The tide gauge at Dewey Beach reached 4.44 feet MLLW, the tide gauge at Fenwick Island reached 3.54 feet MLLW, and the tide gauge at South Bethany Beach reached 3.89 feet MLLW.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread moderate flooding occurred in the tidal areas of Caroline County. There were several road closures with the flood waters approaching some homes and businesses. The tide gauge at Claiborne reached a level of 5.31 feet MLLW.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: By mid week, after a rather tranquil start to the New Year, a weak occluded low split from the broader trough, then elongated as it drove south west of the Sierra crest limiting QPF totals over our region. Guidance showed that frontogenetic forcing, however, would amplify in central Nevada, and stretch west into the eastern Sierra and Mono County. The enhanced lift, coupled with precipitation banding, as projected by EC EFI/SOT and blended guidance showed a snowfall Boom potential  for at least moderate snow south of US-50 in western NV.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public located Palisades Tahoe Ski Base, CA reported 24 hour storm total snowfall amounts of 7.0 inches at the base and 9.0 inches at the Alpine Lodge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved across Georgia during the morning and early afternoon hours of the 9th. Most of the severe thunderstorms was collocated with the greatest instability across South-Central and East-Central Georgia. However, increased shear along the base of CAD was enough to organize an embedded cell which traversed the Atlanta Metro Area. This cell developed a brief circulation, necessitating a tornado warning. ||In total, rainfall amounts of 2 to 3.5 inches were common, with isolated amounts of 4.5 to 8 inches. These amounts produced flooding and flash flooding over the area, and contributed to the improvement of drought conditions over north Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees down along Springhill Rd SSE of Alamo.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper air analysis depicted a negatively tilted trough over the western CONUS, with its axis extending from the central Rocky Mountains northwest into the Pacific Northwest. At the surface, a low-pressure center was deepening over the northern High Plains along with a secondary surface low in western Nebraska. Extending south out of these pressure centers was a Pacific cold front. At 21 UTC, a warm front was noted to extend southeast from southwest Nebraska into northeast Oklahoma. As the evening progressed, strong warm air advection ahead of the mature low-pressure pushed the warm front north into eastern Nebraska by 00 UTC. ||Along this warm front and ahead of the Pacific cold front, several lines of strong to severe thunderstorms moved through eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. The first line of strong storms moved through central and northeast Nebraska after 4:30 PM CDT. No severe reports were associated with these storms in the OAX CWA. Another intensifying segment of the same line moved into southeast Nebraska by 7:30 PM CDT, this time south of the northward advancing warm front. These storms tracked northeast through southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa, producing numerous severe wind gusts across the area and multiple spin-up tornadoes. The vast majority of wind gusts recorded with these storms ranged from 55 to 70 miles per hour. The strongest wind gust was measured at 71 miles per hour in Richardson County. 2 EF-0 tornadoes were confirmed in southeast Nebraska, both in Gage County. There were also an additional 3 tornadoes confirmed in southwest Iowa, all EF-1 tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 64 miles per hour wind gust was measured by a personal weather station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought heavy wet snow to much of the state of Kansas beginning on January 8th lasting into the morning of January 9th.   Northwest winds of 20 to 30 mph along with the snow caused additional impacts including blowing and drifting of roadways making travel more hazardous.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Manager measured 8 inches of snow in Seneca in Nemaha County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across the area and brough heavy snow to portions of western Wyoming and strong wind to southern and central Wyoming. The heaviest snow well in the Tetons where 22 inches of new snow fell at the Jackson Hole Ski Resort. In areas East of the Divide, high wind was main concern. Wind gusts over 70 mph occurred in Natrona County with a maximum wind gust of 78 mph along Wyoming Boulevard. In Sweetwater County, a snow squall moved west to east across the country, bringing wind gusts up to 66 mph and visibility under one quarter mile at times, disrupting traffic along Interstate 80.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind sensor along Wyoming Boulevard to the south of Casper had a maximum wind gust of 78 mph. Wind gusts of 67 mph occurred along Hat Six Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Arctic front dropped across Wyoming and brought heavy snow to portions of western Wyoming. The heaviest snow fell in the Tetons where up to 17 inches of new snow fell. Over a foot of snow fell in portions of the Salt and Wyoming Range. Amounts in the Jackson and Star Valleys generally ranged from 4 to 10 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate to heavy snow fell in the Jackson Valley, with 9 inches of new snow falling near Wilson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Arctic front dropped across Wyoming and brought heavy snow to portions of western Wyoming. The heaviest snow fell in the Tetons where up to 17 inches of new snow fell. Over a foot of snow fell in portions of the Salt and Wyoming Range. Amounts in the Jackson and Star Valleys generally ranged from 4 to 10 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around the Star Valley, 5 to 10 inches of new snow fell. The maximum amount of 10 inches fell near Turnerville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific system moved into western Wyoming and brought another round of heavy snow to western Wyoming. The heaviest snow fell in southwestern Wyoming with up to 20 inches of new snow in the Salt and Wyoming Range. Several locations in the Tetons also received over a foot of snow. Amounts in the western valleys were generally 7 to 13 inches in the Star Valley and 6 to 9 inches in the Jackson Valley. The snow combined with gusty wind that brought difficult travel and some road closures. Some areas East of the Divide had high winds, with gusts as high as 75 mph around Buffalo.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of snow and strong wind brought the closure of Highway 28 over South Pass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several supercell thunderstorms tracked across Washington, Morgan, and Adams Counties during the evening of May 20th, 2024. Large hail, up to 4.00 inches in diameter, accompanied the storms. There were several reports of 1.75 inch hail and larger. Radar showed a few tornadoes were possible, though just one was observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mping public report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front passed the coast on the 8th pushing the tide 1 foot below MLLW on the 9th and 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tide fell to one foot below MLLW during multiple tide cycles. The tide fell to a low of -2.48 feet MLLW at Freshwater Lock.

It was cold enough across the northwest half of Arkansas to begin as mainly snow, but precipitation changed over to rain by early afternoon. In total, snowfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches was common over portions of central, western, northern, and much of northwest Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow was estimated to a depth of 1.0 inch near Rosboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving cold front intersected an area of marginal instability resulting in a line of thunderstorms that raced across the Mid-South during the morning hours of February 28, 2024. There were isolated reports of damaging winds and small hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel-sized hail fell on Birmingham Ridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of disturbances moved across the area resulting in numerous flash flood events that resulted in the flooding of many homes, extensive high water rescues, and a flood-related fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five people were rescued from high water along FM2920 near Mueschke as a result of flooding along Spring Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of disturbances moved across the area resulting in numerous flash flood events that resulted in the flooding of many homes, extensive high water rescues, and a flood-related fatality.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding along Spring Creek resulted in floodwaters covering Robert Cemetery Rd, resulting in its closure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of disturbances moved across the area resulting in numerous flash flood events that resulted in the flooding of many homes, extensive high water rescues, and a flood-related fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding along the San Jacinto River resulted in extensive flooding in the McDade Estates neighborhood. Eleven adults, one infant, five dogs, and a horse were all rescued from the floodwaters. Approximately 50 homes were flooded as a result of the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper trough dropped out of the Gulf of Alaska on February 29 and had deepened off the Pacific Northwest coast on March 1 spreading widespread precipitation as far south a central California. The trough then slowly moved east across the Pacific Northwest on March 2 and 3 before moving east of the region on March 4. This system brought moderate to heavy precipitation to the Sierra Nevada which picked up between 2 and 4 inches of liquid precipitation north of Kings Canyon and 1 to 2 inches further south. The precipitation fell as snow above 5000 feet for the duration of the event and produced 2 to 4 feet on new snowfall north of Kings Canyon and 1.5 to 3 feet of snow further south. This system also produced a half inch to an inch of rainfall in Merced County and a quarter to half inch across most of the remainder of the San Joaquin Valley. Most of the Kern County Mountains and Deserts picked up 1 to 2 tenths of an inch of rainfall. In addition to the precipitation, strong winds also accompanied this system and combined with the snow to produce near blizzard conditions over the Sierra Nevada north of Kings Canyon between the morning of March 1 and the morning of March 3. Scattered thunderstorms also broke out during the afternoons of March 1 and March 2 over parts of the San Joaquin Valley. While the thunderstorms were not heavy rain producers, several funnel clouds were observed and one cell produced a weak tornado in northeast Madera during the afternoon of March 1. In addition to the precipitation, several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts measured wind gusts exceeding 45 mph between the evening of March 2 and the early morning of March 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Kaiser Point SNOTEL (9131 feet) picked up an estimated 18 inches of new snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to occasionally severe thunderstorms ahead of a cold front moved eastward across the Florida panhandle and big bend during the afternoon of January 27th. While most wind gusts along the line were in the 40-50 mph range, isolated areas received slightly stronger winds with isolated wind damage reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several power poles were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Nearly all of the eastern half of South Central Texas had above normal precipitation in January with large swaths of the I-35 corridor and Coastal Plains seeing three and four times normal rainfall. Drought conditions improved. Bexar, Comal, Hays, and Travis Counties all improved from Extreme (D3) drought to less than Severe (D2). Atascosa, Bastrop, Burnet, Caldwell, Gonzales, Karnes, Llano, and Wilson all improved from D2 to less than D2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly all of the eastern half of South Central Texas had above normal precipitation in January with large swaths of the I-35 corridor and Coastal Plains seeing three and four times normal rainfall. Drought conditions improved. Bexar, Comal, Hays, and Travis Counties all improved from Extreme (D3) drought to less than Severe (D2). Atascosa, Bastrop, Burnet, Caldwell, Gonzales, Karnes, Llano, and Wilson all improved from D2 to less than D2.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved across Georgia during the morning and early afternoon hours of the 9th. Most of the severe thunderstorms was collocated with the greatest instability across South-Central and East-Central Georgia. However, increased shear along the base of CAD was enough to organize an embedded cell which traversed the Atlanta Metro Area. This cell developed a brief circulation, necessitating a tornado warning. ||In total, rainfall amounts of 2 to 3.5 inches were common, with isolated amounts of 4.5 to 8 inches. These amounts produced flooding and flash flooding over the area, and contributed to the improvement of drought conditions over north Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees down in Northwest Warner Robins between GA247 and North Houston Lake Boulevard and between Watson Boulevard and Dunbar Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another complex of thunderstorms moved southeast through North and Central Texas during the day on May 30, producing scattered wind damage and severe hail along with some flash flooding. A second round of storms initiated along the dryline Thursday evening, producing more severe weather and flash flooding overnight into the early morning hours of May 31. After above normal rainfall throughout the month, grounds were so saturated that it didn't take much to cause flash flooding or knock down trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: TXDOT reported multiple closed roadways across the city due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding in and around town with 4 to 6 inches of depth in most areas.

Snowfall amounts across VT were generally 4 to 12+ inches with the lighter amounts in the northern Champlain Valley and Essex county with the higher snowfall totals *8-12+ inches) across the eastern slope communities of the southern and central Green Mountains. The main impacts from this storm were hazardous road conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals of 6 to 9 inches were observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep fetch of tropical moisture pushed into central California during the late evening of February 3 and spread inland during the morning of February 4 ahead of a strong low pressure center off the Southern California coast. By the time the precipitation had ended by the evening of February 5, much of the Sierra Nevada above 6000 feet had picked up between 1.5 and 3 feet of new snowfall. Moderate to locally heavy rainfall occurred in the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra as well as across the Kern County Mountains and Deserts where there were several reports of 0.75 to 1.5 inches of rainfall. In addition to the precipitation, strong downslope winds caused considerable damage during on February 4 with several stations reporting gusts exceeding 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Southern California Edison station at Huntington Lake measured a peak wind gust of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large slow moving upper low pressure system off the northern California Coast pulled up a deep fetch of moisture of tropical origin which pushed into central California during the late afternoon of February 18 through the evening of February 19. A period of strong wind gusts accompanied the precipitation during the morning of January 19 and the snow level was around 7500 feet for much of the event. Much of the San Joaquin Valley and West Side Hills picked up between a half inch and an inch of rainfall. The Sierra Nevada and adjacent foothills generally picked up between an inch and 2 inches of liquid precipitation with several SNOTELS picking up an estimated 12 to 20 inches of new snowfall. Between a quarter and a half of an inch of rain fell across most of the Tehachapi Mountain range while the Kern County Deserts generally had less than a quarter inch of rainfall. Scattered thunderstorm broke out over the San Joaquin Valley  by late morning on January 19 and continued through late afternoon. Several of the  thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall and small hail. There were also several reports of roadway flooding in the Visalia area. The precipitation tapered off by late evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported that a member of the public was unable to access his vehicle due to roadway flooding in Winton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quasi-linear convective system (QLCS) developed along a strong cold front which pushed through a very high shear (80 knots of effective bulk shear)/low CAPE (500-1000 J/kg MLCAPE) environment across  the area and the nearby coastal waters. A few discrete storms also developed ahead of the main line. A Wind Advisory was in effect for the entire area except for coastal counties where a High Wind Warning was in effect. A Storm Warning was in effect for our marine zones.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured gust.
